narrative: On January 15, 2021 @ 9:45AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a Case Management Tele-Inspection for the purpose of increasing Capacity from 36 to 48. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry met with Staff Manager Leticia Woodruff. Facility/Office was immediately virtually toured. Currently this facility has apartments located Santa Barbara, Ventura, Oxnard, Newbury Park, Moorepark and Simi Valley). LPA Landry asked Facility Representative to submit an updated LIC 401 Operating Budget to reflect its new requested capacity and current capacity too. Office still maintains locked file cabinets for confidential records. Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Form, Facility Sketch, Ombudsman Information & License were posted. LPA Landry received a new LIC 500 Personnel Report and LIC 200. LPA discussed program specific regulations with the applicant including the following: 1. Administrator Requirements 2. Social Worker/ Social Worker Supervisor Requirements and Ratios 3. Transportation Requirements 4. Telephone Requirements (clients maintain cell phones) 5. Reporting Requirements 6. Physical Plant Requirements 7. Storage of valuables (clients are responsible for their valuables left in common areas, but facility has renters insurance) At this time staff records are kept at Aspiranet's Headquarters and clients records are locked in Manager's office within a locked filing cabinet. Increase in capacity was already submitted to Licensing Program Manager Rosa Rodriguez, approved and signed. Exit interview conducted. Copy of Report given to staff.

investigation_findings: 13On April 15, 2021 @ 4:28PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a tele-inspection Interview regarding the allegation listed above. LPA spoke with Core Program Manager. This investigation initially began on 9/02/20 and since then more information has been received. On or around April 8, 2020 child #2 did take a picture from child#1's instagram and then posted that picture on her own instagram. Child #2 denies the picture was lewd. LPA Landry was unable to interview child #1. Facility provided LPA Landry with Special Incident Report. Law Enforcement was involved, counseled client(s) but left no report. Core Program Manager interviewed both clients, counseled them and made a safety plan for each client. Safety Plan dated 4/10/20 included youths having no contact, directions for blocking (restricting) individuals from social media accounts, apologies and a warning that these behaviors are in violation program rules. Based on information received at this time LPA Landry is not able to determine Lack of Care and Supervision occurred. Therefore, the allegation listed above is unsubstantiated. “

narrative:
On 11/30/21 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Olivia Rosas made announced visit to Aspiranet Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Random Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) THP+FC Supervising Social Worker who granted access to the Administrative Office and an inspection was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 11/30/21. The annual fees are current. LPA Rosas inspected following during the inspection The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) to forty-eight (48) participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty one (21). There are currently thirty-three (32) participants in placement including remote sites in the Ventura County (sites are in Ventura, Oxnard, Newbury Park, Moorepark and Simi Valley). Facility has two (2) Social Workers (1 per 12 participants) and one (1) Social Worker Supervisor (1 per 8 Social Workers) and one (1) Supervising Social Worker. The facility is currently operating within staff ratio. The administrative office is located at 5284 Adolfo Road, Camarillo CA 93012. The office is located on the first floor of the Aspiranet office building and is set up as follows: Upon entering the building the office has a lobby and reception area. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the reception area entrance in the sign-in area. There is an Office for behavioral health staff, Foster Care (FFA supervisor), THPP staff, THPP Supervisor, Facilities Director/THPP Administrator, Behavioral Health clinicians, Foster Care Social Worker/Adoption Social Workers, Adoption Supervisor, Visitation/Multi-purpose room, File Room, Copy/Mail Box room. In the center of the office is a large conference room that can be split into two separate conference rooms. LPA observed locked file cabinets in Program Manager office that contained the participants' files, and discharged files in the locked cabinets. LPA Rosas obtained a copy of the Emergency Exiting Plan for the building. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 2

LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas received the following forms for review, copy of applicable waiver and exceptions, Register of participants, Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan Protocols, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C). The certification/decertification list of participants living units. The facility has hard files in addition they keep files and documents in digital system called Watson Care Management (WCM). Staff Records Review: LPA Rosas attempted to review four (4) staff records. Staff files are stored in Aspiranet Human Resources (HR) Headquarters in San Francisco and they are not able to provide copies of confidential employee documents. LPA will make appointment with HR to be on-site to be able to access confidential files. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report and confirmed that facility has two (2) Social Workers (1 per 12 participants) and one (1) Social Worker Supervisor (1 per 8 Social Workers) who carries social worker caseload. The facility is currently operating within staff ratio. LPA review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 11/29/2021 that indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. The facility has social worker personnel available on a 24-hour basis to respond to any emergency. Clients Records Review: LPA reviewed three (3) clients records which meet requirement. LPA reviewed the Admission Agreements, date of placement in unit, Emergency Contact information, and Needs and Services Plan. The facility keeps a file with required forms and uses a digital WCM system for TILP, Case Notes, and other required documents. The documents are available upon request and can be printed for review. Staff Interviews: LPA Rosas conducted a confidential interview with one (1) staff. LPA obtained contact information for Social Workers to conduct interviews at a later time. Client Interviews: LPA was not able to conduct participant interviews. LPA Rosas obtained register of participants with contact information to conduct interviews at a later time. LPA Rosas by email send the following PINS to S1 PIN 20-17-CRP: New Background Check Requirements, Assembly Bill 819 (Chapter 777, Statutes of 2019), PIN 21-20-CRP: Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children’s Residential Licensees, PIN 21-05-CRP: The Family Urgent Response System (FURS). There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Due to conflicting statements LPA Landry is unable to determine if the above allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. “Unsubstantiated” means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted. Copy of Appeal Rights and this report was emailed to Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On Wednesday February 23, 2022 @12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kathy Landry conducted a virtual inspection with Facility Manager listed above. LPA Landry conducted an entrance interview and discussed the allegation listed above. Facility Manager confirmed 28 clients residing in the program at this time. This investigation initially began 11/13/2020. Since then more information has been received. Exact date unknown but client #1 borrowed money from client #2 (against program rules and agreement). Sometime afterward both clients were no longer friends when client #2 requested repayment of the money loaned to client #1. Facility Manager and Life Coach were consulted and tried to get both clients to resolve their issues. Both clients were reminded the transaction was against program rules & agreement. When the situation could not be resolved both clients were reminded of the consequences of their actions including loss of funds loaned to possible court proceedings to sue for the unreturned funds. A Safety Plan was also drafted for both clients. At this time LPA Landry has received conflicting statements regarding Personal Rights Violation where staff did not provide a safe environment for these two clients and their prohibited money transaction ----->

narrative: Information provided to the Department alleged Nonminor Dependent#2 (NMD2), a roommate of NMD1, was involved in altercations with a male guest while NMD1 was present in the living unit. Furthermore, pets belonging to NMD2 reportedly soiled the carpet throughout the living unit. NMD2 admitted the carpet in the living unit was soiled by pets belonging to NMD2. Facility created a Corrective Action Plan (CAP) was put into place to have the pets removed from the home. Facility stated NMD2 did not comply with the request. On 08/09/2021, an unannounced inspection was conducted by LPA Larios to the living unit and observed a soiled carpet and the smell of animal waste was detected in the bedroom belonging to NMD1. Facility reported due to COVID-19 restrictions staff was not doing on-site inspections. Facility reported they are now having weekly home visits to living units. In addition, on 08/09/2021, LPA Larios and 12/10/2021, LPA Rosas conducted a records review on Nonminor Dependent#1 (NMD1) and Nonminor Dependent#2 (NMD2) and obtained copies of weekly contact notes, Special Incident Reports, Housing Agreements, and Agency Placement related documents. LPA Larios and LPA Rosas conducted interviews with witnesses and parties related to the investigation. On 07/29/2021, the Department assigned complaint investigation to the Monterey Park Children’s Residential Program Regional Office- Foster Family Agency (FFA) #567806515 inaccurately. The correct corresponded facility is THPP+FC #565801976 and is assigned to the El Segundo Children’s Residential Program Regional Office (ESCRP). On 11/19/2021, LPA Larios delivered findings to Foster Family Agency (FFA) and dismissed the complaint and forward to ESCRP to investigate. On 12/10/2021, the ESCRP received the complaint to investigate. Based on information gathered from interviews, photos and inspection conducted of the living unit on 08/09/2021, the allegation is substantiated, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. The Department has concluded, based on the preponderance of the evidence obtained during this investigation, that the allegation of Neglect and Lack of Supervision is substantiated. During the inspection investigation the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections was discussed, and appeal rights were provided. LPA Rosas provided a copy of this licensing report to S1. Exit interview was conducted with A1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On March 2, 2023, at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to Aspiranet Transitional Housing Program Placement THPP for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA Rosas, met with Staff#1 (S1) and together discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, LPA Christopher Larios and LPA Rosas interviewed witnesses and pertinent parties related to the investigation. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 03/02/2023. Based on the confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process, record review, statements obtained, LPA Rosas concluded the allegation of staff did not ensure that youths living unit is safe and sanitary therefore, the findings are substantiated. On 07/29/2021, the Department received a complaint alleging Nonminor Dependent#1 (NMD1) was not afforded a living unit that was safe and sanitary by the Transitional Housing Program Placement (THPP). Report continues LIC-9099C

deficiencies.description: Plan of Operation 86022(e) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on evidence obtained through interviews, photos and inspection, the licensee did not insure NMD1 was afforded a living unit that was safe and sanitary which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall develop a plan and update Plan of Operation to ensure inspections are conducted to the Nonminor Dependents living units in order to provide a sanitary living condition. The licensee will provide an updated Plan of Operation and proof that facility staff were trained on the updates. The Plan of Correction (POC) is due by 03/30/2023 to LPM Kevin Sauk.

narrative: On July 29, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff disclosed personal information regarding a Nonminor Dependent. Statements obtained from interviews conducted had conflicting statements. On 08/09/2021, LPA Larios and 12/10/2021, LPA Rosas conducted a records review on Nonminor Dependent#1 (NMD1) and Nonminor Dependent#2 (NMD2) and obtained copies of weekly contact notes, Special Incident Reports, Housing Agreements, and Agency Placement related documents. LPA Larios and LPA Rosas conducted interviews with witnesses and parties related to the investigation. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Personal Rights. On 07/29/2021, the Department assigned complaint investigation to the Monterey Park Children’s Residential Program Regional Office- Foster Family Agency (FFA) #567806515 inaccurately. The correct corresponded facility is THPP+FC #565801976 and is assigned to the El Segundo Children’s Residential Program Regional Office (ESCRP). On 11/19/2021, LPA Larios delivered findings to Foster Family Agency (FFA) and dismissed the dismissed the complaint and forward to ESCRP to investigate. On 12/10/2021, the ESCRP received the complaint to investigate. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. The Department has decided that the allegation of Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On March 8, 2023 at 09:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado met with Program Director, Michele Gracia, who granted access into the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct a required two-year annual inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents. The Administrative Office is located at 3600 Central Avenue Unit 5, Riverside CA 92506. Presently, the facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement for non-minor participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently 33 participants residing in the program, which include 21 remote sites throughout Riverside County. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, a resource area equipped a computers and work areas for the participants. The office has cubicles/offices for the Program Director, Supervisor, and Life Coaches, in addition there is a kitchen area for the staff. There are working telephones, office equipment, furniture, and supplies located throughout the office space. LPA observed Participant files were stored in a locked cabinet within a locked storage room. Staff files are kept in the headquarters office in San Francisco and LPA’s were provided electronic copies. Currently the facility is staffed with three full-time Life Coaches (social workers), one part-time Life Coach (social worker), one Housing Specialist, one Supervising Social Worker, and one Program Director. The Program Director was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Program Director is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contact. LPA’s reviewed seven staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA’s reviewed eight non-minor dependent files. All files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. Facility provided a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. The facility is in compliance no deficiency were notes at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Michele Gracia, a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

On 02/23/2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Kendal Zirbes and Anastasia Flores met with Core Program Manager Director Stephen Morales who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an annual inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non Minor Dependents. The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Program Manager Director Stephen Morales at 11:25am. LPA’s also inspected one remote site virtually during inspection via FaceTime. Presently, the THPP is licensed to provide care for 75 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently 33 participants utilizing the program. The participates reside in nine of remote sites throughout San Bernardino County. The THPP Administrative office is located in San Bernardino CA. The office is located on the first floor of a retail business establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, a resource area equipped with a computer and work area for the THPP participants, offices for the Management team (Administrator, Program Director, Program Manager, Program Supervisor), cubicles for the Life Coach’s (Social Workers/Case Manager), Housing Specialist. There was a kitchen area for the staff, and additional conference room. The offices space was equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. LPA observed the THPP participant files were stored in a locked storage room. The storage room housed files for two different Aspiranet programs which utilize the same office space. Each of the program files were located in separate locked filing cabinets. THPP personnel files were in a locked safe within the Core Program Director office. Currently the THPP is staffed with three full-time life coaches (social workers), one housing specialists, one Core Program Supervisor (Supervising Social Worker/Program Manager), Core Program Director, and an Administrator. Report continued of page two

During the inspection, LPA's reviewed five participant records and four staff files. LPA observed that three of five Participant files (P1, P2, P3) did not contain a signed Needs and Service Plan by the authorized authorized representative. Based on the record review, the THPP did not ensure the participant needs and service plans were signed by the authorized representative. Therefore, the The Facility is cited under the Non Minor Dependent regulations, 86168.3 (f) Needs and Service Plan. During this inspection LPA discussed Law Enforcement incident reports and the process for designating a new facility Administrator. Exit interview was conducted with Core Program Director Stephen Morals and Core Program Supervisor Andrea Castillo. After the interview, a copy of this report, the Confidential Names List ( LIC 811) dated February 23, 2021, and the appeal rights were emailed to Core Program Director.

On November 22, 2021 at 09:50 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s), Anastasia Flores and Leslie Covarrubias met with Core Program Supervisor, Andrea Castillo and Core Program Director Stephen Morales who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an annual inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents. The administrative office was toured both inside and out with Ms. Castillo at 10:04 AM. Presently, the THPP is licensed to provide care for 75 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently 25 participants utilizing the program. The participants reside in nine remote sites throughout San Bernardino County. The THPP Administrative office is located in San Bernardino CA. The office is located on the first floor of a retail business establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, a resource area equipped with a computer and work area for the THPP participants, offices for the Management team (Administrator, Program Director, Program Manager, Program Supervisor), cubicles for the Life Coach’s (Social Workers/Case Manager), Housing Specialist. There was a kitchen area for the staff, and additional conference room. The office space was equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. LPA’s observed the THPP participant files were stored in a locked storage room. The storage room housed files for two different Aspiranet programs which utilize the same office space. Each of the program files were located in separate locked filing cabinets. THPP personnel files were not readily available, LPA’s were informed the facility is not allowed to store the personnel files at this location and will have them readily available on the next site visit. Currently the THPP is staffed with three full-time life coaches (social workers), one housing specialists and one Core Program Supervisor (Supervising Social Worker/Program Manager) and one Core Program Director. (continued on next page)

During the inspection, LPA's reviewed five participant records. LPA observed that two of five Participant files (P1, P4) did not contain results for tuberculosis test. Based on the record review, the THPP did not ensure the participant medical assessment are not current and up to date. The facility is being cited for non-minor dependent regulations, 86069(b)(1) participant medical assessments. Exit interview was conducted with Core Program Director Stephen Morals and Core Program Supervisor Andrea Castillo. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List ( LIC 811) dated November 22, 2021 and the appeal rights were handed to facility representative. LPA’ will conduct a tour of one remote site upon departure of the annual inspection.

facility_name: BAYFRONT YOUTH AND FAMILY SERVICES THP+FC
narrative:
On 12/21/2021 at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced annual/required inspection. LPA arrived at the facility office at 9:30am and met with Chief Operating Officer, Cynthia Sarmiento who provided the tour of the facility. The facility is currently licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care services to non-minor dependents. The facility office is in a two-story building located in a commercial space. The agency has CARF certification valid until August 16 2023. All THP + FC staff and client records will be maintained at this Administrative Office when there are clients. The facility has an emergency preparedness and disaster plan located in the first floor that is available for inspection. Currently there are no location for housing right now since the facility has no clients. Currently there are no THP + FC site staff and administration is actively looking for locations for future client placement. LPA Karnsrithong conducted an interview with Chief Operating Officer who is the current active employee for the facility. Administrative staff are mostly working remote and will only come in to the office once or twice a week due to COVID-19. During the inspection, LPA Karnsrithong had observed the following: First Floor: There are seven (7) office rooms located in the first floor. There are three (3) restrooms for administrative and staff to use. There is a receptionist desk upon entrance of the building. There is a work station for the accounting manager in the first floor as well. There is a large conference room that has seating and a large table for private meetings and interviews. The room is connecting to a kitchenette and the office of the CEO. There is an open reception area that's connected via sliding glass door to an outside atrium area. There is ample storage space, for files and supplies. (Page 1 of 2)

Parking is also available outside the building. The license is posted in the receptionist area and is visible to all upon entering the office. Mental Health and CARF certification are also posted in the receptionist area. There are three (3) operating fire extinguishers and a first aid kit located in the first floor. Facility sketch plan is located on areas where fire extinguishers are located, one in the receptionist area, and one in the conference room. Second Floor: A staircase will take you to the second floor office. Quality Assurance (QA), Information Technology (IT) Maintenance Department offices are located in the second floor. There is a kitchenette that has a stove, microwave, and toaster for staff to use. There are two (2) working fire extinguishers in the second floor. There are two (2) enclosed office rooms being used by the QA director and IT department. There are two (2) restrooms located in the second floor. QA department houses all the documentation and monitoring for the agency and the facility. There is an employee lounge located in the second floor that is in a patio setting. There is a sliding door that leads to the employee lounge. The employee lounge is not accessible for clients. Exit interview was conducted with the Chief Operating Officer. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility at a later date. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. (Page 2 of 2)

facility_name: BAYFRONT YOUTH AND FAMILY SERVICES THP+FC
narrative:
On 11/29/2023 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at Bayfront Youth and Family Services for the purpose of conducting an unannounced annual/required inspection of the administrative office. LPA met with Administrator/Chief Operating Officer, Cynthia Sarmiento. LPA was granted access and toured the facility. This program is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care services (THP+FC) for up to six (6) non-minor dependents. The census at the time of this inspection is zero (0). The administrative office is a two-story building located in a commercial area. The facility is set up as follows: First Floor: At the entrance of the building there is a receptionist desk and a waiting area. To the right of the entrance there is a hallway that consist of the Administrator's office, the human resource office, three (3) additional offices, two (2) workstations, and two (2) restrooms. To the left of the entrance there is a hallway that consist of the Chief Executive’s office, one (1) restroom, and a conference room. The conference room is equipped with a large table and seating for at least 10 people. The room is used for meetings, and private interviews with clients should then need to meet with staff. There is also a small kitchenette connected to the back of the conference room. There are three (3) regulation fire extinguishers on this floor and a complete first aid kit. Second Floor: Is accessible from an outside staircase. This floor consists of two (2) offices, two (2) restrooms, a small kitchen, and an employee patio lounge. This floor houses the maintenance department, the information technology team, and quality assurance. The kitchen is equipped with a stove, toaster oven, and microwave. There are two (2) regulation fire extinguishers on this floor. The administrator’s office contains a doubled keyed locked storage cabinets for client files. Staff files are kept locked in the human resource office. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 1 of 2)

LPA observed the license is posted in the receptionist area and is visible to all upon entering the office. The facility has an emergency preparedness and disaster plan located on the first floor that is available for inspection. The program will utilize the remote site housing model and ensure the following services will be applicable: 1.) Participants have their own bedroom; 2.) No more than two participants share a bathroom: 3.) No more than two participants share a refrigerator; 4.) On-site supervisor available 24/7 to support, assist and oversee the needs of the participants: 5.) Assigned Social Workers assist and meet with participants a minimum of once a week (face-to-face); and 6.) Supervision, if needed, for the distribution of prescription medication. Currently there are clients placed in the program and no housing locations. Currently the only staff are the Administrator and Chief Executive Officer. There are no deficiencies observed or cited at this site visit. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left with Administrator/Chief Operating Officer.

met_with: Lavina Desilva-Director of Programs and Kamela Stewart- Housing Division Director
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Beyond Emancipation Administrative office. LPA met with Kamela Stewart Housing Division Manager (HDM) and Lavina Desilva Director of Programs (DP). The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 11:10 AM, LPA did a walk through inspection with HDM and DP of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with HDM and DP about the residential units. HDM stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. HDM stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. HDM notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 12:30 PM, LPA reviewed 2 participants files and 4 staff files with HDM and DP. LPA observed 2 Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA observed 4 staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current.

During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report, LIC 610 C to maintain their file current. LPA receive an updated copy of COVID-19 safety plan, updated list of the Participant Residential Units and Leasing Agreements. LPA also spoke with DP and HDM about updating the Program Administrator documents. A review of Licensing Information System on August 10, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility. .

On 8/31/22 at 9:56 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) George Karkazis and Mariah Hawkins conducted an unannounced required 2-year inspection at the transitional housing placement program. LPA's met with Director Lavina De Silva and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE inspection tool was used to conduct this inspection. LPA's toured the facility and observed the office to be in good repair, clean, well organized, and to have confidential meeting spaces. LPA's toured two residential units and observed the following: The first unit was clean and in good repair. The second unit was unoccupied, and certain parts were not safe for occupation due to being under renovation and remodeling. LPA's reviewed three staff files and two residents files and interviewed one staff. Neither resident currently in care were interviewed due to one resident being on a home stay following the birth of their child and one resident being asleep during visit to residential unit. The following deficiency was found during today's inspection: - No emergency and disaster plan was available at the residential units and no documentation that the plan had been provided to participants/residents was in facility records accessible during today's visit. LPA's are issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86023. See attached LIC 809-D. The following advisories were issued (See LIC 9102s): - LPA's observed that the facility conducts safety drills one to two times per year. LPA's advised that drills be conducted on a quarterly basis. - LPA's observed that one staff member did not have mandated reporter training accessible during inspection. LPA's advise that all staff responsible for the facility or with authority to represent the facility ensure they have access to all required documentation.

- LPA's observed that only the administrator has access to current participant files, so LPA's were not able to review current participant records during visit. LPA's reviewed past participant records. LPA's advise that the facility ensure all staff responsible for the facility or with the authority to represent the facility have access to all required documentation. - LPA's observed that participant records did not contain needs and services plans but did have transitional independent living plans (TILPs). LPA's advise that needs and services plans be generated that are consistent with the participants' TILPs. - LPA's observed that needs and services were not updated annually due to not being generated. LPA's advise that the facility begin generating needs and services plans and updating plans at least annually. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Director Lavina De Silva, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Dina Gibson, Interim Human Resource Director
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis and Nicole del Calvo made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Beyond Emancipation. LPA's met with Jenny Fick, Interim Housing Director and Dina Gibson, Interim Human Resource Director. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 12:00PM, LPA's did a walk through inspection with Jenny Fick, Interim Housing Director of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in the administrative offices. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Jenny Fick about the residential units. Jenny Fick stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Jenny Fick stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Jenny Fick notified LPA's that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 11:00AM, LPA's reviewed 5 participants files and 5 staff files with DIna Gibson. LPA observed 5 Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA observed 5 staff files. S1 & S2 did not have background clearance, and S3 & S4 did not have health screen or TB record on file. At this the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulation 80018(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance, with civil penalty, 86066(a)(11) Health Screening, 86066(a)(12) Tuberculosis. LPA's Karkazis and Del Calvo provided education/training pertaining to Guardian and fingerprint clearance Exit interview conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of the report was given to Dina Gibson.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) AmyLe Tran conducted a case management tele-inspection to the TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PLACEMENT PROGRAM (THPP) agency on October 30, 2020, at 10:15 AM via tele-visit (due to COVID 19). LPA Tran met with Division Director Residential Services, Cheryl Rouse via Facetime. The purpose of the case management was in regard to an incident report submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on October 9, 2020, regarding Sexual Abuse. Refer to (811 Confidential Names list, October 30, 2020). On October 8, 2020, Client (C1) (DOB: 9/18/2003) reported to Youth Advocate that on October 1, 2020, he was drinking with his friends (15 teenagers and 5 adult males were present) and “blacked out”. C1 believes he was sexually assaulted due to him bleeding rectally for the past 4 days, having a stomachache, and headache as well. He reported having consumed approximately 15 “Four Lokos” (alcohol beverage) within the span of 1 hour and then “passed out.” He was taken to the hospital and gave consent to have a SART examination done, he also filed a police report. During the exam, youth changed his mind and did not consent to the internal examination or DNA collection. However, C1’s external exam was cleared, and no external injuries were found by nurse. Case manager contacted Division Director, DFCS social workers, and probation officer. Youth was also tested for STD’s, substances, and general lab testing. (Continue on LIC809-C)

(Continue from LIC809) The alleged sexual assault was not at the facility; therefore, staff were unable to prevent harm done to the minor. The agency developed an individual safety plan for C1 due to this incident. The agency has acted by providing additional support, increased supervision, and CFT meeting. There appears to be no negligence on behalf of the staff. Once staff knew the minor was no feeling well, wasn’t answering questions when being asked, they immediately called the case manager and 911 to take C1 to the hospital. Cheryl Rouse agreed to update LPA Tran with any ongoing developments regarding this matter. No citation was given for this visit. A copy of this report was emailed to Cheryl Rouse for review and signature. (end of interview)

The finding for the allegation, “facility staff did not provide a clean environment for youth” is Substantiated. The evidence for the allegation: “facility staff did not provide a clean environment for youth” as follows; On May 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed S1. S1 told this LPA, the protocol for something like a maintenance issue is for the Case Manager to tell the THPP Program Manager (S2) who then would notify S1. S1 would approve or disapprove of the work being done. If approved, there will be a work order and she (S1) would follow-up with the resident to make sure it was taken care of. On June 1, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed S2. Per S2, no concerns were brought to her attention by residents of the home not being clean. On May 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C1. Per C1, the garage was full of things and was dirty. C1 said that the house chores were done by her and the other residents and that the house needs to be professionally cleaned, due to stains that could not be cleaned by the residents. Furthermore, C1 told this LPA that there is an odor, which was described as “mold”. Per C1, the concern of cleanness was the bathroom (downstairs and upstairs), kitchen, and garage. On August 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C2. Per C2, the upstairs bathroom, "it smells bad, like a sewer" (when water is turned on from the faucet). Per C2, the maintenance people came and said it had something to do with the plumbing. Furthermore, C2 told this LPA that others have complained about the smell and that the THPP agency representatives did not do anything about taking care of the smell.

On November 5, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C3. Per C3, the kitchen sink had a stinky smell, and, in the garage, it smelled and had insects and spiders. C3 described the smell in the kitchen sink as "old food". C3 told this LPA that the downstairs bathroom sink "smelled really bad. All kind of stuff in the garage", the garage was cluttered. C3 stated to this LPA, “I had seen a cockroach behind the refrigerator in the kitchen”. On May 21, 2020, LPA Sam Raissi received photos with the initial complaint. A total of eight (8) photos. The photos are of the kitchen, bathroom, and garage. The photos indicate that the THPP home was not a clean environment for the participants. The photos show that there were dirt and debris in the kitchen and bathroom drawers, and the garage was cluttered with items. The agency listed above this report has since removed the items in the garage while this investigation was being conducted. Based on interviews with three participants, observations by this LPA, and photos of the kitchen, bathroom, and garage, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation of “facility staff did not provide a clean environment for youth”, is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The agency listed above this report was issued an Advisory Note –Technical Assistance attached on document (LIC 9102TA). Title 22 Division 6 regulations were not cited during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was sent to Cheryl Rouse. Second allegation attached on document (LIC 9099-A)

The finding for the allegation, “placement home has mold” is Unsubstantiated. The evidence for the allegation: “placement home has mold” as follows; On May 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed S1. S1 told this LPA that there hasn't been anything brought to her attention about the THPP house having mold. On May 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C1. Per C1, the showers had mold, near the drain, and other areas in the shower. On August 28, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C2. Per C2, the upstairs bathroom, "it smells bad, like a sewer" (when water is turned on from the faucet). (when water is turned on from the faucet). C2 told this LPA that there was not mold in the home. On November 5, 2020, LPA Raissi interviewed C3. C3 stated, that the downstairs bathroom sink “smelled really bad. I never smelled mold before, so I don’t know what mold smells like, but it stank really bad”. Interviews with staff members (S1 interviewed on, May 28, 2020) and (S2 interviewed on, June 1, 2020) show that both S1 and S2 were unaware of mold at the THPP home. Observations of the THPP home (on May 28, 2020) conducted by this LPA, could not determine if there was mold in the bathrooms. The photos obtained by the confidential witness does not indicate that there is mold. Therefore, this LPA could not determine if there was mold in the THPP home, therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Title 22 Division 6 regulations were not cited during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was sent to Cheryl Rouse.

narrative: The evidence for the allegation(s) “House monitor was observed kissing a youth”, “House monitor was observed allowing the youth into his room and closing the door” and “House monitor is showing favoritism towards one of the youths”, as follows: Three (3) out of five (5) clients (C1, C2, and C5) were in favor of house monitor (S2), stating he had not made them feel uncomfortable, and he has only entered their room after being given permission to complete his house monitor duties. Those in favor of S2 felt the complaint originates from C3 and former client C6, is a result of having a feud with C2 and their poor relationship with S2. The two (2) clients that felt uncomfortable with S2 (C3 and C4) stated they have seen client(s) C1 and C2 in S2's room together usually on the internet at night. C3 stated she never witnessed C2 inside S2's room at 0500 hours, but she assumes so because C2 was not in her room and thinks C2's excuse of vaping outside is a lie. C3 and C4 felt C2 was flirty and touchy with S2, and that he stared at their buttocks when they walked upstairs. It was noted that C3 and C4 have a poor relationship with staff and clients. C2 denied being in S2's room, stating she is asleep by 0300 or 0400 hours. S2 stated he also slept before 0200 hours because he gets ready for work at 0800 hours. S2 stated he only enters a client's room to check for unauthorized visitors, pick up cleaning supplies forgotten by clients, and to conduct COVID-19 temperature checks. S2 and C2 both stated after the first investigation from CCL (staff sexually abusing the client has already been investigated in case number: CA2620-02028 by Investigator Austin), they do not speak to each other because they do not want more rumors being created from the other clients. Based on IB investigator Phung’s interviews and observations made by LPA Raissi, two (2) out of five (5) clients (C3 and C4) felt uncomfortable with S2. Three (3) out of five (5) clients (C1, C2, and C5) were in favor of S2 and denied the allegation(s). Based on three (3) out of five (5) witnesses interviewed the complaint findings could not be proved. Therefore, the complaint findings are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of the report was left at the agency with Cheryl Rouse.

On August 18, 2021, at 12:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi conducted an unannounced inspection to the Bill Wilson Center - Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) agency for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Raissi met with Division Director, Cheryl Rouse and Program Manager, Risa Palega. The THPP is licensed to serve seventy-five clients, minor and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are 35 clients. This LPA toured the agency, reviewed the staff and client files, and certificates of compliance for the THPP sites. The agency had the necessary documents. A review of Licensing Information System on August 18, 2021 indicates that all agency staff are associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. According to the Cheryl Rouse, there are no weapons, and/or bodies of water at the agency which meets title 22 regulations. There are currently no exceptions on file, and there have not been any deficiencies cited in the past year. There were no deficiencies noted at today's inspection. The agency was issued an Advisory Note –Technical Assistance (LIC 9102TA). Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was sent to Cheryl Rouse.

Evidence for the allegation “Minor is not being adequately supervised”, as follows: Five (5) out of seven (7) individuals interviewed (C1, S1, S2, S3, and IPM) told this LPA that C1 is following the program rules and that C1 has received adequate supervision. Staffing schedules from (3/07/2021 – 4/03/2021) show that there has been adequate supervision at the THPP residence. Staffing schedules were obtained from Bill Wilson Center representatives on (3/26/2021). Two (2) out of seven (7) individuals interviewed (SPO and PO) told this LPA that C1 is not receiving adequate supervision. The individuals interviewed have concerns about the lack of an employee residing onsite at the THPP Bill Wilson Center and that the THPP representatives told (PO and SPO) that the program is an independent living program and there are not twenty-four hours, seven days a week (24/7) staff coverage. Based on this LPA’s review of records and interviews the THPP representatives have increased supervision for C1 based on the needs of the client, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Evidence for the allegation “Minor did not receive services”, as follows: Five (5) out of seven (7) individuals interviewed (C1, S1, S2, S3, and IPM) told this LPA that C1 is following the program and that C1 is receiving services. Based on interviews and observations by this LPA there was a disconnect between what services should be referred by the Probation Department representatives and what services the THPP should be providing. Based on the THPP program the services are being provided; C1 is interning at the (Young Women’s Freedom). Per IPM, C1 is very engaged in the internship. C1 is involved with life coaching and does peer advisory for other youth in the program. C1 comes in daily, weekdays, Monday through Thursday. Per IPM, C1 has been an intern since March (2021) but involved with the center since (2019). C1 is reliable and comes in on time. C1 rarely misses coming in. Since March C1 has only been absent two (2) or three (3) times. In addition, C1 attends a support group (New Hope for Youth), which helps her with services, such as, finding career opportunities and counseling. Bill Wilson Center representatives conduct weekly house meetings to address any needs or services for the youth in placement and to fulfill Assembly Bill (AB) 12 requirements.

Evidence for the allegation “Minor is not attending school”, as follows: Five (5) out of seven (7) individuals interviewed (C1, S1, S2, S3, and IPM) told this LPA that C1 is following the program and that C1 has been attending school. Based on interviews C1 had difficulty at the beginning of the program because of online learning due to COVID-19 restrictions. Based on interviews, C1 is on track to graduate and is attending classes as she is eager to graduate. C1’s biological father has the education rights. Therefore, Bill Wilson Center representatives do not have direct access to school records. LPA Raissi attempted to contact C1’s biological father for further details. C1’s biological father did not return LPA Raissi call. Based on absence records obtained by PO from (2/22/2021 - 4/1/2021) there were absences, but C1 was attending classes and this was in the time-frame when C1 was having difficulty adjusting to the online classes. LPA Raissi could not retrieve further records due to C1’s biological father having the educational rights for C1. Five (5) out of seven (7) persons interviewed (C1, S1, S2, S3, and IPM) were in favor of C1’s progress in the THPP program and denied the allegation(s). Based on two (2) out of seven (7) persons interviewed (PO and SPO) were in favor of the allegation(s) and do not think that the Bill Wilson Center THPP program is an adequate placement for C1. During this investigation, it was revealed that the Juvenile Court Judge asked to pursue C1’s placement at the Bill Wilson Center THPP program. Based on interviews, records obtained, and observations by this LPA there is not enough evidence to prove the allegation(s). Therefore, the complaint findings are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation(s) are Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of the report was left at the agency with Cheryl Rouse.

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights: a)	The licensee shall ensure that each nonminor dependent is accorded the personal rights  t(1)	A nonminor dependent shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment; infliction of pain; humiliation; intimidation; ridicule; coercion; threat; physical, sexual, mental, or other abuse; infliction of pain; humiliation; intimidation; ridicule; coercion; threat; physical, sexual, mental, or other abuse... deficiencies.plan_of_correction: In December 2021, the staff was terminated from the facility. Other staff were also retrained in these areas.

narrative: It was also noted an investigating Social Worker displayed a huge concern for S1 regarding her behavior in the allegations. Based on confidential interviews, and documents reviewed, there is a preponderance of evidence that two clients in care with similar allegations had sustained injuries while in care by Staff 1 (S1). The two clients were both yelled at, and spoken to with inappropriate language by S1 on separate instances. Moreover, S1 pushed one client, and chioked another client. There are photographs that were provided by one of the reporting parties that clearly reveals injuries on one of the client's neck by S1 in approximately four places. The investigating Social Worker who conducted the investgation believed the client who had sustained neck injuries.

deficiencies.description: 86172(b)(2);To be free from corporal or unusual punishment: infliction of pain: humiliation: intimidation: ridicule: coercion: threat: physical, sexual, emotional mental, or other abuse: or other actions of a punitive nature..This requirement was not met, as evidenced by; Based on a file review, and documentation,  confidential interviews, evidence revealed that a staff member had an altercation, and choked a client. This poses an immediate Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to provide a personal rights training to all staff about clients living in a safe and healthy environment, including speaking professionally, and avoiding all physical confrontation with all clients in care. Training should also include staff not locking clients out of the facility as any form of punishment. The date the training will be completed by is due on 3/31/2023. The training information, proof of staff attendance, and copy of the policy for personal rights to be submitted by the POC due date 4/20/2023. It is also noted S1 was terminated on 3/17/23.

At the time of the visit, there were two youth and three staff in the facility. Over the course of the investigation, confidential interviews, a file review, and evidence obtained regarding the aforementioned allegations. Based on confidential interviews, and documents reviewed, there is a preponderance of evidence that two clients in care with similar allegations had sustained injuries while in care by Staff 1 (S1). The two clients were both yelled at, and spoken to with inappropriate language by S1 on separate instances. Moreover, S1 pushed one client, and chioked another client. There are photographs that were provided by one of the reporting parties that clearly reveals injuries on one of the client's neck by S1 in approximately four places. The investigating Social Worker who conducted the investigation believed the client who had sustained neck injuries.

deficiencies.description: 86172(b)(2);To be free from corporal or unusual punishment: infliction of pain: humiliation: intimidation: ridicule: coercion: threat: physical, sexual, emotional mental, or other abuse: or other actions of a punitive nature..This requirement was not met, as evidenced by; Based on a file review and confidential interviews, evidence revelaed that a staff member hit, and spoke in an inapporporiate manner towards the client. This poses a potential Health, Safety and Personal Rights risk to client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to provide a personal rights training to all staff about clients living in a safe and healthy environment, including speaking professionally, and avoiding all physical confrontation with all clients in care. Training should also include staff not locking clients out of the facility as any form of punishment. The date the training will be completed by is due on 3/31/2023. The training information, proof of staff attendance, and copy of the policy for personal rights to be submitted by the POC due date 4/20/2023.  It is also noted S1 was terminated on 3/17/23.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/29/2024 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Vaishali SIngh-Sood and Jasmine Cardeno conducted an unannounced visit to the facility. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings on the listed allegation. LPAs met with Debbie Pell, Program Administrator. At the time of the visit, there were two youth and three staff. Over the course of the investigation, confidential interviews, a file review, and evidence obtained regarding the aforementioned allegation was conducted. However, due to a lack of evidence, and the reporting party failed to return all calls to this LPA, this LPA was unable to substantiate the allegation. The allegation may have happened, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that it occurred. Therefore, this investigation is being closed as unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted at 10:30 AM with Ms. Pell, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator, Ms. Pell.

narrative: On October 30, 2024, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted an unannounced inspection to the Bill Wilson Center - Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) agency for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Singh-Sood met with Program Manager, Angeleena Yeldell. The THPP is licensed to serve 12 clients, minor and non-minor dependents. Currently in placement are 9 clients. This LPA toured the agency, reviewed the staff and client files, and certificates of compliance for the THPP sites. The agency had the necessary documents. On October 30, 2024, a review of Guardian indicated that all agency staff who are associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. According to Ms. Yeldell, there are no weapons, and/or bodies of water at the agency which currently meets Title 22 regulations. There are currently no exceptions on file, and there have not been any deficiencies cited in the past year. There were no deficiencies noted at today's inspection. At 3:30 PM, an exit interview conducted with Ms. Yeldell, and a copy of this report was provided at that time.

It was alleged that facility staff consumed alcohol with facility clients. The investigation revealed that the allegation was not observed firsthand but obtained through hearsay. Facility staff interviewed denied consuming alcohol with clients and denied witnessing other staff consume alcohol with clients. Confidential statements obtained from current and former facility clients also could not corroborate the allegation as the clients denied consuming alcohol with staff and denied witnessing staff consume alcohol with clients. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On February 26, 2021 at 12:40 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joshua Rarela conducted a follow-up complaint tele-inspection to deliver the findings of a complaint investigation concerning the allegation above. During the course of the investigation, Investigator Hector interviewed the law enforcement detective on 12/8/20, the complainant on 1/15/21, two facility staff on 1/15/21, current and former facility clients on 1/19/21 and 1/20/21 (see Confidential Names Form dated February 26, 2021). Investigator Hector also reviewed documents on 12/4/20, 12/7/20 including but not limited to the police report, placement agency service logs, facility client records, and incident reports. (Continued)

narrative: On November 8, 2021 at around 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted a case management inspection at the Transitional Housing Program (THP) facility and met Lori Kezos, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up a Special Incident Report (SIR) the Department received regarding an eighteen (18) year old client (C1) who died at the hospital few days after a car accident. At around 10:00am, LPA reviewed the client file and finished the review at 10:30am. LPA conducted an interview of the THP Supervisor and the Administrator at around 10:45am. LPA gathered the information that the THP staff conducts apartment checks on the clients every Tuesday and as needed depending how well the clients are doing in their program. The clinician of the program also sees the clients every week depending on their availability, since the clients work. The last time C1 was seen at the THP was last October 25, 2021 regarding his career goals. Proof of contacts with C1 was provided to this LPA. Further, on October 30, 2021,the facility staff received a call from C1's relative that he was in a car accident. At the time, they don't have the details. The car accident incident was not reported to the Department for that reason. On November 4, 2021, they received another call from C1's relative that he passed away the night of November 3, 2021.. New information received from the relative was that C1 was not driving the car at the time of the accident. He was with his girlfriend and her stepfather was the driver. Based on the information gathered, at this time no further follow-up is necessary regarding the incident. A citation is issued to the facility for failure to make a report to the Department an unusual incident under Title 22 Regulations. Per the SIR,staff was informed not only about the car accident but also that C1 was transported to the hospital after the accident. Section 80061: Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department, including, but not limited to, those specified in this section.. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report.

On December 15, 2021 at around 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted a case management inspection at the Transitional Housing Program (THP) facility and met Lanier Riley, THP Supervisor. The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up a Special Incident Report (SIR) the Department received regarding a nineteen (19) year old client (C1) who was hospitalized due to drug overdose. C1 was discharged from the hospital the same day. At around 1:20pm, LPA reviewed C1's file and finished the review at 1:35pm. LPA conducted an interview of the THP Supervisor while reviewing the file.. LPA gathered the information that the Probation Officer (PO) is looking for a facility for C1 that can provide a 24 hour supervision like a Drug Treatment Program. During his stay at the THP, he will be provided additional physical and mental health services. Prior to the incident, the THP staff conducts apartment checks on the clients every Tuesday and as needed depending how well the clients are doing in their program. The clinician of the program also sees the clients every week depending on their availability, since the clients work. After the incident, the staff increased the visitation and also conducts random checks and in addition calls them in the unit. Based on the information gathered, at this time no further follow-up is necessary regarding the incident. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vaishali Singh-Sood made an announced post-licensing inspection at the Foster Family Agency (FFA), on above date at 9:30 AM. LPA met with Executive Assistant, Vissana Khounvichith, who assisted with the inspection. B.W.I.T Foster Family Agency office will house personnel occasionally for the FFA including the Administrator and social work staff. Currently the Agency has two social workers and one Social work Supervisor. LPA observed sufficient office space and a location where files are kept double locked and secured. LPA also observed sufficient space for social work staff to have work space as well as locked cabinet areas. Observed was a current fire extinguisher. At this time, Agency does not have facility sketch posted and will post by the end of business today 9/13/2023. Bathrooms are located outside agency office and are locked. Agency staff have keys to access restrooms as needed. During a review of the mass casualty and disaster plan, information was missing regarding points of contact. Agency agrees to complete the updates by the end of business 9/14/2023, and will submit to the department by that day. The agency currently has one family who is approved, and one that is in process of having their approval completed. A review of the guardian system shows all staff are cleared to work in the Agency. Office organization is as follows: Second story small office with one main area with entrance and waiting. Coffee station, office / mail, reception are (all of which are shared). Office space for all staff and social work staff with locked cabinet space. Training is conducted on Zoom, or in the office. Based on this pre-licensing inspection, the FFA is in compliance according to Title 22 Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS version 6). After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. An exit interview was conducted at 12:30 PM, and a copy of this report was given emailed to Ms. Stance.

On 4/5/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Diego conducted a case management visit to address deficiencies found during an investigation at the facility. LPA and LPM met with Director Audra Stance and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, the following deficiencies were found. Staff spoke about residents’ personal matters, including a resident’s private health matter, with other resident(s) and therefore did not ensure confidentiality. LPA is issuing a citation of Transitional Housing Placement Program Nonminor Dependent (AB12) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 86272 Personal Rights, Subsection (a)(12). Staff arrived to a residential unit in the middle of the night and banged on a resident’s bedroom door to wake them up due to them not responding to the staff member earlier in the day. Additionally, a staff member told a resident that they were blocking the resident from contacting their phone number. LPA is issuing a citation of ILS Section 86272 Personal Rights, Subsection (a)(11). The facility became aware of residents engaging in dangerous behaviors such as illegal sex work and threats of violence toward another resident. Further, written correspondence reflects social worker(s) may not have been notified of ongoing behavior incidents and issues leading up to a termination from the program in a timely manner. LPA is issuing a citation of ILS Section 86261 Reporting Requirements, Subsection (c). SEE PAGE 2

PAGE 2 Additionally, the facility did not follow the approved plan of operation (POO) dated 04/12/2023. The facility fined two residents for property damage caused by a physical altercation that resulted in damage to an interior door and a mirror. The residents were required to split the cost of the repair. The POO indicates a damage deposit of $500 is to be set aside for each resident, from which the cost of damages will be deducted, and an itemized damage report is to be completed. This was not followed. Additionally, the facility sent a notice to residents via text of various policy changes, including putting leases and bills in the residents’ names and changing program incentives, and did not report the changes to the Department until instructed by the Department to do so. LPA is issuing a citation of ILS Section 86261 Reporting Requirements, Subsection (d). Lastly, during today's visit, LPA observed that certificate of compliances were only available for one of four residential sites in use, and two remote residential sites were approved for use without notification made to the Licensing agency. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Chapter 7, Section 86030.5 Identification of Transitional Housing Placement Program Participant Living Units, Subsection (a) and Section 86031.5 Notification, Subsection (b). Furthermore, LPA and LPM provided technical assistance with applicable requirements, including reportable incidents, law enforcement contacts, certificate of compliances. See attached LIC 809-D pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Director Audra Stance.

narrative: On 4/15/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a random annual inspection and met with Director Audra Stance. LPA informed of the purpose of the visit. Client records were observed to be complete, except for safeguarded cash records, which do not clearly document the amonut of money provided and saved. Records of electronic payments were supplied. Additionally, LPA advised of telephone requirements in housing units and the requirement to include facility license number in advertisements. investigation_findings: 13On 4/5/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Diego conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver findings for the above allegation. LPA and LPM met with Director Audra Stance and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, a resident was issued a 7-day discharge notice on 2/24/24 with an exit date set at 3/2/24 was not paid their weekly stipend the week of 2/29/24. Additionally, only a $20 payment was made the week of 2/5/24. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Director Audra Stance.

investigation_findings: 13On 10/25/24 at 9:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted a complaint investigation visit to the facility to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Licensee Audra Stance and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, text documentation, and facility’s plan of operation at the time, the facility was withholding allowance. Confidential interviews indicated multiple clients in care were affected simultaneously by the withholding of the allowance. In addition, text documentation and interviews indicated licensee reducing allowance and changing weekly stipends to monthly stipends. This is due to licensee not receiving funds from Eligibility due to social workers not submitting SOC 152 on youths. At the time, licensee had not received an approved plan of operation in the recent changes of allowance to clients in care. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the allegation is substantiated. LPA determined that this had impact the overall operation of the facility.

narrative: On 11/19/2024 at 4:00PM, an informal virtual meeting was conducted with Audra Stance regarding increase of capacity to 50 and compliance history since facility was licensed on May 17, 2024. The following were present at the meeting: Helga Wong - Regional Manager Isabel Diego- Licensing Program Manager Carolyn Flynn- Licensing Program Manager Audra Stance- BIWT Administrator During the meeting, Community Care Licensing (CCL) discussed with BWIT Administrator the review of the increase of capacity request to 50 capacity that will be on hold; facility compliance history of deficiencies on withholding allowance, cash resources records, personal rights, reporting requirements, living unit certification and discharge of client; legal review; age exceptions. BWIT Administrator explained the reason on increase capacity due to additional referrals from the County and discussion of the youths in care. CCL provided information on THPP regulation for minor in care and Trauma Informal, Plan of Operation, and offered Technical Assistance Meeting to assist the THPP program.

The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be

13*** Amended correct deficiency and corrected findings.*** On 11/21/24 at 3:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint inspection at BWIT and spoke with Audra Stance, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. Based on LPA’s interview with staff, clients, and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations, facility operated outside of plan of operation and staff are not treating clients in care with dignity and respect are SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1: 80022(k) Plan of Operation and (ILS), AB 12 Nonminor dependents, THPP, Article 06: 86272(a) Personal Rights. Please refer to attached 9909D. At this time, two deficiencies were given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Audra Stance, Administrator.

deficiencies.description: 86272 Personal Rights (a) The licensee shall ensure...personal rights. WIC (1) To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review and interview licensee did not ensure residents are being treated with respect, which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
