narrative:
On 06/04/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced annual inspection and met with Wesley Sheppard, Lead Case Manager. Director Audra Stance is currently out of town and authorized Wesley Sheppard to facilitate the inspection via phone. LPA Medina confirmed that the Designation of Facility Responsibility form was completed prior to Director Stance’s departure. Upon arrival, no staff were present in the office. Staff arrived at approximately 11:10 AM. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP+FC) program serves non-minor dependents. During the inspection, LPA received an updated copy of the LIC500 Personnel Report to ensure the facility’s records remain current. An updated list of participant residential units was also obtained. A review of the Guardian background check system on June 4, 2025, confirmed that all staff associated with the program had cleared Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI) background checks. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA conducted a walkthrough of the office at 11:45 AM. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, and the agency’s license was observed to be prominently posted. LPA also observed a designated room for client relaxation. No deficiencies were noted during this portion of the inspection. Continues on LIC809-C

At approximately 12:00 PM, LPA reviewed five client files. The facility representative was unable to provide Needs and Services Plans or equivalent documentation for four out of the five client files reviewed. Admission agreements, consent forms, emergency contacts, personal property/valuables lists, and signed personal rights acknowledgements were present. An area for improvement observed by LPA Medina was the organization of clients’ cash resource records. Currently, all records are combined into one folder, rather than being individualized per client for Licensing review. One deficiency and one technical advisory were identified in this section. Please refer to LIC809-D and LIC9102 for further details. At 2:00 PM, LPA reviewed five staff files. No deficiencies were identified using the CARE Inspection Tool. LPA Medina observed current first aid certifications, fingerprint clearances, educational verification, personnel records, health screenings, criminal record statements, employee rights documentation, and completed TB tests. An area for improvement was noted regarding the LIC501 Personnel Records: not all forms included the employee’s date of hire. Please refer to LIC9102 for details. At 3:05 PM, LPA reviewed the Operations section of the CARE Inspection Tool. LPA verified that all residential units had valid Certificates of Compliance. The facility representative also provided an updated client roster. No deficiencies were observed in this section. At 3:30 PM, LPA reviewed the facility’s disaster preparedness plan. The review included the LIC610C, and LPA confirmed that all staff have assigned roles in the event of an emergency. However, the facility was unable to provide documentation of emergency drills upon request. One deficiency was observed in this section. Please refer to LIC809-D. This annual inspection is now complete. As a result of the inspection, one Health and Safety Code violation was cited under section 1565(c), and one violation was cited under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 86270(a)(2)(C). Two areas of improvement were identified. Please refer to LIC 9102 for further details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Lead Case Manager Wesley Sheppard, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Summary: An online, informal meeting was held on August 1st, 2025 at 9am on Microsoft Teams. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss concerns observed by the department and a proposed capacity increase. Attendance: Community Cares Licensing Representatives Regional Manager: Helga Wong Licensing Program Managers (LPM): Joel Segura Licensing Program Analyst (LPA): Jonathan Medina, Will Ea Facility Representatives Administrator: Audra Stance Compliance Manager: “Ms. J” Jammesie Jones Program Facilitator: Vissana Khouvicith Lead Case Manager: Wesley Shepperd Agenda: The following are topics that were discussed based on concerns the department observed during past inspections and relating to proposed changes: (Page 1 of 4)

(Page 2 of 4) Agenda 1: Past Citations/Issues Personal Rights: Facility was cited for multiple violations of personal rights stemming from violations of (1) maintaining the privacy of clients’ medical information, (2) treating clients in a respectful manner/inappropriate comments to clients in care, (3) using availability of shelter as a punitive measure (4) not according residents with the right to file complaints free of punishment Cash Resources Management: Facility was cited for not ensuring that cash resources were properly returned to client upon their discharge from the facility Record Keeping: On April 5th, 2024, the facility was cited for a number of issues related to proper record keeping, including (1) maintaining an up-to-date list of current residents (2) providing notice to CCLD concerning census changes (3) reporting to CCLD within 7 days of any incident in which a residents’ safety is at risk (4) reporting to CCLD within 10 days on any changes to the facility plan of operation. During a recent annual inspection, a citation was given for not (5) maintaining a Needs and Service plan for all clients within the facility’s care. Agenda 2: Capacity Increase Facility shared presentation on positive changes and services BWIT now offers Capacity Increase Goal: What is the target number of the proposed capacity increase and what is the goal of the increase? Facility Response: Increase capacity from 30 to 50. Capacity Increase Plan: What are some of the preparations needed to accommodate the increased capacity? (staffing considerations) Facility Response: Established relationship w/ non-profit to source furniture, both used and new Developed trauma informed care training. (continued on next page)

(Page 3 of 4) Facility Response (continued): Establish High Standard of Care Fully furnished housing Always provide brand new beds Single housing unit for each client Two bedroom units with clients that have children Pet friendly. Parenting youth receive additional stipend. Social Events to create memories and build community (BWIT Prom) Mentorship programs. How to apply for college. driven by individual goals of clients Currently have 5 case managers Agenda 3: Available Support Resources Technical Support Program: Shared information about TSP, a non-enforcement, voluntary service offered to support Providers to meet regulatory compliance. TSP offers 1:1 support in the form of consultation, trainings, and resources for a variety of Community Care Licensing (CCL) topics to all facility types. Agenda 4: Acknowledgement of Progress Initially struggled due to lack of experience. Since first informal meeting 10 months ago, took advice to heart and built a team to support one another Has 90% success rate with a challenging client population Every client that has come through the program has obtained their high school diploma Weekly Checkins w/ Clients Mental health Physical health Property check/maintenance Check progress on short-term and long-term goals Case Manager is required to document visitation notes (continued on next page)

(page 4 of 4) Agenda 4: Acknowledgement of Progress (continued) Weekly Check In (continued) CCLD: Encourage transparency and communication with your LPAs/LPMs CCLD: Encouraged to celebrate successes/accomplishments with clients Hold events to socialize and create memories/community for clients (BWIT Prom) Establishment of mentorship program help learn life skills learn how to set and accomplish whatever goals they have Created “BWIT Moving w/ Purpose” moving service, to transition into or out of the program Fully insured moving service Assistance w/ packing and supplies Short/long distance Van used to shuttle residents to any events/appointments clients have outside of moves Agenda 5: Closing/Follow Ups During this meeting a plan for compliance was discussed, TSP services were discussed and offered to the program, specifically for help with maintaining needs and services plans and training on personal rights. The facility expressed their interest in consulting with TSP. The meeting was concluded. Follow Up Items Facility: Update Program Statement/Plan of Operation w/ all of the program additions shared w/ CCLD today. Provide to LPA Will Ea Facility: Provide updated LIC 500 with new staff hirings to LPA Will Ea Facility: Provide updated LIC 401 Monthly Operating Statement reflecting increased costs/balances as a result of capacity increase to LPA Will Ea CCLD: LPA Will Ea will pass along information regarding how to engage w/ TSP team

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia made an announced prelicensing inspection, on above date. LPA met with applicant, Rupinder Dhillon and Mandave Sandhu, and toured the office suite. On July 8, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced Post Licensing Inspection and met with Mandave Sandhu, Lead Case Manager. Due to a prior unsuccessful attempt to finalize a visit, this inspection is labeled as an "Annual" in FAS; however, it is officially the facility’s Post Licensing inspection. As the facility failed to accommodate two previous inspection attempts, a deficiency is being cited under Title 22, Section 80044(c) – Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. Please refer to LIC 809-D for further information. Staff began arriving at the facility at approximately 11:30 AM. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP+FC) program serves non-minor dependents. During the inspection, LPA obtained an updated LIC 500 (Personnel Report) to ensure the facility’s records are current. An updated list of participant residential units was also collected. A review of the Guardian background check system on July 8, 2025, confirmed that all staff associated with the program had cleared Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI) background checks. However, one staff member—John “Nick” Moriana, the facility’s Administrator—was not associated with the facility in Guardian. LPA reminded the facility that all staff working for CA Impact Coalition must be associated with the facility in Guardian. The Administrator was successfully associated by the end of the visit. At 11:45 AM, LPA conducted a walkthrough of the administrative office using the CARE Inspection Tool. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, and the agency’s license was prominently posted. LPA also observed a designated room intended for client relaxation. Client and staff files were stored in a secure room with locked cabinets. No deficiencies were observed during this portion of the inspection.

At approximately 12:00 PM, LPA reviewed five client files. The facility was able to provide Needs and Services Plans for all five clients selected at random. However, the plans were missing signatures from the authorized placing agency representative. The facility sent the plans to the assigned social workers during the inspection, and the signatures were obtained before the conclusion of the visit. A technical violation was issued. Please refer to LIC 9102 for additional details. Admission agreements, consent forms, emergency contact information, personal property/valuables lists, and signed personal rights acknowledgments were present in all reviewed files. At 1:30 PM, LPA reviewed two of the three staff files listed on the facility’s LIC 500. The three identified staff included the Licensee, Administrator, and one Case Manager. However, there was no personnel file available for the Licensee. A deficiency was cited under Title 22, Section 80066(a) – Personnel Records. While the facility attempted to gather the necessary documentation during the visit, the Licensee’s file was not available upon request. Other staff files contained the required documentation, including current First Aid/CPR certifications, fingerprint clearances, educational verification, TB test results, criminal record statements, health screenings, personnel records, and employee rights forms. Please refer to LIC 809-D for further information. At 2:00 PM, LPA reviewed the Operations section of the CARE Tool. All residential units had valid Certificates of Compliance, and an updated client roster was provided. No deficiencies were observed in this area. At 2:30 PM, LPA reviewed the facility’s disaster preparedness documentation, including the LIC 610C. LPA verified that all staff had assigned roles in the event of an emergency. However, the facility was unable to provide documentation confirming that emergency drills had been conducted. A technical assistance was given in this area to start keeping this record in binder. Please refer to LIC9102 for details. This Post Licensing Inspection is now complete. As a result, the facility was cited for two violations: one under Section 80066(a) – Personnel Records, and one under Section 80044(c) – Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. In addition, two technical violations/assistances were noted: one for missing authorized representative signatures on Needs and Services Plans, and one for the lack of documentation for emergency drills. Please refer to LIC 9102 for more details. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Lead Case Manager Mandave Sandhu, whose signature confirms receipt.

On 09/01/2021, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced visit for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with the Housing Manager and together toured the administrative office and the two on-site homes. The administrative office is located at 1728B - Resource Center. The office is set up as follows: Sitting area with 2 computers, a conference table/interview area and a restroom. To the left there is the Transitional Facilitator office, equipped with 3 computers, where the two (2) clinicians, and one (1) Transitional Facilitator / Case Manager work. Through the Transitional Facilitators office, there is a kitchenette that leads to the office of the Housing Supervisor. Housing clients records and the Outpatients Program records are maintained in the housing supervisor's office. The Facility Administrator and Clinical Program Manager's Office is located in the main Casa Pacifica Campus Administrative Office. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) to 30 participants ages eighteen (18) to twenty one (21). There are currently ten (10) participants in placement including two remote sites, located in Ventura and Oxnard. The Ventura remote-site may house up to four (4) participants, and the Oxnard remote-site may house up to 3 participants. There are currently 2 participants in the Oxnard location, and there are 3 participants in the Ventura location. The Administrative office is located on the Casa Pacifica premises. The two (2) THP+FC single-site models are also located on the Casa Pacifica premises; one is located at 1728A Lewis Road, Camarillo, CA, 93012 which is a house that has 3 dual occupancy bedrooms and 2 bathrooms; the other one is located on 1728C Lewis Road, Camarillo, CA. 93012, which has 2 single occupancy rooms, and one bathroom. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2)

During the inspection of the single-site models located on the premises of Casa Pacifica, LPA observed the following: 1728A: "Vicki's Place" has 3 double occupancy bedrooms, 1 single occupancy bedroom, 2 bathrooms, living room, dining area and kitchen. There are currently 4 participants, along with one infant, residing at this site. LPA observed this site to be clean, safe, and in good repair. LPA observed the fire extinguisher to be fully charged, and the smoke alarm / carbon monoxide detector to be functional. The first aid kit was fully stocked, and the outdoor area was free and clear of any obstructions. 1728C: "Baker's Place" has 2 single occupancy bedrooms, 1 bathroom, living room, dining area and a kitchen. There are currently 1 participant, along with an infant and a toddler, residing at this site. LPA observed this site to be clean, safe, and in good repair, except that the site should be baby-proofed to prevent the baby from accessing cabinets, drawers, and electrical sockets. Due to time constraints, LPA Sauk shall return on another date to complete file reviews and interviews. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On March 9, 2023, at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olivia Rosas and Christine Wilson conducted an unannounced inspection to Casa Pacifica Stepping Stones: THP + FC (Transitional Housing Placement Program) for the purpose of conducting Case Management- Incident inspection to gather additional information regarding the Unusual Incident/Injury Report (SIR) dated 03/03/2023. LPAs Rosas and Wilson, met with Staff#1 (S1) to discuss discussed the details SIR dated 03/03/2923. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated March 9, 2023, at 9:30am. The Department received SIR dated 03/03/2023, where it was disclosed that S1 discovered two (2) video and large quantity of photo content in the storage of Staff#2 (S2) work issued cell phone containing communication from Client#1 (C1). Facility in addition, submitted Report of Suspected Dependent Adult and Social Worker was contacted. Facility reported, no Law Enforcement report was submitted. Facility described the nature of the photos and pictures where staff was found to have cross boundaries with C1. Facility terminated S2 due to violating Casa Pacifica staff conduct policies on 03/06/2023. Based on the interviews conducted and information obtained during today’s inspections, no further investigation or interviews are required on the above incident. LPAs interview Staff#2 (S2), Staff#3 (C3) and resident decline to be interview. This case management investigation is closed. here were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 03/08/2022, the Department received a complaint alleging Nonminor Dependent#1 (NMD1) is being discriminated because of their race, and that residents smoke marijuana on the premises. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with residents, staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. Facility program is designed to prepare residents to live independently by assist them with budgeting, employment, life skills, and educational goals. LPA Rosas during inspection observed adequate ratio that followed regulations. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence did not indicate that staff failed to supervise or discriminate residents in placement. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Neglect and Lack of Supervision and Personal Rights violations. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations is unsubstantiated. The Department has decided that the allegations of Neglect/Lack of Supervision and Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On March 9, 2023, at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Olivia Rosas and Christine Wilson conducted an unannounced inspection to Casa Pacifica- Stepping Stones THP + FC (Transitional Housing Placement Program) for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPA Rosas, met with Staff#1 (S1) and together discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, LPA Rosas interviewed witnesses and pertinent parties related to the investigation. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 03/09/2023. Based on the confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process, record review, statements obtained, LPA Rosas concluded the allegations of client’s smoke Marijuana on the premises and staff are discriminating against a client. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the findings are unsubstantiated. Report continues LIC-9099C

narrative: On 12/20/23 at 01:50 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting an initial complaint investigation inspection (See LIC9099 dated 12/20/23). During walkthrough, LPA observed the facility not free and clear of clutter and debris. Hallway was observed to have debris alongside walls and in corners, bathroom smelled of mildew, cluttered with empty products, shower observed to have growth in corners of grout and kitchen sink containing dishes and food particles. Per California Code Regulation Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 General Licensing Regulations, one deficiency will be cited today. See LIC809-D for details. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with DTYS.

deficiencies.description:
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement was not met by: Based on observation and interview, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above that allowed the build up of clutter and debris in shared common areas which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will send photos of cleaned shared common spaces to jhane.haynes@dss.ca.gov. Licensee will also develop a plan to keep facility free of debris and clutter and email plan to LPA.

narrative:
On 01/30/2024 at 2:05PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to Casa Pacifica Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) Administrative Office for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA Wilson met with Program Supervisor (PS) who granted access to the Administrative Office and an inspection was conducted together. Individuals mentioned in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 01/30/24. The annual fees are current. LPA Wilson inspected following: The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents NMD) to thirty (30) participants. There is a Nalazone waiver on file. There are currently seven (7) participants in placement at (2) different sites (site A and site B are located on the premises of Casa Pacifica. There are no off-site locations during the time of this inspection). There are no participants on a placement waitlist. Facility has one (1) Case Management Social Worker (SW) (1 per 7 participants) and one (1) Facility Supervisor and one (1) Facility Administrator (1 per 1 Social Workers). The facility is currently operating within staff ratio. The administrative office is located at 1728 S. Lewis Road, Camarillo, CA 93012. The office is located in proximity to the sites and is set up as follows: Administration office is a two (2) room office with Resource Center area. The Resource area is used by staff and clients for program use. There are three (3) desks used by staff, Program Superisor and case carrying social worker, large table and chairs, TV, Microwave, refridgerator, and AC unit. The second office has an adjacent kitchenette with refrigerator and microwave. The Adminisrtrator Office is equipped with one (1) desk used by the Program Director and has locked file cabinets for client files, and a heater with thermostat. This office is available to conduct private interviews. Staff records are maintained in the Human Resource office and the client records are maintained in the Program Director's office space inside locked file cabinets. All posting requirements were met. Continues on 8009C Page 2 of 2

Page 2 LPA Wilson, requested the following forms for review, copy of applicable waiver and exceptions, Register of participants, Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan Protocols, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C). There are (2) current Certificates of Compliance for (2) individual units A and B are which are occupied. Due to time constraints, LPA Christine Wilson will return to complete the inspection to and inspect the following: Site A and B inspection, Staff Records Review, Clients Records Review, Staff Interviews, and Client Interviews There are no deficiencies at this time. Copy of report was read with Program Supervisor and left on site.

investigation_findings: 13On 04/25/2024 at 03:11PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jhane Haynes made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and deliver the complaint findings. LPA spoke with Christan Schuler (Perez) Administrator and together discussed the investigative findings. During the investigation LPA Haynes interviewed and accounted for all relevant parties. Interviews reflected staff did not adhere to defensive driver policy. Based on interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Per Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1, one deficiency will be cited today. See LIC9099-D for details. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to the administrator.

deficiencies.description: The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement was not met by facility staff transporting participants in an unsafe manner.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will develop plan to prevent future violation and email to LPA Haynes by 05/10/2024.

narrative: On 06/19/2024 at 10:27am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson, made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, and met with the THPP Program Director, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 06/17/2024. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 06/17/2024, the NMD client (C1) who currently resides in CASA Pacifica Transitional Housing, reported to staff (PD) that she has been pressured into having sex with another NMD participant (C2) in the housing program, but denies the sexual activity is rape, and even though (C1) tells (C2) no, the sexual activity still happens. Further, this has not been reported to the police because (C1) does not want to make a police report. Staff have provided support to file a police report, a safety plan with boundaries and coaching, disclosing how a shared living agreement will be moving forward and well as dating and relationship policy review and referring (C1) to CSEC Forever Found Community Partner. Staff have provided case management, including discussion about intimacy with house mates, the dating and relationship policy, and the risks associated with sexual activity with client (C2). Staff will ensure clients are not transported together and will be increasing on-call staff in the evening. Per the (PD) the structure of living in the temporary location with not be co-ed. Further the (PD) stated the construction for the temporary THPP location start and end of construction date will change due to water damage found, leading to the sub-flooring needing to be replaced and permit clearance needed. Clients will not transfer to the temporary location until permits and project completion. There are no deficiencies cited today. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the licensee.

On 09/18/2024 at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Christine Wilson and Licensing Program Manager, (LPM) Kevin Sauk made an announced visit for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with the Director of Transitional Youth Services, CEO, Compliance and Risks Manager, Facility Maintenance Manager and the Regional Director of Ventura County, and together toured the Stepping Stones (TYS) temporary location on-site cottages and administrative office , The Stepping Stones (TYS) temporary location is located at 1722 S Lewis Road in Camarillo. The administrative office is located at Building N, 1722 S Lewis Road in Camarillo. The Facility Administrator and Clinical Program Manager's Office is located in the main Casa Pacifica Campus Administrative Office. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) to 20 participants ages eighteen (18) to twenty one (21). There are currently (9) participants waiting to be relocated from the original THPP location.. LPA Wilson and LPA Sauk inspected two cottages: McDonald's and Angels Cottages, which are newly renovated and have an identical physical plant footprint as follows: Report continued on LIC809C page 2

At 9:50 am LPA Wilson and LPM Sauk inspected the following: Each building has (2) bedroom suites with on-suite full bathrooms. Clean linens, drawers, cabinets, desk and chair and has a functioning smoke detector with carbon monoxide detector and thermostat in working condition. Water temperature tested to be within range. Each building has (7) additional bedrooms for one client. Beds have clean linens, drawers, cabinets, desk and chair and has a functioning smoke detector with carbon monoxide in working condition. Water temperature tested to be within range. There are (3) fire extinguishers available. External thermostat controls for the additional bedrooms is located adjacent to the kitchen There are (4) all-gender bathrooms with sink toilet and shower/tub. Water temperature tested to be within range. Each building has a kitchen with full sized freezer set at 8 degrees, refrigerator at 36 degrees, additional cabinets for each participant's non perishable items, First Aid kit observed to have all items. The kitchens were stocked with pots, pans, cooking utensils, and enough dishes for participants, air fryer, toaster oven, microwave and dishwasher, all tested to be within working condition. There is a telephone line in the kitchen and additional fire extinguisher. Each building has a laundry room with (3) washers and (3) dryers, additional towels and laundry detergents. Per the Facility Maintenance Manager, additional cabinetry will be added to this area in each building. Each building has a counseling/clinical room for private session and phone calls. No files are kept in this room. Room has (1) desk, (1) table and (5) chairs. Each building has a water filtration station in working condition. Each building has a living room area with (2) couches for (10) persons, television and small tables. Games and books were observed to be available. Each building has a game room with gaming consoles, (2) gaming chairs, (1) bean bag and (4) large chairs with small tables. There is a dining area with (3) tables and (12) chairs. All rugs were non-slip and in good condition. at 11:06am, LPA and LPM met with the Director of Transitional Youth Services, CEO, Compliance and Risks Manager, and the Regional Director of Ventura County in the administrative building and discussed the Plan of Operation. Report continued on LIC809C page 3

Page 3 LPA Wilson and LPM Sauk received a copy of the LIC500, and client roster, copy of fire inspection record cards for McDonalds and Angel Cottages. Per the Facility maintenance manager both buildings have obtained full clearance from the Ventura County Inspector of building and safety. An email was sent to LPA Wilson and LPM Sauk indicating that the new building project is finalized and has passed inspection. Certificates of Compliance, job descriptions and Intake Assessment Forms were reviewed. An LIC200 for a capacity of (20) clients served was submitted today to LPA Wilson and LPM Sauk. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 25, 2023 at 2:15 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 09/20/24. During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on 09/20/24 the Group Home youth (C1) was awol from the facility, which resulted in Group Home youth (C1 visiting with THPP NMD (C2) in their house. Intake facility Manager was notified and saw youth on camera and and called for staff to conduct a perimeter check, where youth was found exiting the house and was escorted back to the Group Home. LPA Wilson and Director of Transitional Youth Services walked the perimeter of the Stepping Stones program, observed the fence and camera. LPA Wilson obtained copy of the SIR, timeline and determined that staff acted quickly to supervise and locate youth. There are no deficiency to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and left with licensee. (S1) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

Page 2 Further, key witnesses that could determine the validity of the allegation (1) were either not available or declined to be interviewed. The above allegations are unsubstantiated meaning, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the finding is unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited, at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On December 11, 2024 at 11:46 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations. LPA met with the Director of TYS THP Administrator. Based on the confidential interviews with all relevant persons, conducted during the investigation process,record review, and statements obtained, LPA Wilson concluded the allegations are unsubstantiated. During the investigative process by both LPA Haynes and LPA Wilson, relevant parties have been accounted for. There are other smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in the cottage related to allegations(2-3), such that the requirement was met. Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description:
80087	Buildings and Grounds		  
(a)	The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Photo evidence of bathroom mold, infestation of insects, broken fans and clogged sinks such that the requirement was not met, thus, posing an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will meet with staff to review Buildings and Grounds regulations to ensure room compliance checks, site walkthroughs and maintenence requests are submitted timely. Licensee will send meeting minutes to LPA by due date.

narrative: On this date, an unannounced Required Annual Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Bruce. LPA was met at 1101 Sylvan Ave, Suite A-5 by Administrator Arlene Figueroa-Morales. Currently the agency services 8 THP+FC participants, employs one part time case manager and one full time Administrator. LPA observed agency has appropriate office space for staff and meetings, and confidential files are locked and maintained appropriately. The two staff files were reviewed on today's visit. LPA observed that all files had required documentation and were in compliance with regulations. All staff are appropriately fingerprint cleared and associated. Five client files were reviewed at today's inspection. Required documentation was present and were in compliance with regulations except for no Needs and Services Plan and no Medical Assessment. Citation for those violations will be issued on today's date.

On today's date, Licensing Program Analysts LPA- Rachel Bruce and Brianna Placencia arrived at the above facility for the purpose of clearing the Plan of Correction for the annual inspection completed on November 7, 2022. Paperwork to clear the deficiencies issued on November 7, 2022 were provided and the plan of corrections were cleared.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lidia Tinoco arrived at the Central Valley Community Resources THP+FC at 1101 Sylvan Ave, Suite A-5 for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Annual Required inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Arlene Figueroa-Morales. A walk through inspection of the facility was conducted. The Agency currently has 8THP+FC participants, employs one Social Worker and one full time Administrator. A file review was conducted on January 31, 2025, presented 0 deficiencies within the past 12 months. A review of Guardian indicates that all facility staff associated and identified on the LIC500 have eligible clearance. LPA reviewed 5 Client, and 3 staff files. LPA interviewed 1 Staff. The FFA received 2 type B Deficiencies on today's visit, See LIC809D and 1 Technical Violation. A copy of the report was provided at the conclusion of the inspection along with appeal rights.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Deaton conducted a case management investigation of the facility address listed above in compliance with COVID-19 precautions. The purpose of the case management was to review background clearance policies for prospective roommates of nonminor dependent THP participants. This report was discussed with Crystal Carter, Social Work Supervisor. On June 8, 2021, the LPA was notified by Ben Payne, Administrator (AD) that a new participant (P1 - see LIC811 Confidential Names list date 9/22/2021) informed the Agency Social Worker (ASW) that they lived with their prospective roommate (RM) while admitted to another Transitional Housing Placement Provider. AD stated that for this reason, ASW facilitated a living unit agreement with P1 and RM prior to receiving a response on RM's background clearance request. AD stated that they were informed RM requires an exception, and that this had been requested. On July 12, 2021, the LPA toured the facility which was clean, safe, and sanitary. On July 19, 2021, the LPA was informed by the facility that RM's background clearance exception was processed. Facility supervisors conducted staff training regarding background clearance policies and the protocol was submitted to the LPA. The LPA conferred with the Policy Department and confirmed on September 9, 2021, that Title 22 Sections 80019(e) and 80019(g) did not apply, however Health and Safety Code Section did apply. These regulations have been included on the attached LIC809-C as reference.

This form is continued from the attached LIC809. Regulatory Statute that applies: Health and Safety Code 1559.110(g)(2)(G) Any adult who is not a participant, including participants in Transitional Housing Program-Plus, as defined in subdivision(s) of Section 11400 of the Welfare and Institutions Code, and who resides with a participant shall obtain a criminal record clearance or exemption in accordance with Section 1522. Regulatory Statutes that do not apply: Title 22 Section 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department or (2) Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 80019(f) or (3) Request and be approved for a transfer of a criminal record exemption, as specified in Section 80019.1(r), unless, upon request for the transfer, the Department permits the individual to be employed, reside or be present at the facility. Title 22 Section 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (g) Violation of Section 80019(e) will result in an immediate assessment of civil penalties of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation for a maximum of 5 days by the Department. (1) Subsequent violations within a twelve (12) month period will result in a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation per day for a maximum of thirty (30) days. (2) The Department may assess civil penalties for continued violations as permitted by Health and Safety Code Section 1548. No citations were issued throughout the course of this investigation.

An announced visit was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Whitlow, on 9/30/21 at 1:00 PM fo continuation ofr annual inspection. During the visit, LPA met with supervisor, Crystal Carter, and reviewed records of ten participants. A technical advisory is being given, but no citations. The Needs and Services Plans of three out of ten participants were not signed by the placing agency, as required, but this does not pose an immediate health and safety risk. LPA also began reviewing staff records, but was unable to complete. LPA will return to facility on 10/1/21 to continue annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted with supervisor, Crystal Carter, who signed LIC 809, and a copy was emailed to the licensee.

An announced visit was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Whitlow, on 10/01/21 at 9:30 AM for continuation of annual inspection. During the visit, LPA met with supervisor, Crystal Carter. Records of ten staff members, the Plan of Operation, and Disaster Preparedness Plans were reviewed. There were no noted deficiencies, although LPA gave a technical advisory. No citations were given. The staff record files contained all required documents, but were not compartmentalized into sections. LPA advised licensee to make more effective provisions for future record review. An exit interview was conducted with supervisor, Crystal Carter, who signed LIC 809, and a copy was emailed to the licensee.

An unannounced visit was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Whitlow, on 9/29/21 at 9:00 AM for annual inspection. During the visit, LPA met with supervisor, Crystal Carter, and toured the facility. The current license was available and posted prominently. A list of all current addresses and telephone numbers of all THPP participant living units and LIC 500 were provided. There was accessible telephone service and there was an office available that provided privacy for confidential interviews. LPA conducted six staff interviews. All staff and participant records are maintained electronically on a computer program. General clerical staff members assisted LPA with navigating the program to review records, and LPA was able to complete review for one participant, but this was time consuming. At 3:30 PM, LPA spoke supervisor, Crystal Carter, and requested that a staff member familiar with the system assist LPA when LPA returns to complete the inspection 9/30/21 at 1:00 PM, which she said she could accommodate. Exit interview was completed, LIC 809 signed, and sent electronically.

On 06/09/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Crystal Carter, CEO in training for the purpose of a case management inspection regarding social worker ratios and qualifications. LPAs Valencia and Lyta Vue conducted the case management. During the course of the inspection, LPAs Valencia and Vue conducted a records review. LPAs Valencia and Vue reviewed records including: LIC-500 Personnel Report, job descriptions, and social worker caseloads. Facility Records reviewed indicated the following: -Four (4) Social Worker Assistants (SWAs) and One (1) Social Worker are over capacity on their caseload, meaning they are assigned more than twelve (12) Transitional Housing Placement Program participants (THP) clients, or more than 18 foster youth, or a combination. Due to the majority of the clients on the caseloads being THP, the citation is issued to the THP facility, not the Foster Family Agency facility license. Based on records reviewed, the following citation is issued: Health and Safety Code Section 1559.110(g)(2)(D) allows for a caseload maximum of 12 clients Transitional Housing Placement clients. While not cited, the licensee was also in violation of Interim Licensing Standards FFA Article 09.7. Continuing Requirements 88265.5 Social Worker Ratios (b) A foster family agency shall employ one full-time social worker for every 18 children or nonminor dependents, or fraction thereof, in placement. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and LIC 809D report was provided to the facility. Appeal rights were provided, and an exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced to the facility for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection. LPM and LPA conducted an inspection of the facility inside and out. The facility submitted a 24 hour Serious Incident Report on 05/31/23 reporting the death of a Transitional Housing Placement Program participant (THP). LPA reviewed and collected records at the facility and interviewed two individuals, CEO (in training) and Director of Social Work. Records indicated the Agency Social Worker (ASW) was making regular contact with the participant and a current Needs and Services Plan was on file. Local Law Enforcement is still investigating, but at this time, no foul play is suspected. The County Coroner will conduct an autopsy. The participant's placing county has been notified. LPA will continue to follow up with the facility as more information becomes available. No citation was issued during this inspection. A copy of this report was provided to the facility. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause of death.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPAs met with Crystal Carter, CEO in training. The Investigations Branch and LPA Valencia conducted the case management. During the course of the case management, it was determined the Resource Parent violated one client’s personal rights by making inappropriate and demeaning comments to a Non-minor Transitional Housing client and a minor in the home who was not a client. Comments included telling the client they had been placed in foster care due to their behavior, and telling the other minor Resource Parent wished they’d never met. The client stated the comments occurred in the summer of 2022. Twelve confidential interviews were conducted. Only two of the twelve individuals interviewed reported hearing inappropriate comments. Record review indicates Resource parent has been fostering for 19 years with no prior complaints. No citation is being issued at this time. Following interview with agency supervisor and review of records, Resource parent has already completed additional training in the following areas: -Personal Rights on 1/18/2023 for 2.5 hours and 3/15/2023 for 2.5 hours. -Changing Destructive Adolescent Behavior a 10 week course for 20 hours completed in 2023. Proof of training's were provided to LPA. A signed copy of this LIC 809 report was provided to the facility. Appeal rights were provided, and an exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced to the facility for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection. LPA met with Amelia Wakefield, Assistant program Manager (APM). The Agency submitted a 24 hr Serious Incident Report on 06/20/2023 reporting Transitional Housing Placement Program participant (THP) client was seen on video pulling a knife out and pointing it towards another THP client. APM reported that the agency created a verbal safety plan and requested an Emergency CFT meeting. APM will send LPA the written safety plan and CFT notes when available. No citation was issued during this inspection. A copy of this report was provided to the facility.

On 09/08/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Cynthia Moreno, Residential Technical Support Analyst arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Crystal Carter, CEO in training. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 09/21/21. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has multiple offices for social workers and multiple confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files that are stored electronically with password protection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has fifty-three (53) clients. Clients live in remote site apartments that resides within two hours from the facility. The facility employs fourteen (14) THP Social Workers and one (1) Case Manager, and five (5) Supervisors. LPA reviewed five (5) Social Worker personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Social Worker personnel. continued on 809-C

LPA interviewed three (3) social worker personnel. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than twelve ( 12) clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed five (5) client files. Two of five (2/5) clients had Needs and Services Plan (N&S) that were not signed by placement agency. LPA conducted a Technical Advisory. All Needs and Services Plan were detailed and had adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC 9102 reports was provided to Crystal Carter, CEO in training. An exit interview was conducted.

On 07/19/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia met with Crystal Carter CEO in Training at Community Care Licensing Office (CCL), regarding a Case Management (CM) Inspection follow up. The CM is in regards to a death of a client on 5/31/2023. Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall and LPA Lyta Vue conducted an initial inspection of the facility on 6/1/2023, interviewed two staff, and conducted a records review. On 7/7/2023, the Department received records from Local Law Enforcement and the county Coroner, who determined the cause of death. Record review indicated the facility had consistently visited the client, and provided supportive services. No foul play suspected. No citation was issued during this inspection. A copy of this report was provided to the facility. No Further investigation is needed at this time.

On 11/02/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced to the facility for the purpose of a Case Management (CM) Inspection and met with Crystal Carter CEO in Training. The CM is regarding a death of a Transitional Housing Placement Program participant (THP) on 10/31/2023. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility inside and out, conducted interviews, and records review. On 11/01/2023 The facility called and informed LPA that they received the information from the placing county social worker about the THP participant. Records reviewed indicated the Agency Social Worker (ASW) was making regular contact with the participant, provided supportive services and a current Needs and Services Plan was on file. Local Law Enforcement is still investigating and the County Coroner will conduct an autopsy. LPA will continue to follow up with the facility as more information becomes available. no citations issued at this time and a copy of this report provided to the facility.

met_with: Amelia Wakefield ISFC Assistant Program Manager (APM)
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of a case management inspection following a record review. LPA met with Amelia Wakefield ISFC Assistant Program Manager (APM. LPA reviewed two social worker meeting agendas dated 9/12/23 and 10/11/23, which indicated Transitional Housing Participants would be fined $25 for missing a visit with their agency social worker. LPA conducted a follow up interview with Crystal Carter CEO in training on this date. CEO in training confirmed the policy has been implemented, but no participants have been fined. The policy is not mentioned in the agency Program Statement, nor was the new policy reviewed or discussed with the Department. The agency is being cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80022(k): Plan of Operation (k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and 809D were provided to the facility. Appeal rights were also provided.

deficiencies.description:
Section 80022(k): Plan of Operation
(k) The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.
Based on records reviewed, social worker
meeting agendas dated 9/12/23 and 10/11/23, which indicated Transitional Housing Participants would be fined $25 for missing a visit with their agency social worker, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to clients/children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Agency agrees to provide a copy of the contract.  If the contract was provided to the participants, a new letter needs to go to participants indicating this policy is no longer in effect.  We will need a copy of this letter.

met_with: Julia McCasland, Social Work Supervisor and Crystal Carter, CEO in training
narrative: The client felt threatened at first, but later agreed that it was a miscommunication and a one-time incident. The client was not able to retrieve their remaining belongings from the home immediately upon their move out but was granted access to the home to retrieve their belongings within a few days. A language barrier was observed by LPA, which confirmed the potential for misunderstandings between the client and the Resource parent, regarding their moving plans and desire to collect their belongings upon moving out. Resource Parents denied the allegations. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and record reviews, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report and the LIC-9099C were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on 02.09.24 for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Julia JcCasland, Social Work Supervisor and Crystal Carter, CEO in training. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Lyta Vue opened the investigation with the facility on 11.22.23 and met with and interviewed Amelia Wakefield, Assistant Program Manager. LPA Thorn opened the investigation at the Resource Home on 11.21.23 and interviewed one Resource Parent and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted 10 additional confidential interviews. LPA reviewed records from the facility including Placement Roster, Agency social worker case notes, prior complaint history, Serious Incident Reports, and Needs and Service Plans for one client. Nine confidential interviews corroborated information regarding an incident involving a Transitional Housing client, moving to and from a Resource Home. Resource parents commented that the client would lose their placement if they left the home, based on information the Resource parent misheard from the agency.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management, following a record review and met with Heather Payne,Executive Director. While conducting an investigation for a different licensed facility on March 12, 2025, it was alleged an uncleared adult may have resided with a Children’s Hope Transitional Housing Placement (THP) participant for up to two years, between 2022-2024. On March 13, 2025, LPA Valencia requested case notes and other participant records from Children’s Hope, for the three years the participant was in the program, from 2021-2024. These records were reviewed. Multiple statements were found in the records to indicate the uncleared adult had their own separate residence. The assigned social worker documented conversations with the participant where the participant was informed the uncleared adult could not reside with the participant without obtaining a clearance. The participant signed an agreement indicating they were aware of the rules of uncleared adults and other visitors in the participants’ unit. While the uncleared adult was observed by the social worker in the participant’s unit on a couple occasions, and known to visit, there was no information that the facility was aware of, or allowed the uncleared adult to reside in the THP participant’s remote living apartment. No citations are being issued. A signed copy of this LIC-809 was provided to the facility.

On 08/05/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Crystal Carter, CEO in training. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 09/08/23. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has multiple offices for social workers and multiple confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including; facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files that are stored electronically with password protection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has 33 clients. Clients live in remote site apartments that reside within two hours from the facility. The facility employs 7 THP Social Workers, 3 Case Manager, and 5 Supervisors. LPA reviewed 5 Social Worker/Case Worker personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Social Worker personnel. continued on 809-C

LPA interviewed 3 social worker/case worker personnel. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than twelve clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed 5 client files. and cited for the following regulation 86270(a)(2)(C) (a) The licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and current record or file in the THPP for a nonminor dependent. (2) The following shall be included in the nonminor dependent's record or file: (C) A Needs and Services Plan for the nonminor dependent, and if provided, the Transitional Independent Living Plan for the nonminor dependent. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC-809D reports was provided to Crystal Carter, CEO in training. An exit interview was conducted.

Yuba City, Ca 95991, on 12/28/21, at 10:30 AM. LPA met with Shannon Pierce, Chief Operations Officer, who assisted with the inspection. LPA, Whitlow, inspected and reviewed the following: A working telephone, three secured locked areas for participant and staff records, an emergency disaster plan, furniture in good condition, and a plan of operation on site. Based upon inspection and review of submitted application, all requirements have been met. An exit interview was conducted with Shannon Pierce and a copy of this report was sent electronically.

LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. Social work personnel do not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. CONTINUE ON LIC809-C

LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of the LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC9102 documents were provided to Karen Kemp. An exit interview was conducted.

Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Karen Kemp - Regional Director. LPAs Kellie McKinley and Misty Valencia conducted the complaint investigation. LPA Misty Valencia opened the investigation with the facility on 9/11/23 and Karen Kemp, Regional Director, was interviewed. During the course of the investigation, LPAs interviewed One former client, a County Social Worker, an Agency Social Worker, a Probation Officer, and a property manager. LPA reviewed records from the facility including: Needs and Services Plan, Agency social worker case notes, Serious Incident Reports, receipts, and additional notices and eviction documentation. The facility indicated a client was given written notice of termination from the program. The client was absent from care and unable to assist with their own move from the housing unit.
