narrative: On 04.19.24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a Case Management inspection following a record review. LPA met with Karen Kemp, Program Director. While conducting a record review on 4.5.2024, LPA Thorn found 10 Incident Reports (IRs) that were submitted to the LPA for a complaint investigation, that had not been previously submitted to the Department within the seven-day requirement. The time period for when the IR’s occurred was between 02.26.23 and 04.04.23 and involved incidents of medical emergency, aggressive act towards self and staff member, and possession of ammunition. PD agreed that she will be checking the Ir's more closely. Agency is issued one citation for violating Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1. 80061: Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1)… a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A signed copy of this 809 and 809D were provided to WHOM. Exit interview conducted and appeal rights provided.

deficiencies.description: 80061(b) A report shall be made to the licensing agency within the next business day during business hours (1) a report shall be made to the licensing agency containing the information in (2) below shall be submitted to the agency within 7 days following the occurance of such event. The requirement was not met as evidenced by LPA's records reviewed observations that agency did not report incidents that meet the reporting requirement. This poses a risk to the health, safety, and personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: THP agrees submit to licensing agency the required incident information in order to meet the licensing requirement. Agency agrees to complete a training about licensing reporting requirements and provide documents that are signed by each staff completing the training. This was agreed to  be completed by 05.20.24.

narrative:
This resulted in files being incomplete. LPA found 1 file in which the Needs and Services Plan was duplicated but not updated. LPA reviewed 6 files for clients who were discharged. LPA found 3 of 6 discharged clients to not have a signed copy of written removal or discharge. The Program Director stated that former staff did provide support services to the clients but did not provide proper documentation. Also, during an interview PD explained that the process for documenting maintenance requests is for the the case managers to write them in case notes. During file review, 6 clients had files showing maintenance as being requested, 5 of these files were observed to have no documentation provided in subsequent case notes as to whether the issue(s) had been resolved. LPA reviewed six files of clients who had been discharged from the agency. Two out of six clients were given proper written notice of discharge but had to be discharged before the scheduled date due to emergency circumstances, which were documented. LPA observed proper written notice was given to one additional client. Three clients had no record of written notice of discharge notice in the file. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. Citations are being issued for violating Interim Licensing Standards Section 86270, Non-Minor Dependents Records and 86268.4, Removal or Discharge Procedures A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

Two clients reported lack of support to understand their finances as being a big concern. Interviews with ASW’s, CSWs, and clients point to living conditions as being a potential barrier to meeting goals, however, all agreed that it is very difficult to secure more desirable housing. Both CSW’s, a probation officer, and two clients reported the Agency Social Workers are dedicated to meeting the needs and providing great supervision to the clients. While maintenance and pest control issues were commonly reported, three of four clients and four of seven agency social workers agreed that these problems were addressed promptly. LPA observed case notes written by current staff to be more detailed and thorough than case notes written by previous staff. Interviews with previous staff conflict with interviews with current staff who all reported that they are given the support and supervision from administration that allows them to provide proper care and supervision to meet clients’ needs. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tina Thorn arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with NAME, TITLE. LPA Thorn conducted the complaint investigation. LPA opened the investigation with the facility on 01.30.24 and met with Program Director, Karen Kemp. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed 4 clients, 7 current and former case managers (CM), 2 county social workers (CSW), 2 Program Directors, 1 property manager, 1 Chief Operations Officer, 3 current and former Administrative Assistants, and 1 probation officer. LPA reviewed records from the facility including Agency case notes, prior complaint history, Serious Incident Reports, Child, and Family Team notes (CFT), Needs and Service Plans for clients, Placement Roster, Lease agreements, discharge summary, and written notice. LPA observed during file review, that 6 of 15 client’s files reviewed did not provide documentation that behavior contracts or CFTs that were referenced as being scheduled, were ever completed.

deficiencies.description: The licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and current record or file in the THPP for the nonminor dependent. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: 6-15 client files did not have proper documentation. this poses a potential health and safety risk to client.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Agency agrees to create a procedure to ensure that supportive services are documented in the client's file. Procedure will be submitted to Department by POC date of 05.20.24.

deficiencies.description: At the request of nonminor dependent or at the discretion of the administrator, social work personnel, or their designee, a nonminor dependent may be discharged from the THPP with 7 days written notice prior to discharge. This required was not met as evidenced by: 3-6 clients were given proper written notice of discharge. This poses a potential health and safety risk to client.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Agency agrees to provide written notice of discharge  to THP client and keep updated information in clients' file. Procedure will be submitted to Department by POC date of 05.20.24.

narrative:
CSW said that P1 initially refused a heater for the residence but CSW told THP they needed to provide one anyway and let P1 decide if he wanted to use it, noting that it was summertime at when P1 moved in and he may not have been thinking ahead to wintertime. On 12/2/2020, the LPA contacted Janice Saelee, Program Manager (PM) who stated the water was repaired and P1 was told to turn on the main water main after 24 hours. PM said that P1 has turned this knob off in the past and knows how to operate it. On 2/19/2021, The LPA contacted the landlords (LL1 and LL2) who own the residence that P1 lived in. When asked to describe ASW's attire LL1 said, "Professional…everybody’s doing everything they can to help him [P1] and he’s just sabotaging…" LL1 said that THP handles all move in/out duties and they “basically rent this apartment to Children’s First.” When asked about the repairs made to the residence LL2 said, "The only thing I know about was the issue with a leak...knocked on the door, he [P1] answered and yelled like a maniac…threatened to kill him because I was on his property…I went back after and some girl from the child place met me there when he wasn’t there…all the caulking had been dug out…obviously it was the kid..” The LPA also contacted ASW who said that P1 told her about a bug problem over the summer, so she purchased bug bombs for him. ASW said her efforts to take care of the leaks were delayed due to P1 not allowing LL2 to enter the residence after verifying the appointment. ASW explained that P1 rarely responded to her attempts for communication via phone or text, but that he would sometimes respond via THP’s Facebook Messenger account and usually only when he was expecting a check. ASW said she purchased two phones for P1 so he could stay in contact with THP and CSW, but that this didn’t help. ASW added that she is required to make contact weekly and after 72 hours without contact conducts a welfare check. ASW said P1 was initially concerned that some of his property would be damaged due to the leak but nothing was. ASW said she purchased two heaters for P1 and has the receipts. ASW said that she worked with P1 consistently regarding housing, finding a job, attending school, and receiving counseling but that P1 lacked motivation. ASW said she “hooked him up with the ILP Program” but that P1 said they weren’t very helpful. ASW said she talked with P1 several times about him needing to stay active with job applications and communication to stay in the program. On 2/21/2021, the LPA contacted P1 who stated THP was not able to fix the leaks, so he eventually moved. P1 said the reason it took so long was because the cause of the leak couldn’t be identified. When asked about an incident when LL2 came to fix the leak P1 said LL2 entered the residence without knocking first. P1 said “things are better now” but could not articulate anything THP could have done better or differently. When asked what program participants are responsible for, P1 could not provide any details aside from needing a job. When asked what the THP is responsible for, P1 could not provide any details but said they gave him gas money. On 2/26/2021, the LPA contacted PM who confirmed THP did not have P1's final Home Inspection Checklist from the residence addressed in the complaint allegations. (Page 2/3).

The LPA reviewed ASW’s Contact Notes from 10/1/20 to 12/1/20. ASW addressed P1 needing a job and counseling services on a regular basis. P1 expressed that COVID-19 was a barrier. Concerns for P1’s participation in the program and mental health were also documented. ASW documented that multiple checks were provided for interview clothes and phones. Several notes were documented regarding ongoing leak issues however a five-day gap with no documented communication was identified. On 11/25/20, ASW documented the following: landlord [LL2] came out to inspect shower pan, put more sealant around it, and asked that the shower not be used for 24 hours, P1 was fine to stay with former roommate; on 12/1/20 ASW documented a phone call to P1 about “him being able to turn water on now and use the shower as well as process of finding new housing.” The LPA reviewed a Serious Incident Report dated 11/13/2020 that documented P1 agreed to LL2 coming to fix the leak on 11/13/20 and was advised verbally and in text that the visit would be early morning. P1 agreed to this on 11/12/20 after the issues were not fixed by the plumbing company. The morning of 11/13, ASW1 messaged P1 firming up an exact time of LL2’s visit for 11am. When LL2 arrived and knocked on P1’s door, P1 answered and would not allow LL2 inside becoming “hostile and aggressive” pushing LL2 out of the doorway and yelling in his face. LL2 called ASW to report P1 would not allow him access into the unit to fix the leak issue. ASW reached out to P1 about the incident and P1 advised ASW that he was not aware of the time and that the LL2 just tried walking in. ASW spoke with LL2 and P1 to reconcile the issue and rescheduled for LL2 to come out without P1 being present. The LPA reviewed the Home Inspection Checklists that were available. It is unclear if the residence was ready for P1 to move into last summer. The LPA reviewed email correspondence between CSW and ASW. On 11/18/20, ASW states the water had been shut off the week before. On 11/20/20, ASW told CSW LL2 would come out the following Monday (11/23/20) at 1pm to fix the issue and they were unable to come out sooner because they needed at least 24 hours’ notice to do so. CSW said the shower was not finished being fixed until 11/25/20 and after the leak was fixed is when P1 was asked to not use the shower for 24 or 48 hours but that he could use the water in the rest of the house, although the water had not been turned back on at the main. On 12/01/20, CSW reports that P1 told her the water had not been turned back on and ASW was not responding to him about it. On 12/02/20, ASW told CSW she told P1 multiple times he needed to turn the water back on at the main. On 12/02/20, PM went out and turned the water back on at the main. The LPA reviewed an email from CSW sent on 2/19/21 regarding the iFoster phone. CSW stated that P1 received that phone on 01/20/20, rarely used it, and in March 2020 ASW told CSW she believed P1 gave it away. CSW and ASW offered to help P1 get a replacement / different phone. The LPA also reviewed the THP Program Statement Social Worker Job Description and Personnel Policies. There is no reference to professional attire and no details pertinent to the investigation. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report will be sent to the THP via email with a read receipt requested.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Deaton discussed this report with Janice Saelee, Program Manager with Children’s First (THP) via PLATFORM in accordance with COVID-19 precautions on 2/26/21. The purpose of the visit was to deliver complaint investigation findings into the above allegations regarding a program participant (P1 – see LIC811 Confidential Names List dated 11/30/2020). The Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) contacted three facility staff, one County Social Worker, two landlords, one program participant, and one family member, and conducted reviewed records. On 11/30/2020, the LPA contacted P1’s family member who stated there has been "major water issues for weeks and weeks;" the issues may have been fixed but Heather Sparks, Agency Social Worker (ASW) "has been very diligent in trying to get him [P1] to do what he should be doing...let’s things slide...” The family member also said ASW does not wear professional attire for home visits. The LPA contacted Shannon Pierce, Chief Operating Officer who was not aware of any issues with P1 but does not work with them on a usual basis. The LPA contacted Alexa Costa, County Social Worker (CSW) who stated they are concerned with how long it took THP to address the leaks and because THP did not inform CSW of the leaks. CSW said it is her understanding that the water was off for one week and has been given different timeframes from multiple people. (Page 1/3).

met_with: Ben Evans - HR and Technology Compliance Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores conducted unannounced annual inspection on 02/24/22 and met with Ben Evans - Human Resource Manager who assisted with the inspection. The LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool and initiated a review of the Physical Plant, Operations, and Disaster Preparedness. Facility was clean and organized. First Aid kit was complete. LPA observed that the license is posted in a prominent area and visible by the public as required. LPA observed that the facility can accommodate for private interviews. LPA observed that there are restrooms available for participants and visitors. LPA observed that there is a file room for confidentially stored and locked files as required. During the inspection on this date, LPA reviewed 5 participant files and interviewed two staff during the inspection. The annual inspection will continue on 02/25/22 for final audit of the program.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores, Robyn Word, and Kellie McKinley arrived at the agency on 02/25/22 at 9:30am to conclude the annual inspection from 02/24/22. LPA reviewed six THP participant files. Files were well organized and contained initial and updated Needs and Services plans, admission agreements, and safeguards for cash resources. Files were missing medical assessments and results of tuberculosis (TB) examination. Licensee explained difficulties in getting participants to agree to medical assessments as young adults. Provider Information Notice (PIN) 21-17-CRP released in May of 2021 clarifies the requirement for children and non minor dependents in Children's Residential facilities to undergo an examination for TB. Licensee explained the difficulties in implementing changes during a pandemic and provided proof of training that was conducted in October 2021 regarding TB exams. At this time, California Code of Regulations Section 86069(a)(1) Participant Medical Assessment is being cited. Exit interview was conducted with Shannon Pierce and appeal rights discussed.

continued from 9099 Interviews and record review indicated a Social Work Supervisor (SWS) had not completed case notes or Needs and Service Plans timely. The Needs and Service Plans (NSP) which were available for LPA to review were not signed by the client, and not specific to the client. Case notes were incomplete and unavailable when LPA first requested them. SWS later stated the missing notes were “at home,” and if they had known LPA was going to the office they would have asked another staff member “to go to my house to retrieve them.” SWS noted concerns with the client on the case notes, but no follow up services were documented. SWS provided LPA with a chart documenting the dates of their home visits with clients. The dates on the chart did not match the dates of the submitted case notes. For 6 clients, the chart reflects that the SWS made home visits, however the corresponding case notes says there was no home visit on that date. When interviewed, a client on SWS’s case load indicated home visits usually lasted about 5-10 minutes. A social worker indicated the training provided upon hire was not nearly sufficient and SWS was not readily available when the social worker had questions. SWS admitted during an interview that their case notes and NSP’s were not current, and this was partly due to the facility being short staffed, and the SWS on vacation. Based on the preponderance of evidence that was met through interviews, observation, and record review, the allegation of: Social work supervisor duties are not being met is SUBSTANTIATED. The Social Worker Supervisor had a caseload and failed to fulfill duties as a Social Worker. Due to missing and incomplete notes, there is insufficient evidence to verify the Social Work Supervisor was supervising the placement of the participant and providing supportive services. The facility is cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Article 06. Continuing Requirements Section 86065.3(f)(2-4) Social Work Personnel (f) Social work personnel shall be responsible for the following: (2) Supervision of the placement of participants in the THPP participant living unit. (3) Development and updating of the needs and services plan of THPP participants. (4) Provision of support services to THPP participants. A signed copy of this LIC-9099, LIC-9099C, and LIC 9099D were provided to the facility. Appeal Rights were given. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA Valencia met with Shannon Pierce, Chief Operations Officer (COO). LPA Hillary Hall, LPA Shannon Parks, and LPA Misty Valencia conducted the complaint investigation. The complaint was opened with the facility on 8/1/22. LPAs met with Chief Operations Officer to discuss the allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA’s interviewed seven facility staff and three clients. LPA reviewed relevant records from the facility including: Agency social worker case notes for multiple clients, Needs and Service Plans, facility LIC-500, staff training log, and job descriptions for social workers and supervisors. The complaint alleges: Social work supervisor duties are not being met. continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description: 86065.3(f)(2-4) Social Work Personnel (f)	Social work personnel shall be responsible for the following: (2)	Supervision of the placement of participants in the THPP participant living unit. (3) Development and updating of the needs and services plan...(4)Provision of... This requirement was not met as evidence by LPA's records reviewed observations that case notes were incomplete and unavailable for LPA to review when requested posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: FFA agrees to continue with performance approval plan that started on 9/01/2022-11/30/2022 with social worker supervisor (SWS). FFA will continue providing compliance over sight to follow new template protocols that was trained back on 9/14/2022. FFA will provide training materials. If SWS fails to meet required protocols SWS will be demoted or terminated.

narrative: Interviews and record review indicate a maintenance staff who is without a criminal record clearance, did go into the homes of Transitional Housing Participants (THP) without being monitored by a staff person who did have a criminal record clearance. The participants were present in the home at the time. COO reported the policy is that all maintenance staff who do not have clearances, are to be monitored by a cleared staff member at all times, in the presence of a client. Interviews concluded the policy was not followed. The maintenance staff has been employed about 1 ½ years and his primary job is maintenance of the THP housing units Based on the evidence that was met through interviews, observation, and record review, the allegation of: Staff are working at the facility without being background check cleared is SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Section 86019(b)(2), Criminal Record Clearance: (b) The following persons are exempt from the requirement to submit fingerprints: (2) A third-party repair person, or similar retained contractor, if all of the following apply: (A) The individual is hired for a defined, time-limited job. (B) The individual is not left alone with participants. (C) When participants are present in the room in which the repair person or contractor is working, a staff person who has a criminal record clearance or exemption is also present. A signed copy of this LIC-9099, LIC-9099C, and LIC 9099D were provided to the facility. Appeal Rights were given. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA Valencia met with Mike Logan, CEO/Administrator. LPAs Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia conducted the complaint investigation. The complaint was opened with the facility on 9/15/22. LPA met with the Chief Operations Officer (COO) to discuss the allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA’s interviewed seven facility staff and four clients. LPAs reviewed relevant records from the facility including: Facility LIC-500, Criminal Record Clearances, and Staff training log. The complaint alleges: Staff are working at the facility without being background check cleared. continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description: 86019(b)(2), Criminal Record Clearance: (b) The following persons are exempt from the requirement to submit fingerprints: (2) A third-party repair person...(A) The individual is hired for... (B) The individual is not left alone...(C) When participants are present... This requirement was not met as evidence by LPA's records reviewed observations and interviews concluded that clearance was not verified for maintencice person who has contact with children in care; posing a potential risk to the Health, Safety, and personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: FFA agrees to conduct training regarding the policy and procedures when un cleared staff have any contact with children in care and to always being monitored by a cleared staff. FFA will email updated policies and procedures regarding uncleared staff by 10/15/2022.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of delivering a case management investigation. LPAs Hillary Hall and Misty Valencia received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) from the facility dated 10/27/22. The facility reported a Non-Minor Transitional Housing Participant called their on-call social worker at 6pm to report hallucinations from a fentanyl and methamphetamine overdose. The facility Program Director approved for an Uber to pick up the participant and transport them to the Emergency Room (ER). The Uber driver had to call the facility to report the participant was incoherent and uncooperative at the ER. The SIR indicated the facility last heard from the participant at 11pm and was not sure of their location as the participant did not stay at the ER. The following day, the facility terminated the participant from the program for non-compliance and substance use. LPA followed up with the facility to ensure the participant was found. Facility indicated the participant was admitted to a detox center the next day. Based on record review and an interview with the Program Director, the facility did not send a social worker to assist the participant due to feeling it “was not safe for a single, female social worker.” The Program Director indicated 911 should have been called to assist the participant. Following the participant’s report of having overdosed, the facility failed to call for immediate medical services (911), failed to personally transport the participant to the ER, nor did they go to the hospital to meet the participant to ensure their safety. continued on 809-C

continued from 809 The facility is cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Article 06. Continuing Requirements Section 86065.3(f)(2, 4) Social Work Personnel (f) Social work personnel shall be responsible for the following: (2) Supervision of the placement of participants in the THPP participant living unit. 4) Provision of support services to THPP participants. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC 809D report were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights provided.

On 3/23/2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Kelly McKinley conducted unannounced annual inspection and met with Shannon Pierce Chief Operations Officer, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs Valencia and McKinley utilized the CARES tool to conduct the inspection. The Agency currently has seventy-one (71) clients. Facility was clean and organized. First Aid kit was complete. LPAs observed that the license is posted in a prominent area and visible by the public as required. LPAs observed that the facility can accommodate for private interviews, there are restrooms available for participants and visitors. LPAs observed that there is a file room for confidentially stored and locked files as required. During the inspection, LPAs reviewed ten (10) staff files and interviewed three (3) staff during the inspection. LPAs reviewed ten (10) THP participant files. Client files were well organized and contained initial and updated Needs and Services plans, admission agreements, and safeguards for cash resources. Two (2) Staff files were missing medical assessments and results of tuberculosis (TB) examination. At this time, California Code of Regulations Section 86066(a)(11) (12)(a)The Licensee shall ensure that personnel record are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information. (11) A health Screening specified in Section 86065(I)(1) (12) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 86065(l)(1). This requirement was not met by; LPAs observed that Staff #8 and #10 has no health screening or TB test in the personal files. LPA provided an Advisory Note-Technical Violation. Exit interview was conducted with Shannon Pierce and report copy provided.

met_with: Ben Evans- Director of Business Operations
narrative: On this date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley and Yesenia Vallejo arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Ben Evan Director of Business Operations. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 3/23/2023. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has multiple offices for social workers and two confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files were stored electronically with multi-factor authentication and password protected as well as and in hard copy format. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has 60 Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs 6 Social Worker(s) and Case Managers, and 1 of Supervisor/Program Manager. LPA reviewed 5 Social Worker personnel files including the THP directors file. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Social Worker personnel. LPA interviewed 3 social worker personnel and one social worker supervisor. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed 5 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to Ben Evans -Director of Business Operations. An exit interview was conducted.

On 4/24/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yesenia Vallejo arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management, following review of Serious incident reports and related interviews, involving a Transitional Housing placement (THP) participant. LPA Kellie McKinley and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall previously reviewed Serious Incident Reports and conducted interviews regarding a THP participant allegedly harboring clients who had absconded from another facility. LPA Vallejo met with Charlotte Spencer site and requested records for one participant including facility contact notes for previous 6 months, most current Needs and service, and placement information, for additional review. No citations issued on this date. Further investigation is needed. A signed copy of this LIC 809 was provided to the facility.

Interviews and records were consistent that a participant moved three times while in placement. The authorized representative was notified the first two times of the participant being relocated to a new living unit, and was notified of the third move the day of. Interviews and records were inconsistent as to if the authorized representative was notified prior to the third move. Based on LPA’s interviews and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: On 06/24/2025 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yesenia Vallejo met with Children First Transitional Housing Regional Director, Karen Kemp to conduct a pre-licensing inspection at their new location. The new THPP/THP+FC facility is conveniently located for the public. LPA conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA observed as you enter the building the office has a reception waiting area with a glass room divider that overlooks into the reception office. In order to be let in to the office building, receptionist unlocks the door manually with a clicker button. The receptionist sits at the front end of the office and there are two desk areas behind receptionist for additional working space. The building has six offices, four are occupied by staff, each with a keypad required for entry, another office is used as a private visitation room, and the other as an additional meeting space. There is a staff lounge located at the back end of the office which is also used for staff meetings. There is a storage closet that contains food and supplies for clients if needed, and two key lock boxes for client and staff keys. To the left side of the hallway there is an additional hallway where two all gender bathrooms are located, one bathroom is for clients and the other has is staff only. At the back end of the building there is an additional point of entry by the handicapped designated parking and is wheelchair accessible. Client files are confidential and locked in filing cabinets in reception area. Additional files waiting to be scanned are located in the locked storage closet. There are four locked mailboxes outside each staff office that can be used to temporary store client files when staff is out. Emergency Disaster Plan and foster youth bill of rights is posted in the reception waiting area. An exit interview was conducted with facility representative, and a copy of the report was provided.

On July 13, 2021 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zeyda Loera conducted a Pre-licensing inspection visit of the facility. LPA met Randy Martin, CEO/Administrator. This Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) will share the same suite with Covenant Community Services and Covenant Coffee. Currently, the THPP office is staffed by one (1) CEO/Administrator, (1) Manager of Operations, (1) Administrator Assistant, As soon as, Covenant is licensed one (1) Social Work and one (1) Case Management will be hired. LPA completed a tour of the THPP's administrative office. The office is conveniently located for the public. LPA observed individual office for the CEO/Administrator. Manager of Operations and Administrator Assistant are sharing an office. The social worker and case management will have workspace in a common space. There is large conference room, small conference room and copy/storage room. The THPP participant records will be filed in a locked filing cabinet in the copy room and the THPP employee records will be filed in a locked cabinet in the Manager of Operations/ Administrator Assistant office. The THPP will have available computers and printers for participants' use. This THPP will use Remote Site models to place non-minor dependent (NMD) participants. Currently, the program has identify an available apartment with four (4) apartment units. Each unit has two (2) bedrooms and one (1) bathroom. A copy of the lease agreement and a sample floor plan was provided. The THPP will complete and sign a Certificate of Compliance for each THPP participant living unit, as defined in Section 86001(c)(2), that verifies that the participant living unit meets the requirements of the Health and Safety Code Section 1501(b)(5). (Ref. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Article 3, Section 86030.5.) The THPP has not identified any host families at this time. The applicant will notify the Department once host families are identified. LPA concluded the visit at 1:20 PM. A signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

Currently the THPP has no non-minor dependents (NMD) in placement. THPP participant records will be kept in steel filing cabinets located in the file room which is kept locked at all times. The THPP personnel records are kept upstairs in the administrator's office. The administrative office has telephone service at all times. facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN & FAMILIES SVCS
narrative:
On June 16, 2022 at 12:37pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Crittenton Services for Children and Family Services for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Kendra Tankersley -Davis, Program Director who granted access into the administrative office and together a tour was conducted. The Administrative Office is located at 2939 Pacific Commerce Dr. Rancho Dominguez, CA 90221. The Facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement-Plus Foster Care (THP+FC) services to Non-Minor Dependents up to thirty (30) participants ages 18-21 years of age. There are currently seven (7) participants in placement. The office is set up as follows: This is a two-story office space. This office is used for Participants, Administrator, Case Managers, and for the THPP for NMD program. First floor: Has a lobby/sitting area which includes a reception area. Reception area is equipped with eight (8) sofa chairs, love seat, coffee table, and two (2) end tables. Access to this area is gained via card entry. There are four (4) supply closets, four (4) bathrooms, two (2) conference rooms, meeting rooms, staff break room, staff offices, and chart room. All bathrooms are clean and sanitary. Hot water tested within a safe temperature range. The chart room is also accessed via keycard entry and contains several file cabinets secured with padlocks. First Aid kit had tweezers, scissors, and thermometer. All regulation fire extinguishers were fully charged and operable. All smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors tested audible. Second floor: Has two (2) bathrooms, several staff offices, training room, and clinical offices. All bathrooms are clean and sanitary. Hot water tested within a safe temperature range. Continued on LIC 809-C

COVID 19 signage and office policies were posted on the main door and throughout the building. Additionally, there was hand sanitizer and hand washing station. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements were met. LPA will review staff records and conduct staff interviews on a later date. LPA advised Program Director of email address to submit Special Incident Reports (SIR’s). Program Director stated staff and client files are kept in the corporate office in Fullerton, CA. LPA advised Program Director that files must be made available for inspection at the facility. LPA also advised that a written request must be made to Community Care Licensing if the licensee wishes to keep the files at the corporate office in Fullerton. LPA will review client records and conduct unit site inspections on a later date. Program Director advised all participant housing is in Buena Park and Anaheim. LPA advised Program Director of Licensing Fees of $908.00 due by August 8, 2022. No deficiencies were cited at the time of inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Program Director.

facility_name: CRITTENTON SERVICES FOR CHILDREN & FAMILIES SVCS
narrative:
On August 13, 2024, at 2:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Dear, Justine Armstrong and (LPM), Licensing Program Manager, Bernice Karnsrithong made an unannounced visit to Crittenton Services for Children and Family Services located at 2939 Pacific Commerce Dr. Rancho Dominguez, CA 90221, for the purpose of conducting an annual required Inspection. The Facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP+FC) services to Non-Minor Dependents, up to thirty (30) participants ages18-21 years of age. There are currently (7), seven participants in placement. First floor: A tour of the facility was conducted and inspected all emergency evacuation procedures. The lobby/sitting area has a reception area with eight (8) sofa chairs, love seat, coffee table, and two (2) end tables. Access to this area is gained via card entry. There are four (4) supply closets, four (4) full bathrooms, two (2) conference rooms, meeting rooms, staff break room, staff offices, and chart room. All bathrooms, (2), two, are clean and sanitary. The facility has several file cabinets secured by padlocks, and there are adequate amount of First- Aid kits that are available throughout the floor. All fire extinguishers, smoke/ carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. Two (2) Client files and two (2) staff files were reviewed however, no client(s) present during the inspection. Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward attempted to conduct the Required 2 year inspection. LPA was unable to reach the administrator, Jessica St. Paul. However the suite receptionist did contact Ms. St.Paul and relayed to LPA the message that Ms. Paul was ill and unable to come to the office. Ms. Paul also stated that there was no other staff that could assist with the inspection. The facility is being cited under inspection authority 86044(c)

LPA attempted to conduct the 2 year inspection. The suite receptionist ( not an employee of C.H.A.I.N Reaction) telephoned Administrator Getro Elize. Mr. Elize stated that he was at a doctor's appointment but could meet with me later in the day. I informed him that I would meet with him later in the week.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Mr. Getro Elize, program administrator, to conduct the required 2 year inspection. This inspection began at 10:00 AM. This is a THPP/NMD program that operates on the remote model. There are currently 4 units that are under renovation. Each unit has 2 bedrooms. There are currently no clients in placement. Mr. Elize was reminded to submit Certificates of Compliance for all housing units when they are ready to be inhabited. There are currently no social workers or social work supervisors. However a social work supervisor is in the final stages of being hired. LPA observed that there is no dedicated space for client privacy during interviews and visitations. The agency is currently operating out of a single office within a suite of offices. LPA also observed that client and staff records are kept in locked storage as required.. Employee files were reviewed. The licensee was requested to submit the qualifications of the administrator to the Department for approval by 03/10/23. The licensee was cited under Title 22 Section 86087.1(a) for failure to provide space dedicated to private client interviews This concludes the required 2 year inspection.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward conducted an investigation of the above allegations. LPA interviewed Clients #1, #2 and #3 and reviewed their written statements. LPA Jones-Steward also interviewed Staff #1. LPA Deborah Lee interviewed Program Manager Rickia Egans and Staff #1. A copy of the internal investigation, social worker's report and safety plans were all reviewed. Based on a review of the available evidence and due to inconsistent stories from the involved parties, LPA Jones-Steward was not able to substantiate that Staff #1 requested to shower in the clients' apartment or that Staff #1 entered the clients' living quarters inappropriately. Therefore both allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated.

narrative: On 12/18/24 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at the Dasiy's House administrative office and conducted an unannounced inspection regarding a case management-other inspection. During the course of the inspection LPA and LPM requested to review client files but were provided incomplete physical files and could not review the electronic files.LPA and LPM also requested to review the staff file but they were not availible for review. Licensee was cited in violation for Personnel Records 86066 and Non-Minor Dependant Records 86270. Exit Interview completed with Administrator David Egans. A copy of this report was given to Administrator David Egans.

On 4/22/24 at 10:44 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen made an unannounced visit to Daisy's House Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for the purpose of conducting aAnnual/Random inspection visit. LPA met with David Egans, THPP Administrator and toured the administrative office. Applicant is utilizing an office space at the above address as the administrative office. The office space is a private suite with one desks . LPA also observe one file cabinet and a printer in the office. The file cabinet is utilized to store the participants and staff records. LPA requested and received a copy of the staff and client roster. LPA reviewed staff and client files. LPA will return to conduct a physical plant inspection at the Housing Units. A copy of this report was given to the Administrator. Exit Interview Completed. No deficiencies cited.

On 4/29/24 at 10:19 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen made an unannounced visit to Daisy's House Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) living units at 5736 Aldama St and 5101 Martin St. for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Random inspection visit. LPA met with Mariya Libman THPP Social Work Supervisor (SWS), and toured the housing units. LPA conducted a physical inspection of four of the living units. Details recorded on LIC-812. LPA also conducted staff and client interviews, recorded on LIC-812's. LPA requested a copy of the Disaster training and facility sketch, which SWS will email to him. SWS will also email LPA a picture of the smoke detector with a new battery. A copy of this report was given to the Social Work Supervisor. Exit Interview Completed. No deficiencies cited.

On 8/20/25 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith conducted an informal office meeting with Daisy's House Administrator David Egans and Mrs. Egans. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss CCL concerns. The following topics were discussed: The Complaint Investigation 12/16/24: client smoking and alcohol use on the premises Care and Supervision: Minor being left unsupervised,possible need for increased staff supervision Reporting Requirements: Law Enforcement involvement and non client breaking a window, missing incident reports NMD Violating THPP Contract: consequences for NMD when violating contract Staff and Client Files: Personnel and NMD records are incomplete and not made available during CCL site visits, updating Plan of Operation Licensee informed LPA and LPM that there was a dispute between a tenant and the owner, but CCL informed Licensee that we had concerns regarding compliance to regulations regarding the NMD's smoking and using alcohol on the premises.Licensee conformed that there was an incident with an NMD's girlfriend breaking a window and a Law enforcement report was made. CCL reminded Licensee to report these incidents to CCL as they are reportable incidents. CCL informed provider that they should conduct internal investigations with clients and staff to determine whether there is a violation of the plan of operation or CCL regulations. Provider was also informed to document consequences and make sure it is accessible to CCL when NMD's violate their contract.

Although it is undetermined whether the NMD's child was left unsupervised there is a possibility of a lack of supervision during the times that the client was smoking and drinking in the car port. CCL suggests that case managers conduct meetings at different times throughout the week and more frequently to verify compliance to NMD THPP contract. Licensee stated that they provide staff and clients with drug and alcohol abuse awareness resources, this should be recorded in client's files if client has a history of substance abuse. Provider informed CCL that clients sign logs when attending the provided life skills training's. Case Managers conduct face to face case management visits weekly, to preform environment checks and to provide life skills training. This documentation must be made available to CCL. CCL received the revised Plan of Operation and will follow up with the provider within 30 day to determine whether the revisions meet licensing requirements. CCL will move forward with the capacity increase. Provider must submit personnel report LIC 500 showing updated supervision/work schedule for updated capacity. Exit Interview Completed and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Multiple staff and client interviews stated that there was no consumption of alcohol in or around the home by the client. Witness testimony and video evidence showed the client drinking around the home and in the carport under the home. The facilities program statement only prevents alcohol consumption in the home. Facilities internal investigation did not find any evidence of alcohol consumption in the home. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and video evidence, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore, the allegation of the “Licensee did not prevent underage youth from consuming alcohol in the home” has been found to be unsubstantiated. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff and client interviews stated that smoking and drug use of ant kind is not happening in the home. Witness testimony and video evidence showed the client smoking around the home and in the carport under the home. The facilities program statement only prevents drug use in the home. Facilities internal investigation did not find any evidence of drug use in the home. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and video evidence, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore, the allegation that the “Licensee did not address illegal drug use in the home” is found to be unsubstantiated. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff and client interviews stated that while there have been calls to law enforcement because of the actions of clients in the homes, it has not led to any charges or arrests, and it was actually the neighbor who called the police on the clients. Witness testimony shared that law enforcement has been called multiple times due to clients verbally and physically fighting with each other. LPA observed a video of Law enforcement at the complex trying to talk to one of the clients in their home due to a noise complaint. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff are not following proper reporting requirements” has been found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report.
investigation_findings: 13On 3/28/25 at 10:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at Daisys House office and met with Administrator David Egans for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff and client interviews stated that there has not been any fights between the clients in care at the homes, and therefore nothing for the Licensee to address. A witness interview shared that there have been verbal and physical fights between the clients. LPA observed a video of a person smashing the windows of the home of a client, and another video of a group of people, including clients, yelling at each other in the courtyard of the housing complex late at night. LPA was unable to determine if the Licensee failed to intervene after those incidents. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has not been met, therefore the allegation of “Staff did not prevent inappropriate interaction between children in care” is found to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.

Witness testimony shared that law enforcement has been called multiple times due to clients verbally and physically fighting with each other. LPA observed a video of Law enforcement at the complex trying to talk to one of the clients in their home due to a noise complaint. investigation_findings: 13On08/20/25 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith facilitated a informal office meeting with Administrator David Egans from Daisys House. LPA delivered the complaint findings regarding the above allegations. Allegation: "Licensee did not address fighting between youth placed in the home" LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff and client interviews stated that there has not been any fights between the clients in care at the homes, and therefore nothing for the Licensee to address. A witness interview shared that there have been verbal and physical fights between the clients. LPA observed a video of a person smashing the windows of the home of a client, and another video of a group of people, including clients, yelling at each other in the courtyard of the housing complex late at night. LPA was unable to determine if the Licensee failed to intervene after those incidents. LPA was not able to determine which specific client or which of the clients' guests/friends was participating in the fights.

narrative: Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and video evidence, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation of the “Licensee did not prevent underage youth from consuming alcohol on the premises” has been found to be substantiated. Allegations: “Licensee did not prevent illegal drug use on the premises.” LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. Staff and client interviews stated that smoking and drug use of any kind is not happening in the home. The Administrator stated that the Facilities internal investigation did not find any evidence of drug use on the premises. Other witness testimony and video evidence showed the client smoking around the premises, specifically in the carport under the home. LPA observed multiple video evidence of a client smoking in the carport on multiple occasions. The videos clearly show the client smoking either using a bong or a joint while in the carport under and around the housing unit. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and video evidence, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation that the “Licensee did not prevent illegal drug use on the premises” is found to be substantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On08/20/25 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith facilitated a informal office meeting with Administrator David Egans from Daisys House. deficiencies.description:
Responsability for Providing Care & Supervision:
"The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the needs of a nonminor dependent."
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on multiple video evidence of the client smoking drugs & drinking alcohol in the carport at the living unit, the licensee did not provide adequate care and supervision to ensure that clients were not smoking drugs at the housing units.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will read and review ILS Section 86278. Administrator will submit a written plan of how they will ensure that regular supervision is provided at the remote sites. Adminsitrator will submit a written plan to show how drug and alcohol abuse awarness help was given to the clients.

narrative:
On December 17, 2021 at 8:49 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA) Anastasia Flores, Charmaine Linley and Jessica Rubio arrived and were greeted by Daughters of Love, Transitional Housing Placing Program (THPP), Facility Director, Medina Pina. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing inspection of the facility. At 09:04 AM, LPA’s began tour of the facility with Medina Pina for a pre-license of a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The corporate office is in the process of being obtained by February 1, 2021. There are five bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPAs observed a television in both living rooms and furnished with couches and chairs. The facility will have locks placed on the bedroom doors prior to accepting clients and each client will have their own entrance code to their rooms. The administration will keep a master key in case of emergencies. The common areas for residents are the kitchen, two sitting areas, living room with ample sitting space, television and a fireplace with proper coverings for safety. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The laundry area had a washer and dryer. The facility has ample storage space in the garage. The garage will be emptied prior to accepting clients. The windows had blinds for privacy. LPA Flores informed Ms. Pina the screens on the windows will need to be replaced prior to obtaining clients. The exit in the backyard has some debris which will be removed by 12/31/2021 Downstairs; 1 bedroom with a full-size bed, dresser to be utilized by NMD. Upstairs; Master bedroom with a king size bed, dresser, walk in closet and master bathroom for NMD, One bedroom with a full-size bed, dresser, closet door needs to be replaced for NMD. One bedroom with a twin-size bed, dresser, no closet. One bedroom with a full-size bed, dresser, and closet (continued on next page)

LPA’s observed there are clean mattresses, pillows, and beds are in good repair. The facility has plenty of linens. The residents will be given chores. It was discussed the possibility of assigning meal duties to clients in care to assist with the independent living activities. Residents are allowed to create a list for specified groceries and go shopping with the Facility Manager weekly. The following were discussed: During the meeting component II and component III were discussed. LPA’s discussed Post Licensing Visits that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations; personal fingerprint requirements, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA’s communicated about LPA’s responsibility; Special Incident reporting requirements, for LIC624, CC: internal procedures, AB388 reporting form LE624E. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a THPP/NMD facility. License will expire one year from effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 10 clients. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. It was discussed the possibility of expansion for the facility license in the future as stated in the program statement. LPA provided applicant with a copy of the special incident report and provided applicant the email address and directions on reporting incidents to Community Care Licensing Riverside Office. It was discussed that the client files and staff files need to be at a location off site in a corporate office, to be utilized for staff trainings, counseling for clients and meetings. Original Board of Directors signature pages need to be obtained. LIC309, treasurers last name to be corrected, Criminal background clearances, applications, for all employees associated with the facility. Educational records, transcripts, for Shelly McCall, Medina Pina and Toni Piper to be obtained. Pages 65-66 part 1 of the Plan of Operation (room arrangements) to be corrected. No other plan of operation updates is needed prior to issuing provisional license. An exit interview was conducted with facility representatives.

On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio arrived to verify corrections requested on the Pre-licensing visit made on 12/17/2021. LPA verified the debris in the backyard and garage had been cleared. Screens on the windows were replaced except for four (4) in the front room of the facility. Administrator will send LPA pictures with these screens replaced. LPA also obtained requested forms.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio arrived to verify the office location of the facility. The office is located at 468 W Fifth St Ste 101, San Bernardino, CA 92401. LPA met with Administrator Medina Pina who granted access to the office. The office consists of a reception area, one office and one conference room. Administrator provided a copy of the lease as well. LPA advised that the client and staff files should be kept in a locked file cabinet in a locked office. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator.

On November 2, 2022 at 9:00 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Toni Castillo made an unannounced post-licensing visit. There was no one at the facility. LPA made a phone call to Program Director Medina Pina who came to facility to meet LPA and grant access into the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an unannounced post-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The facility was assessed both inside and out with the Program Director. Currently the THPP has zero NMD placement's. There are no remote apartments for this THPP. Both administrative office and home is licensed as the THPP. The THPP facility is located in Riverside County. The facility is located in a residential establishment. This is a residential home with an administrative office, The facility has five bedrooms The common areas for residents are the kitchen, two sitting areas, living room with ample sitting space, television and games. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The laundry area has a washer and dryer. The facility has ample storage space in the garage. The facility has restrooms for NMD use. THPP license was posted in the entry area. Due to there being no NMD placement's LPA did not review any client or staff files. Based on the post licensing inspection on this date, the THPP is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted with Program Director Medina Pina and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On October 3rd, 2023 at 10:55 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Emina Preciado and Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera, conducted a random annual visit at Daughter's of Love, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA's met with Administrator, Medina Pina, who granted access to the office, which is a retail business establishment. The Administrative office is located at: 468 W. Fifth Street Suite 101, San Bernardino, CA 92401. The facility address is incorrect as is listed as one of the remote cite. The office consists of a reception area, two offices and one conference room. The facility has Wi-Fi accessibility. The restroom are located inside the building. The facility currently has four participants in one remote site, the remote site is within two hours from the office location. This remote cite is in the city of San Jacinto. During the visit, LPA's reviewed four participant files. All four participants files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. Staff files were not reviewed during this inspection, as they were not available. LPA's will return at a later date to review the four staff files. Based on record reviews and observation, the facility is not in compliance and is being cited under, CCR 86066(a) Personnel Records. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of this report along with LIC 809-D page was provided to facility representative.

narrative: On April 5, 2024 at 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Emina Preciado and Rachel Vanegas, conducted a pre-licensing inspection at Daughter's of Love, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA's met with Case Manager, Maura Benigni-Kline, who granted access into the office. The purpose of the pre-licensing inspection was due to the administrative office relocating. The office is located in a two story retail business establishment at: 468 W. Fifth Street Suite 101, San Bernardino, CA 92401. The administrative office is on the first floor and consists of: a resource center, reception area, one staff office, and one conference room. The facility has a working telephone, Wi-Fi accessibility, and a private area for confidential interviews. The restrooms are located inside the building on the first floor. Participant and personnel records are stored in a secure area, a locked filing cabinet. The facility currently has seven participants and has two remote sites. The remote sites are within two hours from the office location in the cities of Beaumont and San Jacinto. Based on observation and record review, the facility meets the regulatory requirements and is ready for licensor at the conclusion of the visit. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was provided to facility representative.

facility_name: DAVID & MARGARET YOUTH AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Raymond Wu and Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Supervising Social Worker Wayne Wolcott. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an Annual Required inspection. David and Margaret's THP+FC office is located in Whitney Building inside the main campus. The facility is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care services to non-minor dependents. The agency's THP+FC program uses remote single housing units to place Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) participants. A tour of the office was conducted. LPAs observed the following: The THPP+FC facility has a lobby area with a table and two couches. The table has a computer which is for client use or intern use. Next to the lobby is a supply closet and a bathroom. There is an office for the supervising social worker with a desk, computer and telephone and also has two locking file cabinets which is used to store the client files. There are two social worker offices with computers and telephones. Each of these offices houses two social workers. There is an office for the therapist and a Session room which is used for one on one sessions with participants. There is an office for an Employment Coach with a desk, computer and filing cabinet. There is an office for the program support staff and the housing navigator. There is an office for the Program Manager with a desk, computer, telephone. The facility currently has 14 transitional housing placement participants ages 18-21 years. There is a total of seven (7) staff; two (2) of which are full time social workers. The agency is in compliance the social worker ratio. LPAs reviewed 7 staff files and 7 participant files. A review of the staff files indicated that all facility staff have received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. During today's visit, no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations were observed. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this form was emailed to the Licensee.

narrative:
On May 03, 2024 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles and Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an unannounced annual/random inspection to the Transitional Housing Placement Program for Non Minor Dependents facility. LPAs met with Senior Director of Placement Programs, Marissa Scholefield. PHYSICAL PLANT The facility license is posted in a prominent location. All participant records are maintained in a secure area or locked file cabinets in the administrative office. The administrative office has telephone service on the premises. OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS The facility maintains a register of participants available upon request. The facility is currently operating within licensing regulations. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS The facility has an emergency and disaster plan for the THPP NMD participants. The emergency plan shall include emergency information, instructions, and telephone numbers, including a 24-hour emergency number for the licensee and the participant’s responsible party.

STAFF RECORDS There is a total of thirteen (13) staff; seven (7) of which are full time social workers and one (1) social worker supervisor. Staff records are available upon request. The agency is in compliance with the social worker ratio. Senior Director of placement program meets the education and experience requirements, completed the required training, file contains the Statement acknowledging requirement to report child abuse, fingerprint, and child abuse index check clearances and current with CPR and first aid. CLIENT RECORDS The facility currently has forty-six (46) transitional housing placement participants ages 18-21 years old. The facility ensured that the Transitional Independent Living Plan/Needs and Services Plan is signed by the NMD, the THPP Director or SW personnel and the agency responsible for placement. The facility ensured the participants record are maintained locked on site in the THPP office. LPAs reviewed five (5) personnel records, five (5) participant’s record (refer to Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 05/03/24) and interviewed one (1) staff. During today's visit, no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations were observed. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report, LIC 9102 and LIC 811 was provided to the Senior Director.

facility_name: DAVID & MARGARET YOUTH AND FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
...page 2 Complainant was interviewed on July 23, 2024 C1 was interviewed on July 30, 2024. TSW was interviewed on May 16, 2025. Director interviewed on May 19, 2025 The investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that the placement was in disrepair and staff did not ensure that placement was free of pests. Review of documents showed that a youth moved into an apartment provided and maintained by the THPP on June 21, 2024. Shortly after moving into the apartment, youth noticed fleas in the apartment. Youth advised THPP about the fleas and requested carpet to be cleaned. In confidential interviews it was revealed that the youth sent a picture to the Transitional Social Worker showing fleas in the apartment and on the rug. TSW said that there were fleas in the picture received, however it was not determined if the fleas were dead or alive. LPA observed documentation that the THPP treated the apartment two (2) times before youth moved in. It was revealed that there were fleas and bugs on the carpet. TSW said the THPP treated the apartment for fleas and changed the carpet after youth complained. Youth could not stay at the apartment due to the fleas biting. Youth stayed at a relative’s home, until the issue was resolved or relocated to a new apartment. In other interviews, the THPP was not made aware that the bathtub would not drain. LPA observed documentation showing THPP treated the apartment for pests prior to youth moving into the apartment. THPP made attempts to fix the issues brought to their attention. Pest control treatment occurred on May 7, 2024, and May 14, 2024. Apartment professionally cleaned on June 17, 2024. Youth moved into apartment on June 21, 2024. Pest control treatment on June 24, 2024, and June 26, 2024. Carpet washed June 27, 2024. THPP moved youth into a new apartment on July 11, 2024. Continued on page 3

page 3 Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were provided to Director. Exit interview was conducted.

LPA Rosas conducted interviews with staff, and pertinent parties regarding to allegations. On 02/09/2022, LPA Rosas conducted a facility inspection to the administrative office where facility denied the allegations. Persons interviewed stated, that living units had landlines but were removed as residents are given cell phones upon admissions to the program and residents prefer cell phones for communication. The facility reported, they facilitate residents obtaining low-income “Obama” cell phone services. Facility reported, they were charging fines for property damages to teach residents about taking care of personal property but stopped during COVID-19 pandemic. On 07/14/2022, Divinity Prophet organization, Los Angeles Department of Children and Family Services, and Community Care Licensing Division conducted office meeting with facility to discuss allegations and facility concerns. Facility reported, they are in the process of obtaining landline telephone lines for all remote sites (living units) and had remove charging fines for residents. On 10/13/2022, LPA Rosas conducted annual inspection and inspected four (4) remove sites located in Moorpark, CA. LPA Rosas, during the inspection of the 3 out 4 units did not have telephone services (landlines) in the living units. On 10/20/2022, LPA Rosas continued annual inspection and conducted resident file review and found receipt for property fine charge. LPA Rosas obtained copies of Divinity Prophet and Associates THP+FC Intake package that stated the following, Section- Maintenance and Repair Policy states that residents are responsible for any repairs that need to be performed when their occupancy is over such as broken windows, stained carpet, or restore damage furniture. Section- Policy for Care of Furnishings states that if found that participants have caused the damage to the furnishings, they may be fined. In addition, Utilities and Telephone Policy section, states that all residents will have access to landline telephone services to make and receive confidential telephone calls. On 02/09/2023, LPA Rosas received a copy of Verizon monthly telephone statement. The monthly statement showed remote sites (living units) phone numbers listed as active. Based on information gathered from interviews, record review, field inspections, office visit and remote site inspection conducted on 10/13/2022, the allegation is substantiated, which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Results from the Department’s investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. The Department has concluded, based on the preponderance of the evidence obtained during this investigation, that the allegation of Admission Agreement, and Personal Rights are substantiated. narrative: On 8/16/2023, at 11:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at Divinity Prophet, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Thomas Chavira II, Program Administrator in response to a Special Incident Report submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 8/14/2023. The incident, reports in part, on 8/12/2023, a participant was stabbed at the THPP’s remote site by another participant resulting in the death of one participant. The participant who committed the stabbing was subsequently arrested as a result [See confidential names form LIC811; dated 8/16/2023]. During this inspection, LPA Martin informed the incident has been referred to CCL Investigations Branch, Investigator Dennis Seng. Upon completion of the investigation, the investigation findings will be discussed. LPA Martin requested and obtained the following documents from facility and Participant files: Participant/Client Roster, Personnel Report (Schedule) LIC500, facility staff job description, Participant needs and services plans and transitional independent living plans (TILP), as well as Admission Agreements for subject participants. The incident requires further investigation. Upon completion, the Department's findings will be issued and discussed. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Program Administrator .

The office is located on the second floor of a business office building and is set up as follows: Administration office is a three (3) room office with reception area and outdoor patio. The Program Supervisor office is equipped with a desk and lock file cabinets. There is a door from the main office space and Program Supervisor office that leads to a roof patio. In the business office building there are two conference rooms that licensee states are available to conduct private interviews. Staff records are maintained in the Administrative Office inside locked cabinets and the client records are maintained in the Social Workers office space inside locked file cabinets.
