narrative: On 4/9/2023, at 3:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at Divinity Prophet, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA Martin later spoke with Thomas Chavira II, Program Administrator via telephone to deliver findings concerning Special Incident Report submitted to CCL on 8/14/2023. The incident reported in part, on 8/12/2023, a participant was stabbed at the THPP’s remote site by another participant resulting in the death of one participant. The participant who committed the stabbing was subsequently arrested as a result. CCL Investigator, Douglas Real conducted the investigation consisting of confidential interviews with facility residents, staff members and contacts with the Ventura Police Department. The investigation revealed residents live independently in their own residences and Facility Case Managers conduct weekly visits to the Participants homes to monitor and assess Participant progress as well as provide guidance and assistance with independent living. Participants #1 (P1) and #2 (P2) resided in the same apartment and their case manager visited both participants two days prior to the incident leading to P1’s death. Records reviewed revealed P1 resided in the residence for ten days prior to the incident and no issues, problems, or safety concerns were reported to the case manager by either participant. Confidential statements revealed no apparent problems or issues with the care provided by the facility or its employees. Statements obtained further deny claims of neglect or lack of supervision resulted in the stabbing death of P1 by P2. Based on the statements gathered, and records reviewed the Department has determined there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred or that neglect, or lack of supervision resulted in the stabbing death of P1 by P2. The Department’s finding is therefore determined Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies per California Code of Regulations cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was provided to Program Administrator by email for signature.

On 6/24/2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Kim Hayward Glover who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an announced pre-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) Sub Office. The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator at 12:05pm. Presently, the THPP NMD has requested a capacity of 48 NMD’s who will be placed in remote site apartments. Administrator was advised the apartments must be located within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area, two meeting/conference rooms, three case managers offices, three Administrative offices, locked storage area, two interview rooms, two bathrooms, and a kitchen area. In addition, there are five computer stations for the NMD’s located in the reception area. The administration office was equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. According to Administrator, all participant files will be stored in locked cabinets within the case managers offices. The staff files will be located in a locked cabinet within the Administrators office. Currently the THPP is only staffed with the Administrator, all additional positions will be hired after obtaining the CCL license. During this inspection Component III for THPP NMD was conducted by LPA Zirbes. During this component, LPA discussed Post Licensing inspection that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations; NMD regulations, personal fingerprint requirements, associations, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA informed the Administrator, about the reporting requirements specifically, AB388 and LIC 624 LE. Furthermore, Provider Information Notices (PIN), Resource Guides and the process for designating a new facility Administrator was reviewed. Licensee was advised that this pre-licensing report and application will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are licensed as a THPP NMD. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Kim Hayward Glover and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On August 8, 2022 at 9:10 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera met with Administrator Kim Glover who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an announced post-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) Sub Office. The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator. Currently the THPP has twenty-one NMD’s placement's and fifteen remote site apartments. The remote apartments were all within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area, two meeting/conference rooms, three case managers offices, three Administrative offices, locked storage area, two interview rooms, two bathrooms, and a kitchen area. In addition there is a computer lab and there are motivational signs, along with an educational and employment resource area. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. LPA reviewed seven NMD files. The files were stored in locked cabinets within the case managers offices. LPA also reviewed all staff files which was a total of four. The staff files were in a locked cabinet in the Administrators office. Based on the annual inspection on this date, the THPP is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Kim Glover and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On June 14th 2023, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado arrived at Divinity Prophet, Riverside, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA's met with Program Administrator, Shari Wolvek, who granted access to the facility. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an unannounced required two year inspection for the THPP for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD's). The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator. Currently the THPP has twenty five NMD placement's and nineteen remote site apartments. The remote apartments were all within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area, one meeting/conference room, three case managers offices, three Administrative offices, locked storage area, two interview rooms, two bathrooms, and a kitchen area. In addition there is a computer lab and there are motivational signs, along with an educational and employment resource area. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. LPA’s reviewed six non-minor dependent files. All files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. Facility provided a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. LPA's reviewed all staff files which was a total of three. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. The staff files were in a locked cabinet in the Administrators office. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. Based on observation and record review, the annual inspection on this date, the THPP is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator, Shari Wolvek.

On January 17, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that facility staff are engaging in human trafficking, facility staff are supplying client(s) with drugs, and facility staff do not ensure that clients are provided with a safe environment. CCL specifically received a report identifying S1 as the alleged perpetrator of these allegations. Regarding the allegations that S1 was engaging in human trafficking, the department received inconsistent information regarding whether S1 was engaging in human trafficking while C1 was in placement. There was no supportive evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred or other known witness to the allegation. LPA did receive information through a confidential interview that S1 was observed taking clients out of the facility overnight to unknown locations. Confidential interview could not provide further details about the incident or whether these overnights with clients were linked to human trafficking. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation. Other confidential interviews denied that S1 was engaging in human trafficking. Regarding the allegations that staff are supplying client(s) with drugs and that facility staff do no ensure that clients are provided with a safe environment. SI, Jackson received inconsistent information whether S1 was supplying clients with drugs (marijuana) and whether S1 was providing a safe environment for clients in care. while other confidential interviews stated that the allegation was true. The department received inconsistent information regarding the allegations. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff are engaging in human trafficking, facility staff are supplying client(s) with drugs, and facility staff do not ensure that clients are provided with a safe environment, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Program Administrator, Tonnette Ellis.
investigation_findings: 13On October 31, 2023, at 12:17 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met with Divinity Prophet Transitional Housing Program (THP) Program Administrator, Tonnette Ellis to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegations. On January 24, 2023, at 1:01 PM LPA Daniel Mena initiated the investigation at the facility and collected pertinent documents to assist with the investigation process. LPA Mena informed the facility that Special Investigator (SI) Charlotte Jackson would be leading the investigation. SI, Jackson conducted interviews with three clients (C1, C2, C3), three staff members (S1, S2, S3) and a witness. LPA Urena conducted interviews with a County Social Worker (CSW), and continued interviews with three staff members (S1, S2, S3) and a client (C2). LPA made several attempts to re-interview C1 but was unsuccessful. LPA also attempted to interview client #4 (C4) however, due C4 to living out of state and last known contact information not valid an interview with C4 could not be conducted. Therefore, no additional information was obtained.

narrative: On December 9, 2020 at 10:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White conducted a Case Management - Incident tele-visit at the above location in response to an Incident Report. LPA spoke with the Program Administrator, Kim Glover to discuss the Incident in order to investigate possible Neglect/Lack of Supervision. On December 8, 2020 Community Care Licensing (CCL) On Duty Worker received a call from the program' Administrator stating that Client #1 informed them that while she along with three other people were in a car waiting at a red light at the intersection of King Blvd and Western in Los Angeles, they heard gun shots. The Client reported that the gun fire grazed her head and struck the driver. The Client reported she does not know what happened to the driver because she was transported to California Hospital and she was released on 12/08/2020. During the tele-visit LPA interviewed the Program Administrator. LPA was informed Client #1's Case Manager conducted a wellness check on 12/08/2020 and attempted to obtain additional information, however Client #1 would provide any other information regarding the incident. LPA requested a copy of the SIR along with Client #1's Intake paperwork and TILT. LPA obtained contact information for Client #1, Client's Case Manager, and Client's Probation Officer. Additional interviews will be conducted at a later date. Based on the information gathered, further investigation is needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Program Administrator, Kim Glover for signature due to COVID -19 Public Health Crisis.

investigation_findings: 13On June 25, 2021 at 2:10 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to Divinity Prophet-Gardena THPP for the purpose of delivering findings on the on attached complaint investigation. LPA spoke to Office Manager, Dosalyn Smith and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation LPA interviewed pertinent parties, reviewed relevant information, and conducted a walk through of the unit. Staff denied the allegations. Staff said the unit is safe, that Child #1 was provided a new bed when she moved into the unit, and that Child #1 has not voiced any concerns about her roommate nor the area to staff. Staff stated there is also a Sheriff's and Probation Department located a few blocks from the unit. Child #1 stated she is fine living in unit, that she does not have any issues with her roommate, but said she could use a bigger bed because she is tall. Child #2 said she does not have multiple people come in and out of the unit, but said she does have a friend over every now and then. Based on information obtained this investigation is being closed

narrative: On September 14, 2021 at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced visit to the above location for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Incident visit in response to a Client Death. LPA met with Administrator, Tamara McKinstry. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a Law Enforcement Contact/Special Incident Report stating Client #1’s infant died the morning of 09/10/2021. The incident was reported to Administrator and staff went to the remote location to provide support to the client and gain additional information. During this visit, LPA reviewed Client #1’s file and obtained a statement from staff regarding the death of client’s infant and the actions taken by the staff following the notification of the incident. LPA was informed that Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department went to the location and took a report. LPA obtained police report number and copies of documents from Client #1’s file. Additionally, staff was advised to obtain and forward a copy of the death certificate to CCL once received. There was no evidence to support that staff violated any policies and procedures. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was left with staff.

On April 12, 2022, at 4:00 P.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kuliema Calloway conducted a Case Management - Deficiency inspection at Divinity Prophet-Gardena. During the course of the complaint investigation, for the complaint received on April 8, 2022, deficiencies were observed that did not fall into one of the allegations, which were made against the above-said facility. This complaint investigation revealed the following additional violations: 1) Responsibility for Providing care and Supervision: On 04/08/2022, during a physical plant walk-through of a participant’s (P3’s) apartment, LPA Calloway, and Licensing program Manager (LPM) Smith did not observe perishables or non-perishables in the kitchen, and the cabinets, refrigerator, and freezer were observed to be empty. 2) Food Service: On 04/08/2022, during a physical plant walk-through of a participant’s (P3’s) apartment, LPA Calloway, and LPM Smith did not observe appliances (pots, pans, dishes) or utensils in the living unit. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), the following deficiencies were observed and cited. (See LIC809-D) Exit interview conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Case Manager Supervisor (S1).

On April 27, 2022 at 9:03 AM Licensing Program Analyst, Kuliema Calloway and Licensing Program Manager, Lakescia Smith, made an unannounced visit for the purpose of a follow up Case Management- Deficiencies visit. LPA and LPM met with Tamara Perkins, Program Administrator for Divinity Prophet and informed Tamara that during a physical plant inspection on 4/8/2022, multiple compliance concerns were observed in Participants 1, 2 and 3's unit. However, the initial report did not address all compliance concerns. The following concerns were observed: Liquor bottles on top of the refrigerator and in a box on the floor in the kitchen. There were beer bottles and beer cans on the balcony in a box. The sliding glass door for P1's bedroom did not have a latch/lock or a screen. The participant was provided with a small, window lock to secure the door. In the bedroom for P2, the closet glass door has multiple cracks. LPA and LPM took several pictures of the deficiencies in the units. LPA requested and obtained copies of the maintenance request on 4/11/2022. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, Section 86022 (e) Plan of Operation. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights provided.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Meka Brown, Shari Wolvek & Deborah Smith to discuss the allegation that the facility did not provide a full crib for the newborn infant of Participant #1. LPA Jones-Steward previously spoke to Particiapant #1 and verified that the crib in her apartment has no mattress. Per Ms. Smith there was a full crib offered but Participant #1 did not want that crib so a mini-crib was purchased. However the mini-crib does not have a mattress and Ms. Smith has been unable to find one that fits. Ms. Smith, Ms. Wolvek and Ms. Brown stated that there will be a full crib or bassinet in place within a matter of hours. Based on the information gathered during this investigation the above allegation is substantiated. Subtantiated means that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met. Facility was cited under Title 22 86088(b)(1)

deficiencies.description:
Fixtures. Furniture, Equipment & Supplies
The licensee shall ensure that each THPP participant and his or her minor child(ren) are provided with household essentials ...All of the essential items above shall be age and developmental stage appropriate to the participants and his/her children as applicable. Based on interviews with the participant and staff it was determined that the facility failed to meet this requirement by not providing a crib with a mattress for the newborn infant of the participant
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Ms. Wolvek, Ms. Brown and Ms Smith stated that a full crib or bassinet will be provided by this afternoon and photographic proof will be submitted to the Department within 24 hours.

met_with: Meka Brown, Director of Programs, Licensed Care
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward completed the investgation of the above allegation. LPA spoke to the CEO of Divinity Prophet, the Probation Officer of Participant #1 and the orginal complainant. LPA also searched for SIR's regarding the departure of Participant #1 from the program. There were no SIRs found dor this matter. Per emailed statement provided by CEO Hope Ricks, an SIR was not submitted because Participantt #1 left the program on his own after notifying staff of his intent to do so. However, per Title 22 Section 86261(d) the licensee shall notify the Department when a non-minor dependent is discharged in accordance with Title 22, Section 86268.4(c)(1)(B). Based on the information obtained during this investigation, the allegation that the licensee did not follow proper discharge procedure is resolved as substantiated. A finding that an allegations is substantiated means that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirement
The licensee or THPP staff shall notify the licensing agency and the person or agency responsible for placing a nonminor dependent, such as a social worker or probation officer, when the nonminor dependent is discharged as specified in Section 86268.4, Removal or Discharge Procedures. The licensee failed to meet this requirement. Based on information gathered during this investigation, it was determined that the licensee did not report the discharge of Participant #1 to the Department.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a self-directed corrective action plan to detail how it will comply with the regulation to report when clients are discharged from the progeam.

narrative: The two toured units posed some physical plant concerns of a broken sliding door, cracked mirror, and front door panel damage. These concerns were cited and addressed during the initial visit. LPA was unable to justify rodents and expired food due to specific units not identified in the photos. Confidential interviews indicated that participants could leave their unit to go to work, school, and conduct personal business. Per staff interviews, the following was stated: Participants are required to notify case manager if they will be gone beyond a 24-hour period. Participants are required to work or be enrolled as a requirement of the program. The program was providing transportation prior to COVID but now encourages participants to take public transportation. Participants are responsible for purchasing their own hygiene products. The allegations stated minors are not provided allowance however, per client and staff interviews, an allowance is given every two weeks. There is no supporting evidence and it is unclear which clients did not receive an allowance. Per staff interviews, support was provided for budgeting and saving however, due to COVID it stopped and there isn’t a set date for it to return. While touring one of the units, LPA/LPM observed a participant asking for parenting and anger management classes and staff stated they would accommodate. The initial photos provided, were not dated nor did they identify which unit they were taken in. The concerns do not reflect in the allegations and the alleged allegations occurred two years ago. Based on review and analyzing all of the evidence, the LPA has found this complaint to be Unsubstantiated, meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the Case Mgr Supervisor and The Program Administrator Due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer.
investigation_findings: 13On June 29, 2022, at 10:45am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Enrique Hernandez, arrived at the facility for the purpose of concluding complaint findings of the investigation conducted by LPA Kuliema Callaway and LPM Lakescia Smith. LPA met with Deborah Smith Case Mgr Supervisor and Paisley Moore The Program Administrator at Divinity Prophet- Gardena. During the investigation, LPA Kuliema Calloway and LPM, Lakescia Smith reviewed documentary evidence, photos, toured two living units, and conducted confidential interviews. LPA and LPM attempted to tour three additional unit sites but were unsuccessful. One of the attempted sites in Carson had a lock box on the door. LPA contacted staff to inquire and they did not respond. Confidential interviews provided inconsistent statements and no witnesses to corroborate allegations. During the tour, there were no observations of drugs or dangerous objects however, LPA/LPM did observe empty liquor bottles in one of the units. Living units were observed to be clean, sanitary, and without odor. Continue on LIC9099-C

narrative: Although the allegations may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has determined that the allegations Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There are no deficiencies noted or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the Program Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On October 27, 2022 at 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to DIVINITY PROPHET-GARDENA to conclude the investigation on the above allegations. LPA met with the Program Administrator to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. During the investigation LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the allegations. Based on the interviews and statements obtained during the investigation process, the allegation cannot be corroborated because supporting evidence includes the following: The Licensee denied the allegations.LPA accessed and found discrepancy in the alleged victims’ statements. There is no evidence or witnesses to support that the facility “Staff did not afford a NMD privacy while in care and that staff mishandled a NMD while in care. Documented evidence and confidential interviews were congruent and confirmed that the youth obtain the proper allowances; that the staff followed provided proper protocol and directives when entering the participants unit and there were no witnesses present to confirm that the staff mishandled a NMD while in care.

met_with: Shari Wolvek, Director of Quality Assurance & Compliance
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Ms. Shari Wolvek to conduct the Required 2 year inspection. At this time, the facility is in the process of relocating, therefore most equipment is packed in anticipation of the move. There are currently no clients in placement. There is one social worker and one social worker supervisor on staff. There are no participant units associated to this license currently. LPA Jones-Steward discussed with Ms. Wolvek, the documents required for the relocation: LIC 200, LIC 610, LIC 999, LIC 500, a check to cover the relocation fee and a board resolution to approve the move. LPA Jones-Steward reviewed the staff files for the social worker and the social work supervisor. The social worker was found to not have the required Masters Degree. The facility was cited under Title 22 Section 86065.3 (e) and advised to submit an exception request to allow Staff #2 to work as a social worker.

met_with: Shari Wolveck, Director of Quality Assurance
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Ms. Wolvek and other personnel to observe the living units with which DCFS expressed concerns. LPA and Ms. Wolvek visited three units. LPA observed that in Unit #1 there were no current deficiencies. However in Unit 2, the shower door was off track and one of the the two ovens did not work, In Unit #3, the wall heater did not work and the carpet in the hallway was loose and torn. LPA observed that there were no land line telephone service in the units. However all clients had personal cell phones, Ms. Wolvek stated that the organization is in the process of providing land line service to all units. LPA discussed the deficiencies with Ms, Wolvek and issued a plan of correction,

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Ms. Brown and Ms Wolvek to discuss previously resolved complaint #34-CR-20220204130028. LPA explained that one of the findings within the complaint would be changed from unfounded to substantiated upon review by management. LPA also discussed the appeal process with Ms. Brown and Ms. Wolvek.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA spoke with Meka Brown, Shari Wolvek, Diana Flaggs and Maurissa Mitchem. However no specific client was named as having had the above inappropriate fines levied against them. Without such information the allegations cannot be substantiated nor negated. Therfore they are resolved as unsubstantiated.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. Per staff and client interviews, the facility does provide cell phones for the participants but not landlines. Per staff interviews cell phones were provided in lieu of landlines at the request of social workers and probation department. Per today's discussion, landline service will be provided by the end of May 2022 per agreement reached with Maurissa Mitchem and Michael Scroggins of the Department of Children and Family Services. Based on on interviews with staff and clients, landlines were not provided in the living units of the participant. Therefore this allegation is substantanitated, A substantiated complaint means that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met.

deficiencies.description:
Telephones
At all times, telephone service shall be readily accessible in the THPP. A nonminor dependent may, by arrangement with the licensee, have personal landline or cellular telephone service or a personal computer for Internet access in the THPP. Based on interviews with staff and clients, the licensee failed to meet this regulation by not providing landline service in each participant living unit.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a corrective action plan to detail how they will meet this regulation. Licensee was advised of appeal rights and process.

met_with: Shari Wolvek, Director of Quality Assurance & Compliance
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward completed the complaint investigation that was began by LPA Charmetha White. LPA Jones-Steward spoke to three of the five current and former particiapants that were also enrolled in the Divinity Prophet program in 2020. The other two participants were unreachable. The participants all denied any major problems with receving their allowances. The majority stated that they felt safe in their apartments. They also stated that repairs were generally made in a timely manner, although one stated that they had to pay for repair of damages out of their allownance. LPA also reviewed allowance logs for the time period in question and allowances were always signed for according to procedure set forth by Divinity Prophet. Based on the vaguries of these allegations, the age of the complaint when received by this LPA and the small pool of clients available for interview, the above allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated.

narrative: While investigating complaint # 34-CR-20211110162859 Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward was made aware of organizational changes that were not reported to Community Care Licensing as required by Title 22. Specifically there was an unreported change to the executive director and there is currently no administrator. The licensee was cited under Title 22 Sections 80061(e) and 86064(a)

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements:
The items below shall be reported to the licensing agency within 10 working days following the occurrence; Changes to the organization and changes to the chief executive officer. Based on conversations with the current executive director, the licensee failed to meet this requirement by not reporting the change in the executive director to the Department.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The board of directors shall submit evidence of formal appointment of the new chief executive officer and all other organizational changes to the Department for review

deficiencies.description:
Administrator Qualifications and Duties: 
All licensees shall employ a qualified administrator Based on conversations with the current executive officer, the licensee faliled to meet this criteria. There is currently no one serving in the capacity of administrator
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The board of directors shall appoint a qualified administrator and submit their credentials to the Departartment for review.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward spoke with executive director Margaret Davis about the allegations, Per Ms. Davis, C1 was moved to a new location in December 2021 because the management at the buliding where he was living would not do anything about the pest control issues. Ms. Davis provided invoices for new furnishings which were delivered to his new apartment as proof that client was relocated. Per Ms. Davis, C1 no longer resides with Divinity Prophet. He left in March 2022. Therefore LPA was not able to speak to C1. Likewise the administator and the case manager during the period of the allegation no longer work for Divinity Prophet. Based on the available information, the allegation is resolved as unsubstantiated.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Ms. Meka Brown and Ms. Sheri Wolvek to resolve the above allegations. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff, C1 and the original reporter. LPA reviewed PEX card statements and discussed them with Ms. Wolvek and C1. The situation of C1's alleged lack of a consistent case worker was discussed with staff, C1 and with the original reporter. Based on confilicting information gathered via interviews and record reviews LPA was not able to conclude that the allegations are true or false. Therefore they are resolved as unsubstantiated.

13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed Participant #2 and the Case Manager for Participant #1. LPA could not make contact with Participant #1. During the course of the investigation, it was revealed that Divinity Prophet was made aware that a visitor to the living unit of Participant #1 and Participant #2 did fire off his handgun during an argument with Participant #1. However Divinity Prophert staff did not report the incident to Community Care Licensing because they thought that DCFS staff would make the call. Based on interviews with the staff and participants, this allegation is substantiated.

deficiencies.description:
The licensee shall report the following to the Department within one business day:
Any unusual incident or client absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any client. The licensee failed to meet this requirement by not reporting that a visitor to a participant's living unit fired a handgun outside the unit.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a self developed Corrective Action Plan to show how it plans to correct this deficiency.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed Participants #2 and #3, Divinity Prophet Staff and DCFS social workers. LPA also reviewed work orders and purchase orders and receipts. LPA was not able to gain entry into the units of the Participants. Based on information gathered during the interviews of involved parties, it was determined that Divinity Prophet living units of Participant #2 and Participant #3 were often in a state of disrepair. The units were at times plagued with issues such as vermin infestation, plumbing issues and carpets in need of cleaning. Therefore the allegation is resolved as "substantiated". A substantiated finding means that the “preponderance of the evidence” standard has been met.

deficiencies.description:
Buildings & Grounds
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. The licensee failed to meet this requirement by not ensuring that participant living units remained in good repair
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee is to submit a self directed Corrective Action Plan to demonstrate how it will prevent futher deficiences of this nature

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed Divinity Prophet staff and reviewed C1's financial records. C1 could not be reached for comment. Neither her social worker or the ombudsman office have a current telephone number for her.Per review of C1's available financial records, she did not have a savings account because she opted out of the choice to establish one. Her discharge records show that she was formally discharged on 06/02/22 but did not leave the unit until 06/06/22. Since she was no longer an actual participant in the program, she did not receive an allowance for that five day period. Based on the available information it appears that Client #1 had no funds due her upon her discharge from Divinity Prophet. However due to an inability to obtain a statement from C1, this cannot be fully verified. Therefore the allegation is resolved as unsubstantiated. an ubsubstantiated findings means that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

13The above allegations were investigated by LPAs Connie Jones-Steward and LPA Daphne Edison. LPA Edison spoke with Divinity Prophet staff. LPA Jones-Steward spoke with the social worker for Clients #2 and #3. Neither LPA Jones-Steward nor Edison were able to make contact with any of the Clients. LPA Edison attempted to gain entry into the apartments of Clients #1 and #2 but was unsuccessful as clients did not respond to her requests. Based on the inability to interview the clients or gain entry into their apartments, the above allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated finding means that an allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: On May 23, 2022, at 12:10 PM., Licensing Program Analyst, Kuliema Calloway and Licensing Program Manager, Lakescia Smith conducted an unannounced Post-Licensing visit to 38345 30th Street Ste. B-1A, Palmdale, CA 93550. LPA and LPM met with Annlelise Galaviz, Case Manager Supervisor and conducted a tour of the administrative office. LPA was informed that Elizabeth Richard is no longer the Program Administrator and administrator qualifications were submitted one month ago for Annelise Galaviz to become the new Program Administrator. The Administrators office; is equipped with with four offices, a lobby, and a kitchen. A locked file cabinet is used to store client files and staff files are stored in one of the offices. The license is posted on the wall adjacent the conference table and LPA observed the Certificate of Compliance for the residential units. LPA will follow up with Annelise regarding on-call staff, Jaime Kirk who is not associated with the facility. LPA was informed it is currently one case manager and one case manager supervisor. One case manager is part-time and should reflect on the personnel report. Eight NMD's are assigned to Annelise and four NMD's are assigned to Carlos MIna. LPA advised staff to update personnel report to reflect staff current work schedule and submit to CCL. The following deficiency was cited (See 809D) Exit interview completed. A copy of this report was provided to the staff, Annelise Galaviz. Note: LPA will return at a later date to complete the inspection.

THIS REPORT HAS BEEN AMENDED FROM THE PREVIOUS DATE 12/08/2021 DUE TO CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION LISTED. The Administrative Office is located at: 38345 30th St. East Suite B-1A Palmdale, CA 93550. The office is located on the 1st floor of the building. LPA observed the entire Administrative office. The restroom is located outside the administrative office to the left. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) for 27 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently seventeen (17) participants in placement residing in the program -Remote Sites. The Administrator stated that there are ten (10) Remote Sites are all located in the Palmdale and Lancaster. The administrator confirmed that no staff is residing in the Remote Sites. There are no bodies of water on the premises. LPA viewed the location of the Remote Sites and Residential Lease confirmed for Palmdale and Lancaster. LIC 809 Page 1 of 3

THIS REPORT HAS BEEN AMENDED FROM THE PREVIOUS DATE 12/08/2021 DUE TO CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION LISTED. LPA's observed the entire Administrative office. The office is set up as follows: At the entrance. There is a front lobby there is a sliding glass Receptionist Window to greet clients and authorized representatives to sign in. There is locked door adjacent to the receptionist window that leads to the main administrative conference area. The Administrators office; is equipped with an office desk, desk top computer, office supplies, locked file cabinet, a book shelf utilized to store files. The shut valves are located inside the door. There is large conference table with ten (10) chairs; two (2) Case Management offices (desk, table top computers and chairs) an interview office utilized for residents, social workers and any other authorized representative. There are 2 seated desks with office supplies, a book shelf with additional office supplies; office equipment (printer fax machine) (1) computer, portable folding table and covered trash cans. There a small size kitchen equipped with cabinets, a sink, microwave, coffee maker, and supplies for the clients, food pantry, additional supplies for the units. LPA observed the THP+FC residence files and staff files were stored in the locked file cabinets. Currently the facility is staffed with two (2) Social Workers. The administrator is aware that the social worker meets the regulation requirements ratio 1 to 24 for supervision. The administrator is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed. The administrator ensures that the THPP residents are provided care and supervision by conducting visit at minimum of 1x weekly for one (1) hour session. The administrator stated that client independently cook their own food. The THPP provides a distributes allowances of $100 including gifts cards for incentives. The administrator conducts events to encourage the residents to build rapport; establish appropriate relations, discuss boundaries and limitations. Continued LIC 809 Page 2 of 3

LPA reviewed three (3) staff files and five (5) client files contain; (Admission agreement/ COVID-19/Intake/ Policy and Procedures, /Allowance Logs/Savings Log/Case Notes/Goals/ Incident Reports/Disciplinary notes/Vital documents/Mental Health/Disaster plan/Physical Health/Employment Education/Life Skills/County Benefits/Files and Transitional Resources LPA reviewed the LIC-500 Personnel Report; and the Register of Facility Client/Residents staff roster. LPA confirmed criminal record clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances for three (3) staff. LPA interview one (1) Staff/Administrator Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapter 7, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator LIC 809 Page 3 of 3

On May 27, 2022, at 11:00 AM., Licensing Program Analyst, Kuliema Calloway and Licensing Program Manager, Lakescia Smith made an unannounced Case Management Annual Continuation Visit at the Administrative Office. LPA and LPM met with staff, Annelise Galaviz and requested to review staff and client files. A file review was completed but LPA will return to complete the client record's review. narrative:
On 02/09/2023 at 9:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an unannounced to Divinity Prophet Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) Administrative Office for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1) and Staff#2 (S2) who granted access to the Administrative Office and an inspection was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 02/09/23. The annual fees are current. LPA Rosas inspected following during the inspection: The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) to twenty-seven (27) participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently six (6) participants in placement at different remote sites in the Antelope Valley (sites are located in Palmdale and Lancaster). The facility currently has Administrator serving as the Social Worker (1 per 12 participants) and the Director of Programs as the Social Worker Supervisor (1 per 8 Social Workers). The facility is currently operating within staff ratio. If the capacity increased, then additional personnel would need to be added. The administrative office is set up as follows: The administrative office is located at 38345 E 30 TH, EAST Suite B-1A., Palmdale, CA 93550. Administration office is equipped with (4) four offices with reception area, and a kitchen. Staff records and client records are maintained in inside locked cabinet. All posting requirements were met. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 2

LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas requested the following forms for review, copy of Register of participants, Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan Protocols, Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities (LIC 610C). The certification/decertification list of participants living units. Staff Records Review: LPA Rosas reviewed (2) two staff files. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that facility has currently has Administrator serving as the Social Worker (1 per 12 participants) and the Director of Programs as the Social Worker Supervisor (1 per 8 Social Workers). The facility is currently operating within staff ratio. If the capacity increased, then additional personnel would need to be added. LPA review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 02/06/2023 that indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. The facility personnel available on a 24-hour basis to respond to any emergency. Clients Records Review: LPA reviewed three (3) clients records which meet requirement. LPA reviewed the Admission Agreements, date of placement in unit, Emergency Contact information, and Needs and Services Plan. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview using the inspection tool interview form with one (1) staff. LPA Rosas together with S1 conducted a collateral visit to three (3) remote sites located in Palmdale, CA. LPA Rosas during inspection the housing units did have telephone service but had no dial tone. S2 was able to provide LPA Rosas with a copy of Verizon monthly telephone. The monthly bill showed remote sites phone numbers listed as active line. S1 and S2 stated, the living units do have telephone service and checking with Verizon on why they are not working. LPA Rosas by email send the following PINS to S1 by email: PIN 21-26-CRP Transitional Housing Placement Provider (THPP) Nonsubstantive Changes to Regulations Update, PIN 22-06-CCLD Guardian Background Check Best Practices, PIN 22-07-CCLD Guardian Webinar For Licensees and Providers, PIN 21-20-CRP Statewide Launch Of New Inspection Tools For Children’s Residential Licensees. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left with S1.

Meeting Attendees: Latricia Rogers- Licensing Program Analyst Christina Barns- Licensing Program Manager Cheraki Davis- Licensing Program Manager Emmett Downs- Program Director Anita Downs- Human Resource Director Rosa Hernandez- Housing Manager Jesse Vega- Program Manager The topics listed below were discussed during the meeting: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rogers asked E. Downs for clarification regarding locations for physical sites/ housing for future participants as Application (LIC 200) only referenced an address for an office space. E. Downs informed LPA Rogers that they do not currently have placement sites and that they are in partnership with several apartment complexes for future placements.

On May 13, 2022, at 8:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the facility agency's administrative office located at 4324 Latham St. suite #140, Riverside, Ca. 92502. Upon entrance into the facility, there is a spacious open area with a large table that will be used training's and equipped with a work station with a large printer/scanner. There are three separate offices with locked doors. Office #1 Identified as the Administrator's office. Offices #2 and #3 adjacent are the Supervising Social Worker Offices. All offices are fully equipped with work desk units, telephones computers and computer stations. Records: Client files will be locked in office #1. There is a staff break room equipped with refrigerator and microwave. The restroom are located inside the building. On April 11, 2023, at 8:30am, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced post-licensing inspection at the facility agency's administrative office located at 4324 Latham St. Suite #140, Riverside, CA 92502. LPA’s met with housing specialist, Rosa Hernandez, and Intake Coordinator, Rita Hill, and were given a tour of the facility. There are currently four participants residing in the program, which include two remote sites in the city of Riverside. Upon entrance into the facility, there is a spacious open area with a large table that is used for training's and is equipped with a workstation with a large printer/scanner. There are three separate offices with locked doors. The conference room is equipped with a table, chairs, white board, file cabinets, and television. The facility has Wi-Fi accessibility. The restroom are located inside the building. Office #1 Identified as the Administrator's office. Offices #2 and #3 adjacent are the Supervising Social Worker Offices. All offices are fully equipped with work desk units, telephones computers, and computer stations. LPA’s observed that Participant files were stored in a locked cabinet in Office #1. Currently, the facility is staffed with two full-time Life Coaches (Social Workers), one Housing Specialist, one Supervising Social Worker, and one Program Director. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. LPA’s reviewed four staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA’s reviewed four non-minor dependent files. All files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. Facility provided a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. Based on observation and record review, the facility is in compliance, no deficiencies were noted at this time. Exit interview conducted with Housing Specialist, Rosa Hernandez, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

On April 11, 2024, at 11:10am, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPAs), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Cynthia Robinson, conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection at the facility agency's administrative office located at 4324 Latham St. Suite #140, Riverside, CA 92502. LPAs met with Program Director Emmett Downs, housing specialist, Rosa Hernandez, and Intake Coordinator, Rita Hill, and were given a tour of the facility. There are currently 16 participants- Non Minor Dependents (NMD) residing in the program, which include 8 remote sites throughout Riverside County and 1 remote site in San Bernardino County. Upon entrance into the facility, there is a spacious open area with a large table that is used for training's and is equipped with a workstation with a large printer/scanner. There are three separate offices with locked doors. The conference room is equipped with a table, chairs, white board, file cabinets, and television. The facility has Wi-Fi accessibility. The restroom are located inside the building. Office #1 Identified as the Administrator's office. Offices #2 and #3 adjacent are the Supervising Social Worker Offices. All offices are fully equipped with work desk units, telephones computers, and computer stations. LPAs observed that Participant files were stored in a locked cabinet in Office #1. Currently, the facility is staffed with two full-time Life Coaches (Social Workers), one Housing Specialist, one Supervising Social Worker, and one Program Director. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. LPAs reviewed four staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPAs reviewed four NMD dependent files. All files reviewed were complete and had the required documents with the exception of NMD (C1) missing the TB test. Facility provided a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. CONTINUED NEXT PAGE

Based on observation and record review, the facility is in compliance, no deficiencies were noted at this time. Exit interview conducted with Program Director Emmett Downs, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

met_with: Transitional Housing Program Director Jenna Bethancourt
narrative: On Monday 03/14/2022 at 11AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a prelicensing inspection at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) administrative office. The THPP is currently licensed and is moving the local administrative office to the new location at which this visit was conducted. LPA met with Transitional Housing Program Director Jenna Bethancourt for the scheduled visit. Safety precautions were taken including mask-wearing and hand hygiene. The office is located in an office building. The THPP will continue to serve up to 15 participants. There are currently no units listed under this location. Director confirmed that Director and Executive Director Melody King are aware that all units must be within a 2-hour drive from this office. The program plans to utilize remote sites and host-family sites. During inspection, LPA toured the office with Office Manager and Director. LPA observed the office to be quiet, clean, and in good and safe condition. The office has storage space, meeting spaces, and a confidential meeting space. The office will be open Monday to Friday, 8AM to 5PM, and the program has a 24hr on-call worker. The fire extinguisher is located inside and is up to date, and the first aid kit was centrally stored and observed to be complete. Participant records will be stored in a locked cabinet in the main back room of the office, and personnel records will all be accessible through a digital filing software (currently, Kidnet). Three medium-large kitchen knives were accessible in the staff kitchen in an unlocked drawer. Director confirmed that knives will be stored in a locked drawer in the Office Manager's desk as a safety precaution for participants visiting the office. Per Director, there are no weapons or firearms on the premises. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Director Jenna Bethancourt. Provisional licensure anticipated for Wednesday 03/16/2022.

On 7/15/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Office Manager Lisa Florence and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. No deficiencies were found during the inspection. The facility site (administrative office) is tidy and well-organized. Participant and personnel files were observed to be complete. There are no participants currently in the program, and consequently no units currently held by the program, so no unit inspection was conducted. The facility was observed to be in compliance and operating according to the license. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Office Manager Lisa Florence, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced required Annual inspection to EA Family Services. LPA met with Antonette Geiser, Office Manager. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. Only Office Manager Antonette Geiser was on site, no participants present. At 11:15AM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Antonette Geiser. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in the file room. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Antonette Geiser, about the residential units. Antonette Geiser stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Antonette Geiser stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Antonette Geiser notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 10:21AM, LPA reviewed five staff files with Antonette Geiser. Staff files are complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. Antonette Geiser stated that they have received two new participants at the beginning of March 2023. Not all participant documents are on site. Participants have not been in placement for over 30 days, LPA did not review participant files. All documents are complete and up to date. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with Antonette Geiser, Office Manager.

met_with: Executive Director Melody King; Program Director Jenna Bethancourt
narrative: On 3/5/24 at 11AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) Executive Director Melody King and Program Director Jenna Bethancourt for an informal office meeting held virtually over Microsoft Teams. LPA informed of the purpose of the meeting, which was to discuss the Department's request for revisions to the program's plan of operation (POO). The Department was recently made aware that a revised participant agreement has been used by the provider. Upon review of the POO and the participant agreement document approved by the Department, the licensee is advised to make the following revisions to their POO. 1) Submit all revisions, including the participant agreement, to the Department for review. 2) Indicate in the POO the minimum stipend/allowance and the method(s) used to determine how much a participant receives in greater detail. 3) Remove fines as a consequence. LPA advised that the licensee revise this section to reframe consequences in a positive reinforcement manner and discussed ways to accomplish this during the meeting. 4) Remove the pet fine. LPA advises that having a pet is a rule violation, but applicable regulatory and/or licensing requirements provide that participants' cash resources must be free of any liability the licensee incurs. 5) Remove the move-in kit charge. LPA advises that the THPP is required to supply basic furnishing as a basic service in order to maintain licensure, and applicable regulatory and/or licensing requirements disallow a licensee from making expenditures from participants' cash resources for basic services. LPA discussed applicable regulatory sections, including Title 22, Sections 86126(d), 86126(f), 86088(a),86001(b)(2), and Nonminor Dependent Interim Licensing Standards for THPP, Section 86226. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Executive Director and Program Director, whose agreed to sign and send back to LPA an emailed copy to confirm receipt.

On 5/20/2024 at 9:50am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and LPA Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs met with Antonette Geiser, Office Manager. LPAs reviewed ten client files. During the file review, LPAs observed that the facility used one to two sentences to document what services the facility provided to clients. LPAs observed that the facility had documented services on the clients' bi-weekly case notes. LPAs advised that the facility should include more information on their Needs and Services Plans regarding services provided. LPAs delivered a Technical Assistance for Interim Licensing Standards 86268.3(c)(3) Needs and Services Plan. Based on record review and discussion, LPAs found that the facility had not done medical assessments for the clients within thirty days of admission. This poses a potential risk to the health, safety, and/or personal rights of clients in care. LPAs delivered a Type B citation for Title 22 California Code of Regulations 86069(a) Participant Medical Assessments. LPAs reviewed three staff files. LPAs conducted one confidential interview. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility. LPAs observed the posted license and observed that the office was clean, tidy, and in good repair. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Antonette Geiser, Office Manager at 1:10pm and delivered appeal rights.

On 04/09/25 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and LPA Cole Oliver conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs met with Antonette Geiser, Office Administrator who assited with the inspection. LPAs reviewed ten client files. During the file review, all client files contained necessary documents and information. LPAs reviewed four staff files. During the file review, all staff had required documentation and training. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility. LPAs observed the posted license and observed that the office was clean, tidy, and in good repair. LPAs conducted 1 confidential interview. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Antonette Geiser, Office Administrator.

On 08/22/2024 at 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Misty Valencia and Tina Thorn met with Environmental Alternatives Family Services Social Worker Supervisor Jamie Cobabe to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. The facility is located in the same office complex as the EA Family Services Foster Family Agency (FFA) and Adoptions Program in Sacramento. There is a separate reception and entrance for the proposed adoption agency. The FFA, THP and Adoption agency will use the same entrances. The office is conveniently located for the public. The office has a reception area, 4 office spaces and a conference/training room, all of which can be used for confidential meetings. Agency has a communal staff bathroom and break room located outside the office in the hallway, which is available to staff and families. There are also multiple private room areas available for visiting LPA observed the rooms to have ample space for furniture and privacy for visitations with families. There is adequate parking available. Emergency Disaster Plan is posted in the reception area. License will be posted as soon as it is issued. All files and personnel records will be kept confidential and locked in the office and separated from visiting areas. As of right now all files are currently waiting in the old office to move into the new office space once license is provided and able to post in the building. The office space was observed to meet the requirements of Title 22 Regulations at this time. The facility will be submitted for licensure. An exit interview was conducted with facility representative and a copy of the report was provided.

On Wednesday, November 13th, 2024, at 9AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, made an unannounced visit to the facility with the purpose of conducting a follow up visit regarding an incident that was reported to the department on November 12th, 2024, involving the death of a client. LPA Crass met with the Assistant Executive Director/THP Director, Jenna Bethancourt. LPA Crass conducted four interviews. LPA Crass obtained copies of the client's complete file, including the most recent Needs and Services Plan, Medical Records, and Social Worker case notes. LPA Crass will obtain a copy of the coroners report and police report for the file at a later date; reports are not available at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Jenna Bethancourt, THP Director.

On Monday, November 18th, 2024, at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, made an unannounced visit to the facility with the purpose of conducting a subsequent, follow up visit regarding an incident that was reported to the department on November 12th, 2024, involving the death of a client. LPA Crass met with the Social Worker Supervisor, Jamie Cobabe. LPA Crass conducted one interview. A police report was not available at this time, but will be sent at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Jamie Cobabe.

On Thursday, November 21st, 2024 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, made an unannounced, subsequent visit for the purpose of closing out a Case Management, regarding an incident that was reported to the Department on November 12th, 2024, involving the death of a client. LPA Crass met with Brittany Johnson, Office Manager. LPA interviewed the THPP Director (S1), the client's prior Case Manager (S2), the prior Lead Care Manager for CalAim (S3), the client's current Case Manager (S4), the Facility Social Worker Supervisor (S5), the client's girlfriend (W1), and the client's County Social Worker's Supervisor (CSWS) between November 13th, 2024 to November 18th, 2024 and retrieved a copy of the client’s complete file. LPA Crass will obtain a copy of the coroner’s report and police report for the file at a later date, as reports are not available at this time. No deficiencies were cited. This case management is closed. No follow up is needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Office Manager, Brittany Johnson

On Thursday, July 31st, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass arrived Unannounced for the purpose of an Annual inspection. LPA met with Office Manager, Kelly Golla who assisted with the inspection. Office Manager Supervisor, Kitty Cannon arrived later to assist. LPA conducted a physical walk through of the facility. LPA observed that the office has a reception area, 3 office suites and a conference/training room, all of which can be used for confidential meetings. Agency has a communal staff bathroom and a break room located outside the office in the hallway, which is available to staff and families. There are also multiple private room areas available for visiting. LPA observed the rooms to have ample space for furniture and privacy for visitations with families. Emergency Disaster Plan and License are posted in the reception area. All areas of the building were clean, in good repair, and had no obstructions in the walkways. All files and personnel records are kept confidential and locked in the office and separated from visiting areas. LPA reviewed five staff files and five client files. LPA found that 6 staff who work at this THPP license are not associated to the license. However, all are DOJ/FBI/CACI cleared and associated to the agency's Sacramento FFA license. LPA found that all other staff requirements were met. For client files LPA found all requirements were met. The agency is being cited one Type A citation for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86019(e)(2) CRIMINAL RECORD CLEARANCE on the attached LIC 809-D page. An exit interview was conducted with Kitty Cannon. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were given.

On 8/28/2023 and 8/29/2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley met with Social worker Leslie Naseath - social worker and Jeanne Harvey Senior social worker supervisor via Facetime. LPA McKinley toured the new facility and found it open and organized with the fire extinguisher recently inspected. LPA suggested EA obtain additional fire extinguishers as there is only one in the building currently. The LIC 610 was posted along with the emergency exit route floor plans in various locations in the building. The office First Aid kit was supplied with a thermometer, tweezers, scissors, gauze bandages and antiseptic wipes. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in functioning order and all pathways were free and clear. All staff have required initial training's. The offices have sound machines just outside the SW offices for privacy. Each office had a adjustable sign to let others know if they are in a meeting or session with a client. The office building is a free standing among other office building surround it. There is a pathway most of the way around the building with clean landscaping and a ramp to enter the office for persons who are not ambulatory. Although the front office entry way is small the building offers much more space for social workers and client visit rooms. There is a copy room, large storage room with a code entrance, a kitchen, several offices, a conference room, and a large open space with couches. There are two glass slider exit route in case of emergency. The building has heating and air. The facility has two public restrooms for families and children and one employee only bathroom as well. Leslie and Jeanne were asked about cleaning the building prior to them moving in and what they have as a regular service. Jeanne stated they have a regular cleaning services and would have the building thoroughly cleaned prior to moving in the remainder of office furnishings and belonging from the G street location. No deficiencies were noted. No citations given.

On 03/11/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Agency Social Worker (ASW) Giselle Olguin. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Bi-Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 04/11/23. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual Inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has seven (7) offices for Social Workers, Case Workers, and one (1) confidential interview/visitation room. LPA observed the proper postings including facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current and will expire 03/19/25, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files stored in the Office Manager’s office in a locked filing cabinet and stored electronically with a password protection and username. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has sixteen (16) Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs three (3) Case Managers. LPA reviewed three (3) Case Worker personnel files. Case work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Case Worker personnel. Report continued on 809c

LPA interviewed three (3) Case Worker personnel. Case work personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed six (6) client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client, and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Facility has no minor clients. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C report was provided to Agency Social Worker (ASW) Giselle Olguin. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Robyn Word, conducted a pre-licensing virtual inspection at the proposed facility site for Environmental Alternatives Services Inc. Foster Family Agency (FFA) office. The facility was toured with Social Worker Supervisor Jeanne Harvey. The FFA office is in a secure area. The entrance to the office is a private reception area. The office is being leased by the FFA. LPA observed a visitation area with locking cabinets for children’s and foster home files, this area will also be used for private visitations for families, other client’s visitors, and a training and conference room for staff. There are two Social Worker offices which have, desks, and locking cabinets that can be used to store home files as needed. There is a copy room with a fax machine, copy machine, and working telephones. There is a restroom located in the hallway. LPA observed a staff break room, a storage area, there is office equipment and furniture throughout the office space. The phone number to the office is 530-741-2800. The office space was observed to meet the requirements of Title 22 Regulations at this time. After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to Social Worker Supervisor Jeanne Harvey.

facility_name: EA FAMILY SERVICES - YUBA CITY THPP/THP+FC
narrative: Continuation from 9099 Based on the evidence gained, and statements in interviews the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC9099D.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word met with Administrator Melody King, on 6/2/2022 at 12:05PM to discuss the complaint investigation. The California Department of Social Services, Fiscal and Performance Audits Bureau, conducted an audit review for the allegations: Facility is misusing funds, and Board of Directors is not ensuring a fiscally responsible budget. The purpose of the audit was to evaluate the financial condition of the Provider’s program. The scope of the audit included a review of the Provider’s financial records for the audit period including, but not limited to, the general ledger, invoices, receipts, canceled checks, bank statements, credit card statements, lease agreements, DMV registrations, and internal control procedures also, the CDSS auditors reviewed pertinent records related to the Board of Directors, such as the Articles of Incorporation, bylaws, and Board Minutes. During the audit period, the audit disclosed some concerns regarding the Provider’s program operations related to unallowable or unsupported costs that were disallowed, internal control issues, and oversight by the Board of Directors. Please see continuation page 9099C

facility_name: EA FAMILY SERVICES - YUBA CITY THPP/THP+FC
narrative:
On 01/9/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Janelle Douglas, Social Worker. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has two offices for social workers and two interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, accreditation, and emergency disaster plan. The restroom for Clients and staff was clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly and exit maps posted. LPA observed client files were stored in a locked file cabinet. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has 17 THP participants. Clients live in either approved homes or remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility currently employs one Social Worker and two Case Managers in the program. LPA reviewed one Social Worker, two Case Manager, one Office Manager, and one Administrator personnel files. Personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date. LPA reviewed five client files. All Clients had signed Admission Agreements. Four of five Client files did not have current Needs and Service Plans and a Plan of Correction was drafted and signed. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC 809D, reports were provided to Janelle Douglas, Social Worker. An exit interview was conducted.
