Continued from 9099 There was no verification that a client who correctly completed the process to get an Emotional Support pet authorized by a clinician or physician, was actually denied having the pet. Therefore, a Technical Violation was given to the facility to ensure future compliance with applicable state laws. Based on interviews, observation, and record review, there was not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 and LIC-9099C report was provided to the Case Manager and emailed to Program Director. An Exit interview was complete.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of opening the 10-day complaint investigation and delivering findings. LPA met with Zyla Oru, Case Manager, to discuss the allegation. LPA interviewed two case managers at the facility. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed two county social workers, one clinician, and one client. LPA reviewed relevant records on site and requested copies of records be sent to LPA including: Roster of clients with contact numbers, rental agreement, participant agreement, and agency social worker case notes for five clients for previous three months. The individuals interviewed indicated the facility does not allow clients to have emotional support pets. This was also documented in their participation agreement. This requirement by the facility violates California fair housing law for persons with disabilities. Contined on 9099C

narrative: On 4/11/2023 at 9:00 AM LPA Kellie McKinley met with Rayna Harkness for a annual inspections for the THP license for EA Family Services THP program.. Rayna is filling in for supervisor who is currently out. LPA McKinley toured the facility and found clean and organized with Fire extinguisher current for inspection which will be coming up in June 2023. The office First Aid kit was supplied with bandages, tweezers and small scissors. A separate scanning thermometer is in the office for use when needed. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in functioning order and all pathways were free and clear. All staff have required initial training's, with the exception of a new employee who is in the process of completing all required training and documents for the staff file. THP Client files are stored in a locking file cabinet behind a locked office door. LPA reviewed 10 client files which were organized in order of the table of contents at the front of the folder. One client was missing a Needs and Services plan. On two additional client's Needs and Services plans, required signatures were missing A technical violation is noted for ILS regulation 8268.3 (d). (d) The Needs and Services Plan shall be signed by the nonminor dependent, the THPP administrator or social work personnel, and the person or agency responsible for placing the nonminor dependent, such as a social worker or probation officer, and maintained in the records for the nonminor dependent as specified in Section 86270, Nonminor Dependents' Records. No citation were given at the time of the annual inspection. A copy of this form was sent to the THP program at the time of the inspection completion. An exit interview was conducted.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst Lisa Slusher travelled to the Environmental Alternaves DBA EA Family Services office in Fresno CA. LPA was met by Administrators Rehmana Arif and Deally Curran. Also present were Jenna Bethancourt, Kathleen Hernandez, Lisa Florence and Kylie Martinez., for the purpose of a scheduled pre-licensing inspection for an THP+FC. Agency has an Assigned Administrator/Social Work Supervisor and two social workers, with more to be hired and assigned. A general overview of their program and a tour of the facility was provided. This facility has a reception area, waiting area, and office space for staff. Observed fixtures and furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. Also observed locked cabinets for client and staff files in order to ensure confidentiality. Discussed daily ongoing functions including incident reports. There is ample confidential space for meeting with clients on an as needed basis. Incident reports to be emailed to CCLFresnoIncidents@dss.ca.gov. This LPA's email address is Lisa.Slusher@dss.ca.gov. LPA received updated LIC 200 for facility name update during inspection. Agency will ensure that all appropriate personnel are associated to the facility license through Guardian. The above licensee meets the requirements to be licensed as in Fresno County serving participants within a two hour driving radius.

On this date 2/23/22 at 9:00 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher travelled to the facility to conduct a post-licensing inspection. Prior to this inspection a pre-inspection Covid screening was conducted. Met with Office Manager Kathleen HernandezThe agency was licensed at this location on 10/12/21. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: client and staff files are kept in locked filing cabinets, and are printouts from an electronic filing system. Facility has adequate confidential meeting space and space for Social Workers to complete job duties. narrative: On September 18,2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisa Slusher conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 9:00 AM. LPA met with Vicky Moreno, Office Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Post Licensing inspection at the Foster Family Agency. The agency provides Transitional Housing Services for non-minor dependents at scattered housing sites. A tour of the agency was completed. The office is adequately equipped to provide privacy for interviewing and is conveniently located for the public. Staff files, client files and resource parent files are maintained in a locked room. The license, personal rights, complaint number and emergency disaster plan are posted in plain view. The agency employs one office manager, one Administrator/Social Worker Supervisor, two social workers, two case managers and two transporters. The LPA requested the following items: Personnel Report LIC 500, list of current THP+FC placements.. During today’s inspection, LPA Slusher reviewed physical plant, operational requirements, and disaster preparedness. There are no violations of Title 22, Division of 6 of the California Code of Regulations were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the FFA representative.

On January 23, 2024, at 9:07 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an announced visit at Embracing Lives Changes II, administrative office, located at: 3600 Lime St. Building #2 Suite #213, Riverside, CA 92501. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA met and did a walk through of the facility with, Administrator, Cornicha Hayward. Upon entrance into the facility, there are multiple businesses with private suites. There is a spacious open area with a large table that leads to each individual suite. There is one office that is equipped with a desk, locked file cabinet, and printer/scanner. The facility has Wi-Fi accessibility. Facility, participant, and personnel records are stored in a locked file cabinet. There is a staff break room located in the building, downstairs, that is equipped with a refrigerator and microwave. Restrooms are located inside the building both upstairs and downstairs. There is a conference room that is equipped with a table, chairs, white board, file cabinets, and television. There are currently six participants in five remote sites. Four of the remote sites are located in Riverside county and one in San Bernardino county. Remote sites are no further then two hours distance from the Administrative office location. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports, as needed, to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. During the inspection, LPA reviewed six participant records and five personnel records. Five out of five personnel records reviewed met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. Five out of five personnel records reviewed had a completed Tuberculosis (TB) test but did not have a health screening on file. *Continued on next page LIC 809-C*

Six out of six participant records had required documents including admission agreement, personal rights, medical/education history, immunization records, and medical consent forms on file. Six out of six participant records reviewed had a completed Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) on file but did not have a completed Needs and Services Plan (NSP) on file. Based on observation and record review, the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 86066(a)(11) and Title 22, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 86268.3(a) which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. Technical violations were given to the facility with a plan of correction and due dates. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of this report along with LIC 809D was provided to Cornicha Hayward, Administrator.

Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that facility staff refused to allow a client (NMD) in care to seek medical attention. It was alleged that NMD could not visit the doctor for a skin rash. Confidential interviews reported that NMD was told by staff they were not allowed to leave to see a doctor for the skin rash. Confidential interviews reported that NMD was responsible for making appointments with doctors, and they were allowed to leave their house when they wanted. Additional confidential interviews reported that NMD was not shown how to make their (NMD) doctor’s appointments, which was the reason for not making an appointment for the skin rash. LPA was unable to determine if the allegation occurred due to conflicted statements. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff (S1) handled the client (NMD) inappropriately and refused to allow the client (NMD) to seek medical attention are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Corneisha Hayward, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 12, 2024 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an unannounced visit to Embracing Life’s Changes II Transitional Housing Placement (THP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. On 08/16/2024, LPA initiated the complaint at THP and obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. LPA interviewed Non-Minor Dependent (NMD), staff (S1, S2, and S3) and County Social Worker (CSW). On 08/12/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that facility staff (S1) handled a client (NMD) in an inappropriate manner. It was alleged that S1 put their hands on NMD. Confidential interviews reported that S1 pushed and grabbed NMD on multiple occasions in response to keep NMD from physically harming themselves. Additional confidential interviews reported that S1 would not grab or pull NMD and would stay out of the way of NMD to avoid getting pushed. The documentation collected reported that NMD was to have 24/7 surveillance due to its high-level care needs.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an announced pre-licensing inspection at the agency and met with Executive Director Michel Douglas who assisted with the inspection. LPA conducted a walk through of the agency with ED. The office is located in a commercial office building, with other businesses present. There are two rooms in the office with space for private interviews/meetings. There was a locked safe for files, chairs, a desk, and shelving. The business hours are not yet posted on the door. Needed before Licensure: To be submitted to CCL by Friday 12/13/2024. 1. For Administrator, ED will submit the following: - Proposed Administrator's proof of education that meets the requirements. - Proposed Administrator's Resume, and employment verification. - LIC 501. 2. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an announced pre-licensing inspection at the facility and met with Executive Director and Administrator (ED), Kimberlee Espadron and Social Work Supervisor (SWS) Michel Douglas, who assisted LPA with the inspection. The facility is located in an office building, shared by other businesses. The office space is one room, equipped with a file cabinet which will confidentially hold client and staff files. A restroom is located in the building. The room can provide space for confidential interviews, providing others in the room leave. LPA completed Component Three of the licensing process with ED and SWS by reviewing regulation and processes with them. LPA collected updated LIC forms and the final program statement. ED updated LIC308, LIC309, LIC400, LIC200, LIC999, as well as updated their Program Statement section - Transportation. ED updated the Emergency Disaster plan section to include all required information, LPA collected a copy of this. Topics reviewed: Fingerprint clearances, Guardian, LPA inspections, citation/advisory note process, civil penalty types, CARE tools, CDSS forms and how to find them, exceptions and waivers, ACLs, ACINs, PINs, Certificates of Compliance, reporting requirements, reporting units and phone numbers, inspection authority, POCs, extensions on POC due dates, social worker/social work supervisor ratios, client access to telephones, personal rights, AB12 ILS and THPP specific regulations.

The facility does have a facility phone, it is a cell phone, which they will leave in the office and keep it charged at all times. On-site at the remote location, they have a landline phone that connects to the wifi. On this date, the facility is ready to be licensed and LPA will issue the license to ED and SWS. LPA and ED/SWS will keep in communication about minor changes/updates to be made to their Program Statement. An exit interview was conducted with ED and SWS and a copy of this report was left with them.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall met with Licensees Michel Douglas and Kimberlee Espadron via Microsoft Teams to discuss their plans for their license. Licensees Espadron and Douglas wish to separate and be licensed separately. Options given were: 1. to maintain their current license and open a different location, however the board will still be accountable for all. 2. Surrender license and apply for two more licenses separately. Licensees initially started as a partnership and are currently a corporation, however the financial information was under an individual, rather than the corporation. If Licensees choose to stay intact with the corporation, and to submit a new application for a second THPP, the Licensees will need to submit a Board Resolution stating agreement with their plans. Licensee will also correct the financials through the corporation. Licensees can change their facility names if they so choose. CCL will work with the Licensees to correct the current program statement if Licensees choose to keep it, and assist with the potential new program statement. LPM informed Licensees how to proceed whether they completely separate, choose to stay under the same corporation, or one licensee takes over the license and the other branches off with their own separate application. Licensees will inform CCL how they would like to proceed by 8/1/2024, and CCL will assist them through that process. An exit interview was conducted with the licensees and a copy of this report was emailed to them with a read receipt. Licensees will sign the document and return it to LPA.

Licensee Michel Douglas made an announced visit to CCL's office to review Program Statements with LPA Alyssa Burgess. During this meeting, Licensee and LPA discussed other program changes that are in process with Xtended Menu: Licensee provided LPA with a Board Resolution which changed the Corporation name from "Xtended MEnU, Inc.", to "Empower MEnU, Inc.", as well as Secretary of State documents with the name change. The Resolution did not include a facility name change approval, so Licensee stated she will have that to LPA by COB tomorrow 9/20/2024. Licensee asked LPA questions about forms she will submit to CCL for the change of location and Administrator. LPA reviewed these with her, as well as what else needs to be submitted for the name change, relocation for the facility, and Administrator designation. LPA also reviewed with Licensee how to complete the facility sketch form. Licensee gave CCL the relocation fee check during today's office visit, and will submit the rest of the documents by COB tomorrow 9/20/2024. Licensee provided LPA with a Board Resolution to elect a new Chief Financial Officer. LPA reviewed requirements with Licensee to ensure herself and her Board Members review and fill out the acknowledgement (LIC 9165) from the "Facts You Need To Know" Booklet (PUB 326) and maintain that record in their files. Licensee will also send CCL a copy of those acknowledgements. LPA will process the Corporation Name Change when the other documents from the resolution are received.

Needed for Change of Location: 1. LIC FORMS: 200, 999,610, 9045, 500, 400, 401, and 308. 2. Lease agreement for the new location. 3. Check with the relocation fee of $454 (RECEIVED). ** An updated Program Statement/Plan of Operation will be submitted by Licensee to CCL within 60 days of relocation licensure. Once relocation is completed, LPA will give Licensee the correct due date. Needed for Change in Administrator: 1. Proposed Administrator's proof of education that meets the requirements. 2. Proposed Administrator's Resume. 3. LIC 501. An exit interview was conducted with Licensee and a copy of this report was provided to her.

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation -86022(e) 
The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on records review and interviews, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above. The mobile phone number on file was disconnected and the staff were not readily available until 12:30PM when regular business hours are from 8AM to 5PM.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will provide documentation of attempted mobile phone number  and Licensee should also submit a written statement to LPA Turner indicating how they are going to prevent not being available when CCL arrives at the office by March 20, 2025.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall conducted an unannounced annual inspection at the facility, located at 2003 Main St., Susanville, CA on 02/10/2022 at 9 am. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word met with Administrator Melody King, on 6/2/2022 at 12:03PM to discuss the complaint investigation. The California Department of Social Services, Fiscal and Performance Audits Bureau, conducted an audit review for the allegations: Facility is misusing funds, and Board of Directors is not ensuring a fiscally responsible budget. The purpose of the audit was to evaluate the financial condition of the Provider’s program. The scope of the audit included a review of the Provider’s financial records for the audit period including, but not limited to, the general ledger, invoices, receipts, canceled checks, bank statements, credit card statements, lease agreements, DMV registrations, and internal control procedures also, the CDSS auditors reviewed pertinent records related to the Board of Directors, such as the Articles of Incorporation, bylaws, and Board Minutes. During the audit period, the audit disclosed some concerns regarding the Provider’s program operations related to unallowable or unsupported costs that were disallowed, internal control issues, and oversight by the Board of Directors. Please see continuation page 9099C

narrative:
On 1/18/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Rayna Harkness, Office Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 2/10/22. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has 2 offices for social workers and 1 confidential interview/visitation room. LPA observed the proper postings including facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were in working order, the 2 fire extinguishers were current up to July 2024, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files stored in a locked filing cabinet in the Office Manager’s office and electronically with password. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has four (4) Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs 1 Social Worker, 1 Supervisor, and 1 Office Manager. LPA reviewed 3 personnel staff files. All three staff had completed criminal record clearances and both the Social Worker, and the Social Worker Supervisor met minimum education experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for all staff personnel. LPA interviewed 1 staff personnel. Staff personnel indicated Social Worker does not have more than 12 THP clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed four client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Report continued on 812c

No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 (and LIC-809C) report was provided to Rayna Harkness, Office Manager. An exit interview was conducted. End of report.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility on 1/17/24 at 9:00 AM. LPA rang the doorbell and no one was there. LPA made a call to the phone number but no one picked up. LPA called the EA-Quincy and was told the staff who was on duty was at a training. LPA will attempt at a later date.

photos and text messages during record review. The facility verified the maintenance worker is not directly employed by the facility, but the facility was aware of the maintenance workers derogatory comments and violation of confidentiality. Conflicting information was provided by facility staff regarding whether timely follow up was done with the Property Management company and maintenance worker. On 4/3/2024, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall conducted an interview with facility Operations Manager Zach Anderson. Anderson indicated he had a conversation with the Property Management company regarding the inappropriate conduct of the maintenance worker, but could not recall the date of the conversation. Anderson indicated additional follow up will occur with the facility and Property Management company to ensure no further inappropriate conduct by maintenance staff occurs. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report and the LIC-9099C were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

During the course of the investigation, LPA Pope conducted additional interviews with two staff members, one THP participant, and one children’s services social worker. LPA Pope reviewed records from the facility including: LIC 500, participant file and lease agreement, Notice to Enter, 30 Day Contract, Serious Incident reports, and Copies of Text Messages and Photos. The maintenance worker then took photos of the unit and texted derogatory comments about the participant to another participant. LPA Pope observed the

narrative:
Discussions between C1 and RP were about multiple sexual partners, attraction(s) between C1 and RP, "love being expansive and impossible to compartmentalize", being "fluid and undefinable at times", and C1 or RP having emotionally involved communications between them. One of the messages uncovered stated "we have a connection & we care about each other". The allegation that RP engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the facility is related to this inappropriate contact, conversations and communications between C1 and RP. In addition, Investigator Burton received information that C1 and RP were found by a third party sleeping clothed together in the same bed at least one time and a picture showing that C1 and RP in clothes and in bed together (not the same incidents). RP was told that C1 may have had a crush on RP but RP did not stop the inappropriate messages or communications and even admitted that communications between C1 and RP were emotionally involved. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that resource parent had an inappropriate relationship with client in care and resource parent engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the facility are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84072(d) Personal Rights. Investigation shows that RP carried on an inappropriate relationship with C1 that appeared to be emotionally abusive in nature. These discussions included content of a sexual nature and were inappropriate as the nature of the relationship was that of care provider/mentor and youth in care. Facility cited for violation of Health and Safety §1569.58(a)(2) Officers, directors and employees of licensed facility... Investigation shows that staff engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare or safety of an individual in or receiving services from the facility, or the people of the State of California as it relates to the inappropriate contact, conversations and communications between C1 and RP. Exit interview conducted with Kitty Cannon and document provided.

When interviewed, C1 alleged that the relationship between C1 and RP was "intimate and very sexual" but denied there was sexual intercourse or penetration or other contact of a sexual nature. C1 denied that C1 and RP ever kissed but did make statements about inappropriate touching over the clothing that could not be corroborated. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that resource parent had an inappropriate sexual relationship with a client in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Kitty Cannon.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores made an unannounced complaint inspection on 12/30/21 and met with Kitty Cannon, Office Manager to discuss the findings of the complaint allegations. LPA informed Kitty Cannon that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection of the facility on 9/23/2021 by LPA Walker-Flores. However, files were unable to be reviewed due to a lack of documentation provided by the agency. Investigator Shannan Borton, Investigations Branch, conducted this complaint investigation. A review of documentation provided by another facility for resource parent, (RP, see confidential names list titled 12/30/21) was conducted. This resource parent was employed at a group home where they were introduced to the client. Interviews were conducted for current staff and clients, and other individuals relevant to the investigation from 8/6/21 through 10/21/21. LPA informed Kitty Cannon that the allegation that RP had an inappropriate relationship with a client in care is related to the relationship between C1 and RP. Investigation shows that RP and their partner allowed C1 to move into their home through an independent living arrangement overseen by this agency. While C1 was in the home, investigation showed that there was inappropriate contact and conversations between C1 and RP as demonstrated by text messages and photos obtained by the investigator. Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 i.e. To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, corporal punishment, and exploitation. This standard was not met as evidenced by investigation showed that RP had an inappropriate relationship with C1 that appeared to be emotionally abusive in nature. Discussions included content of a sexual nature and were inappropriate as the nature of the relationship was that of care provider/mentor and youth in care which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word met with Administrator Melody King, on 6/2/2022 at 11:30AM to discuss the complaint investigation. The California Department of Social Services, Fiscal and Performance Audits Bureau, conducted an audit review for the allegations: Facility is misusing funds, and Board of Directors is not ensuring a fiscally responsible budget. The purpose of the audit was to evaluate the financial condition of the Provider’s program. The scope of the audit included a review of the Provider’s financial records for the audit period including, but not limited to, the general ledger, invoices, receipts, canceled checks, bank statements, credit card statements, lease agreements, DMV registrations, and internal control procedures also, the CDSS auditors reviewed pertinent records related to the Board of Directors, such as the Articles of Incorporation, bylaws, and Board Minutes. During the audit period, the audit disclosed some concerns regarding the Provider’s program operations related to unallowable or unsupported costs that were disallowed, internal control issues, and oversight by the Board of Directors. Please see continuation page 9099C

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Robyn Word and Tina Thorn made an unannounced annual inspection on 4/26/2023 at 9:50 AM and met with Katelyn Pomeroy- Social Worker and Administrator Melody King and toured the agency inside and out. The THP+FC is in a shopping plaza. The THP+FC shares an office with the Foster Family Agency and CalAim. THP+FC files/records are in the front office and kept in locked file cabinet. License is posted for Transitional Housing Placement Program. LPA observed that the disaster plan is posted as required. Bathroom facilities are available for client and visitor use and appeared to be clean and sanitary as required. LPA observed office space for private interviews as necessary. LPA observed the temperature of the office space to be comfortable. Fire extinguisher is mounted and tagged as inspected on July 25, 2022. THP+FC is licensed to serve 62 clients, ages 18-21. Clients are housed throughout different counties. There are currently 6 clients in the THP+FC program and 1 staff/ Case Worker assigned to the 6 placements. The office area is clean. The LPAs did observe water damage on the ceiling area. The Administrator stated that a maintenance request was sent to the building manager on 4/10/23. LPA’s requested proof of follow-up with Property Manager within 30 days. LPA reviewed 3 of the 6 client files, and staff files including the Case Worker file and the Administrator file. Staff and client files are secured. The copy of license is posted. A review of records indicate staff have criminal record and child abuse clearance. CPR and First Aid certification and training hours are complete. There are no title 22 deficiencies cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility

On 05/22/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yesenia Vallejo, and LPA Aleza Ruiz arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Abby Hoekstra, Office Manager. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a required Bi-Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Bi-Annual inspection for the facility was on 04/26/2023. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has three offices for social workers/case managers and two confidential interview/visitation rooms on the second floor. LPA observed the proper postings including, facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files were stored electronically with password protection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has three Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in either host homes or remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs one Case Manager, and one Supervisor/Program Manager. LPA reviewed one Case manager personnel files, and one Supervisor/Program Manager files. Both personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for each personnel.

LPA was unable to interview Case Manger as they're out on leave. LPA was unable to interview Supervisor/Program Manager due to being out of office during time of inspection. LPA will conduct a phone interview. LPA reviewed three client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Facility is issued two citations per CCR 86065(f)(4) and 86064(h). A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C and LIC809D report was provided to Abby Hoekstra, Office Manager. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal Rights were provided.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an announced Prelicensing Inspection at the agency and met with THP Director (TD) Jenna Bethancourt, who assisted with the inspection. The agency is relocating from their Woodland THPP Office. The office is located in an office building. The THPP will continue to serve up to 150 participants. Once licensed, the agency will convert licensed information over to current placements. TD confirmed knowledge that all units must be within a 2-hour drive from this office. The program plans to utilize remote sites and host-homes. LPA, TD, and Office Manager Asifa Ali conducted a walk-through of the agency. LPA observed a lobby, and a side office area, three visits rooms, two kitchens, four bathrooms, two conference rooms, one file room, one lounge, five office work spaces, two storage garages/warehouses, and one storage closet. LPA observed all spaces to be clean, free of hazards, and equipped adequately with all needed supplies. LPA observed there to be multiple carbon monoxide detectors and smoke detectors, and three fire extinguishers which are up to date. LPA observed the file cabinets to be locked, which is where the agency will store client and staff records. LPA observed five first aid kits in the office. All sharps, and chemicals/cleaning solutions are locked. LPA observed posted childrens' rights, the complaint/grievance policy and forms posted. LPA observed no deficiencies. The agency has submitted all required documents for the relocation. The agency is ready for licensure, dated 3/23/2022. An exit interview was conducted with TD and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt, which will serve as the record of receipt.

Faith Samuels Foster Youth (FY1) Nicole Robinson Resource Parent (Former) (RP) Jamie Cobabe Supervisor for Sacramento Office (Sup) On 2.14.2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jennifer Baca arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting a Case management visit on the death of a Foster Youth on February 9. LPA met with Jamie Cobabe Supervisor for the Sacramento office. The Foster Youth was in a fatal car accident on February 9th, 2023. The Foster Youth had filled out a beneficiary designation form and had listed the former Resource parent Nicole Robinson as the beneficiary. The Resource parent will be in the office on 2.14.23 at 2pm to gather the Foster Youths belongings, and to gather FY belongings from her apartment. There is no other information at this time. LPA Baca received copies of the Foster Youths file and a copy of the Beneficiary delegation Form. Sup stated that they asked the RP to follow up with the agency if there would be a service for the FY as they would like to assist in the arrangements. A copy of this report was left with Supervisor for Sacramento office Jamie Cobabe

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Annual Inspection at the agency and met with Agency Social Worker Supervisor (SWS) Jamie Cobabe, who assisted with the inspection. LPA and SWS conducted a walk-through of the facility and LPA observed: two conference rooms, one file room, seven office spaces, two storage areas, one pantry, two kitchens, three visitation rooms, a staff lounge, the lobby, and four bathrooms. LPA observed no deficiencies. All fire extinguishers were in date and charged. All client files were locked. All areas of the building were clean, in good repair, and had no obstructions in the walkways. There are working smoke detectors. LPA reviewed five staff files and five client files. LPA found that 8 of 15 staff who work at this THPP license are not associated to the license. However, all 15 are DOJ/FBI/CACI cleared and associated to the agency's Sacramento FFA license. LPA found that all other staff requirements were met. For client files LPA found that the Administrator does not sign the Needs and Services Plans as required. One out of five NSPs were out of date, and the one that was out of date, was being drafted. All other requirements for client files were met. LPA interviewed two Social Workers, one Case Manager, and one Social Work Supervisor. On this date the agency was cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86019(e)(2) and Health and Safety Code (HSC) 1565(a)(7). All citations and advisory notes are reflected in the 809 for the Post Licensing, issued on the same date. An exit interview was conducted with SWS and a copy of this report, appeal rights, and confidential names list was left with her.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection regarding an Incident Report that occurred on 4/7/2023 and was submitted to CCL by the agency on 4/10/2023. LPA spoke with Social Work Supervisor (SWS) Jamie Cobabe and Case Manager (CM) Wendy Sanchez-Rico about the incident. LPA collected a client's Needs and Services Plan, staff information, and client information. Further information is needed in order to resolve this case management. LPA conducted an exit interview with SWS and left a copy of this report with her.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an announced Case Management inspection at the facility to interview Director Jenna Bethancourt, regarding an Incident Report that occurred on 4/7/2023 and was submitted to CCL by the agency on 4/10/2023. LPA first opened this CM inspection on 4/17/2023. LPA interviewed Director and collected client documents. Further information is needed in order to resolve this case management. LPA conducted an exit interview with Director and gave a copy of this report to her.

In LPA's review of the Premise Report, collected from the Sacramento Sheriff's Department, it lists out all Calls for Service made by members of the public, at or tied to the apartment complex address, from January 2020 through Present 2023. There were 280 total calls for service, some of which were four for shots fired, two assault, one sexual assault, 15 battery, six assault with a deadly weapon, 90 disturbances, four threats with a gun or other weapon, three threats, five burglary, one petty theft, one grand theft, one auto theft, three vandalism, four trespassing, two suspicious vehicles, and eight suspicious circumstances. These records only show what kind of call was made, not where the violation occurred, so it is possible not all of these events occurred at the apartment complex, however were reported by individuals at the complex, or about individuals at the complex. In LPA's review of the Case Notes provided, LPA found instances where maintenance was needed for minor issues, such as the heater pilot being out and a broken closet door, and the EA Case Manager (CM) assisted the client in getting those problems fixed. There were no concerns reported about insect issues. In Case Notes from 2020, when the client was first placed in November 2020, the client was not happy with the apartment due to safety concerns about personal conflicts with individuals in the community, and requested a change. EA then moved the client to the apartments the client then resided in from December 2020 to February 2023, to ensure the client felt safe. More current Case Notes from 2023 also detail how CM was helping the client get what they needed in regard to school, employment, and certifications. There were many entries which detailed all of CM’s efforts in working with the client on getting the client an apartment they wanted, and supporting the client through their decisions. In several case notes it shows that CM was working on getting the client into another apartment of their choosing in 2023, however the client was indecisive about where the client actually wanted to live, whether it be with EA, a SILP, or with their spouse. The apartment the client was thinking about choosing was also out of EA's reasonable price range. The client went ahead with moving plans without speaking to, or working with EA at times, which led C1 to voluntarily leaving EA. Most recently, on 4/23/2023, the client submitted an inquiry about coming back to EA.

LPA also observed the environment of the apartments. LPA did observe a bullet hole in the hallway of one of the buildings, pointed out to LPA by a tenant. This tenant stated that had been there since before the tenant lived there, which is over four years ago. LPA also observed one bullet hole in the face of the building to the right of the vending machines, and a bullet mark on the vending machine cage itself. It is unclear when those marks were made. LPA observed many children out and playing together, as well as several adults going about their business. LPA observed all individuals to appear homed, and non-suspicious. LPA did not observe any criminal activity while she was at the apartment complex. When LPA conducted interviews with the six randomly selected tenants, LPA could observe the apartments, to varying degrees whether LPA went inside or not, and observed all spaces to be modernized, and in good condition. LPA did not observe any bugs or other pests. When LPA did a walk-through of the apartment unit related to this complaint specifically, LPA also observed it to be clean, semi-modernized, and without bugs or other pests. Confidential interviews conducted revealed the following: In LPA's interviews with the Intake Workers, Director, Case Manager, and Social Work Supervisor, it was confirmed that it is the client's choice to accept an apartment, and if they do not approve of it, EA will work to find a better match for the client. During LPA's interview with the Case Manager, he stated he never observed any insects. LPA Burgess and LPA Monica Roberts requested in total three times, the photographic evidence from the individual involved, of the insects which were alleged to have been in the apartment, however LPA never received them. In LPA's interview with the Property Manager (PM), there were no records of insects being reported as an issue in the client's unit, however, the PM also stated that they will do regular preventative insect spraying. All six randomly-selected tenants, and the one current EA client, that LPA interviewed stated they felt safe at the apartment, and some reported small issue with children running around with trash, or the homeless coming into the complex. PM also stated that all issues that were reported to her by the client were addressed by maintenance. PM stated that the area is a rough area, but has improved since she has come to the complex in May of 2021, and they have gotten new tenants.

In LPA's interview with the Deputy, it was confirmed that the area is a, "dangerous," area with drugs, gangs, homelessness, poverty, and struggles; however, many areas of Sacramento are like that, and at the same time, you will see children walking home from school, and regular non-criminal daily life. Additionally, the Deputy explained that the clients are adults and can choose whether or not to live there. LPA was also made aware in this interview that bullet holes/shootings happen in all areas of Sacramento, not only apartments such as this one. Based on all information collected and interviews conducted, LPA found that the area the apartment is in does have crime and dangers, however that is common in other areas as well. LPA learned that tenants feel safe, and Property Management addresses concerns. LPA found that EA Case Manager worked to support and assist the client in meeting their needs and helping them to get what they want as well. LPA also found that the clients have the final say-so in where they will be placed and can reject a placement, as well as EA will move them if they feel unsafe. LPA was informed there were cockroaches in the apartment by one individual, however saw no evidence of this, and did not receive evidence to prove such. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with SWS and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with her.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the agency and met with Social Work Supervisor (SWS), who assisted with the inspection. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Case Management Inspection at the facility and met with Office Manager (OM) Brittany Johnson who assisted with the inspection. On 3/16/2023, LPA conducted a Post-Licensing inspection and cited the agency for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86019(e)(2) which stated: (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Request a transfer of a criminal record clearance as specified in Section 86019(f) or... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on records review, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in 8 out of 15 staff which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. Civil penalty was assessed. The agency appealed this citation and civil penalty. After review and consideration, the citation and civil penalty were upheld, however, the Department agreed to downgrade the Type-A citation to a Type-B citation. LPA is re-citing the citation as a Type-B, and the Type-A citation will be dismissed. The agency has already cleared this deficiency as required. An exit interview was conducted with OM, and a copy of this report and citation clearance letter was left with her.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection regarding an Incident Report (IR) that occurred on 4/7/2023 and was submitted to CCL by the agency on 4/10/2023. LPA met with Case Manager Wendy Sanchez, who assisted with the inspection. The IR reported that on 4/7/2023 client's (C1 - See Confidential Names List dated 5/15/2023) EA Case Manager (CM) called Adult Protective Services for C1 due to C1 living in filth with rotting food, unwashed clothes, and trash throughout C1's apartment. The CM that was present reported bad smells in the apartment. C1 was non-coherent and could not verbally communicate. C1 had been neglecting C1's basic needs, and EA was unsure if C1 was eating, maintaining personal hygiene, or their healthcare. LPA conducted an investigation into whether Environmental Alternatives - SAC THPP/THP+FC (EA) was an appropriate placement for C1 or not, by conducting confidential interviews with the County Social Worker, EA's Social Work Supervisor, EA's Case Manager, EA's THPP Director, and EA's Intake Coordinator on 4/17/2023, 4/26/2023, 5/11/2023, and 5/18/2023. LPA also collected and reviewed C1's Pre-Placement Questionnaire (PPQ), "New-Add" email, other emails, Needs and Services Plan, pictures, and TILP. Based on the records reviewed, LPA found that C1 was placed with EA on 11/15/2022, after leaving a mental health facility by 11/10/2022. In C1's PPQ, it notes that C1 has a, "low level of functioning or ability to be independent," in the area of taking C1's medication for C1's mental health. It also states that C1 had been 5150'd on 10/11/2022, and then went to another mental health facility afterwards, where C1 lived until C1 was placed with EA. C1 has had suicidal behavior or thoughts before, but there were no

additional details provided. The PPQ states C1 has a need for intensive mental health or wrap services, however none were described. The PPQ acknowledged that C1 most likely is on psychotropic medication, however C1 refuses to take C1's medications. Additionally, C1 has not developed positive anger management and coping skills, and no further details were provided. C1 struggles with impulse control and has no positive lifelong connections. C1 does not demonstrate positive relationship skills with peers, and no details were provided. C1 has had major behavioral episodes, for which C1 was placed in a mental health hospital. C1 has a history of substance abuse and ongoing substance abuse issues in that C1 has admitted to using meth, "and whatever else [C1] can get ahold of." C1 has threatened a roommate with a knife in the past. C1 is receiving mental health services, however refuses to cooperate with utilizing those services. C1 was placed in a specialized apartment which has on-site case managers of sorts, which are not affiliated with EA who provide additional support to clients and work with EA's Case Managers, though the level in which they do this was not made clear. During an interview, it was confirmed that C1 had drug paraphernalia (crack pipe and bong) in C1's apartment, located when EA had the apartment cleaned when C1 went to the hospital. Another crack pipe was located in C1's apartment previously on 3/1/2023 as well. During interviews it was confirmed that C1 continuously struggled with maintaining their apartment, never was compliant in managing their mental health or adhering to the program, and that both EA and the specialized apartment could not meet C1's needs. Most recently C1 was released from hospitalization on 4/28/2023, then re-hospitalized on 5/3/2023 for hallucinating, and returned to placement on 5/16/2023. EA CM observed C1 to be high on 5/16/2023 on something other than marijuana. During LPA's interviews, LPA asked why EA gave C1 placement knowing C1's unmanaged mental health, recent hospitalizations, unmanaged drug-use, and general inability to care for themself. LPA was informed it was essentially a, "favor," to the County, who was struggling to find placement for the client, and to build a positive relationship with the County. During multiple interviews it was confirmed that EA cannot meet the needs of C1.

EA has accepted C1 back into the program after discharge from the hospital on a Behavioral Contract, signed by C1 on 5/1/2023, requiring C1 to be compliant in managing C1's mental health services and medications. However, this should have been the standard since the beginning of C1's placement. Based on an interview, C1 is still not being compliant in their program or addressing their mental health and drug use. LPA reviewed C1's Needs and Services Plan which details mental health management as C1's main need to focus on and that, "it is recommended that this client be placed in a transitional housing program with more support and assistance to help with the client's mental health needs. The current placement is not ideal for the client's needs." Since being in placement, C1 has been hospitalized two times, however there has been more than four 5150's. THPPs are the least-restrictive facility type in the Children's Residential Program. Based on all information collected and interviews conducted, LPA has found that C1's placement in EA's THPP was inappropriate and detrimental to their well-being. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the AB12 Interim Licensing Standards for Nonminor Dependents in Foster Care, Chapter 7, Transitional Housing Placement Program, Version 2, Section 86278(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted with CM and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with CM.

deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the
needs of a nonminor dependent.
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records review and interviews, the agency violated this section by inappropriately accepting the client into the program and failing to meet their needs while they were in the program. This is an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: C1's dishcharge plan is to be submitted to CCL by POC due date of 5/19/2023.

narrative: On 3/7/24, LPA Uchenna Ajaero received the following report and discussed it with the LPA. Per LPM, Jodean Hall, this investigation will be handled with a follow up phone call. DESCRIBE EVENT OR INCIDENT (INCLUDE DATE, TIME, LOCATION, PERPETRATOR, NATURE OF INCIDENT, ANY ANTECEDENTS LEADING UP TO INCIDENT AND HOW CLIENTS WERE AFFECTED, INCLUDING ANY INJURIES The client was in THP placement at the Renew on Coloma apartment complex. Maintenance was repairing the dishwasher and had the heater running to try to assess why the heater was not working. The client shared that the heater caught fire and it disintegrated on its own. Fire did not create further damage. Fire department or LE was not called. Maintenace removed the smoke detector from the ceiling and told client that he would come back to repair the heater at another time. 3/14 LPA Ajaero contacted the SW and was told the property management office has submitted a request to have the unit fixed. 3/22 ASW Nicole contacted LPA and stated the unit has been fixed and the client is settled in the apartment. End of report.

On 12/07/2020, at approximately 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted a case management inspection in this program's Sacramento office located at 4221 Northgate Blvd., Ste. 3 Sacramento 94834. The purpose of this inspection was to follow up on the reported deaths of two Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) participants on 12/06/2020 (confirmation of date and time of deaths pending coroner's report). LPA was assisted on-site by Social Worker Amber Elam and Office Assistant Kaybrien Douglas. The clients' files were reviewed. This inspection will be continued at a later date.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) made an unannounced visit to the facility to conduct case management inspection regarding an incident report received by the Department on 6/25/2021. LPA met with Miranda Benavidez, Case Manager (CM), who assisted with the inspection. The incident which occurred on 6/17/2021 involved a client of the THPP attempting suicide by cutting both of her wrists with a knife while in the apartment. The client's fiance was also present in the apartment. Law enforcement, the fire department, and ambulance were on the scene. The client was taken to the hospital and treated, then was placed on a 5150 hold. Law enforcement believed there to be domestic violence from the fiance to the client. The agency wrote in the IR the fiance will no longer be allowed in the apartment. LPA asked questions regarding: 1. How is, and where is, the client currently. 2. How will the agency ensure the client's fiance is not present. 3. How will the agency ensure the client's safety. 4. Is this a proper placement of the client. 5. What oversight and support is provided for this client. 6. What is the agency's future plans for this client. CM stated that she has been contacting the client weekly to check in. CM also called in a wellness check, and conducted a wellness check herself, after the incident. The client is back at the apartment, and the fiance is not allowed on the property, however they were spotted off property engaged in an argument on 6/23/2021. CM, the County Social Worker, and the client will be meeting on 7/8/2021 to discuss safety plan and safety measures to take. In the meantime, LPA has advised CM to make contact with the client daily by phone to ensure she is safe. CM is also going to be getting the client into therapy as well as in contact with WEAVE for support with domestic violence. At 2:29 PM an exit interview was conducted with CM and a copy of this report will be emailed to CM with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

met_with: Jamie George, THP Case Manager/FFA Social Worker
narrative: Interviews and documents reviewed are also consistent that the apartment was in good repair at the time of placement. The challenge is how the agency handled the problems that happened afterwards. CSW, NMD and RP state that the agency did not act in a timely manner and that put NMD and her children in danger. However, Interviews with PM and ASW indicate that the agency put a request to address the problems right away. In addition, PM shared that NMD refused entry into her apartment when maintenance crew arrived at the location. The agency also disclosed that they will pay NMD’s relocation fees and return all NMD’s savings to her. Based on LPA’s observation, interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allege violations did or did not occur. Not tile 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspections. A copy of this report was left at the agency.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/1/2021 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) N. Sanders and Stephannie Verna arrived at the above agency for the purpose of delivering the complaint investigation findings. LPAs met with Jamie George, THP Case Manager/FFA Social Worker and informed her about the findings. The allegation is that living unit in which non-minor dependent was placed is in despair and living unit in which non-minor dependent was placed has cockroaches. LPA initiated a complaint investigation at the agency on 5/27/2021. Interviews were conducted with Agency Social Worker (ASW), Reporting Party (RP), Non-Minor Dependent (NMD), Property Manager (PM) and County Social Worker (CSW) on 5/26/2021, 5/27/2021, 6/10/2021, 6/15/2021 and 6/29/2021. Interviews are consistent about the apartment being in despair because of water leak, mold and cockroaches.

narrative: On September 23, 2021 Licensed Program Analyst Chad Cabigon (LPA), and Yuvi Diaz (LPA) conducted an announced case management inspection due to a death report received byThe Department on September 22, 2021. LPAs obtain copies of the participant's entire THP file. Phone interview was conducted with the assigned Program Case Manager, Ellie Fanaika. Further investigation is required.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the agency and met with Office Manager (OM) Donna Massey, who assisted with this inspection. The facility utilizes their Sacramento FFA office as a satellite office for this license, where the majority of clients are assisted from. Only two clients are in care out of this office. As the files are electronic LPA was able to access them from the licensed location. LPA utilized the CARE Tool for this inspection. LPA conducted a walk-through of the agency with (OM) and LPA observed no deficiencies. LPA reviewed 14 client files, and 10 staff files. LPA found that all clients reviewed did not have any health screenings or TB tests on file, however, all clients are Non-Minor Dependents and are not required to share medical information with the agency. LPA found that one client did not have a Needs and Services Plan in the file as required after 30 days in placement. One client (C7) was missing their NSP, but today is the 30th day, so LPA advised the facility to ensure they include the NSP for that client in their file. Client C6 should have their NSP in file, and a Type B Citation was issued for that deficiency. There were no other issues found in client files. For the staff files, LPA found that no file had any of the staffs' duties described, and a Technical Violation was issued for that. No other issues were found during this inspection. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Section 86068.2(c), Type B. Additionally, LPA issued an advisory note regarding the address and facility information that the agency puts on their incident reports for this license. An exit interview was conducted with OM, and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights and a confidential names list, was emailed to her with a read receipt, which will serve as the record of receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the agency and met with Donna Massey, Office Manager (OM1), who assisted with the inspection. LPA is investigating a Child Abuse Clearance Index (CACI) hit that occurred for an individual connected to this agency (P1 - See LIC811). OM contacted her supervisor and the Sacramento office to find out if P1 is in any way involved with the agency. OM1 contacted individuals with the agency and found that P1 is a prospective roommate of a THPP client with this license, but based out of the satellite Sacramento office location. LPA spoke with Asifa Ali, Office Manager (OM2), who checked with the assigned case worker and found that P1 is the boyfriend of the client who has not moved in yet, awaiting fingerprint clearance. There is no paperwork for LPA to collect as the agency is awaiting the clearance before allowing P1 to move in. Further investigation is needed to conclude this case management. LPA conducted an exit interview with OM1 and a copy of this report and LIC811 was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the agency and met with Social Worker Supervisor (SWS) Mercedes Robinson, who assisted with this inspection. On 10/25/2021, CCL received an incident report which stated during the rain storm on 10/24/2021, portions of the apartment the participant lived it were severely damaged and unlivable. The participant was offered to stay in a hotel by the THPP until a remedy could be made for the apartment, however the participant found housing through a family member. LPA asked about the safety measures that were put in place for this client, and how the agency made sure the alternative residence was a safe space for the client. SWS stated the ASW inspected the home during move-in, and all was compliant. LPA also asked about the furnishings and equipment in the new residence, which SWS stated that the participant has everything he needs. LPA asked about the financial support the participant receives and if it was lowered. SWS confirmed that the participant gets no less financial support because of this move. The client intends to live at the new residence for the remainder of his time with the THPP. The new home is also within the required distance of the THPP. SWS stated that all paperwork was updated. LPA found that the THPP met the participant's needs and no further investigation is required. An exit interview was conducted with SWS and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

On 01/12/2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chad Cabigon conducted an unannounced inspection in the Environmental Alternatives (EA) - Sacramento THPP (Transitional Housing Placement Program) office located at 4221 Northgate Blvd., Sacramento 95834; the purpose of which was to formally close a case management inspection that was conducted on 12/07/2020. That inspection was regarding the deaths of two THPP participants for whom services were provided under the now-closed THPP license that was attached to the office address at 600 Cottonwood Street, Woodland. As part of the 2020 case management inspection, LPA interviewed EA personnel and other individuals who were either involved in the deceased clients' cases or had knowledge of the matter. LPA also reviewed relevant records. No deficiencies were cited as a result of the case management inspection. A copy of this report is being provided to EA.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On March 30, 2023 at approximately 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a virtual Component II session via Zoom with applicant, Environmental Alternatives. Present at the meeting from Environmental Alternatives were Jenna Bethancourt, THP Program Director and Kylie Martinez, Social Worker Supervisor. During the meeting the following items were discussed and requested: 1. LIC 308 - Add K. Martinez to LIC 308 as an individual with administrative responsibility 2. Board Resolution regarding the LIC 308 above 3. County Letter of Support Aspects such as housing locations, continuing requirements, and more were also discussed. The Pre-Licensing inspection is tentatively scheduled for Thursday, April 06, 2023. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On April 06, 2023 at approximately 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Raymond Wu and Joe Martinez conducted a pre-licensing inspection and Component III meeting at the facility. The THPP is located in the CityServe non-profit building. LPA met Kylie Martinez, Social Worker Supervisor. The program will use host families, long-term hotel units, and apartment units to place Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) participants. . Licensee will inform CCL prior to the first client moving into a living unit. A tour of the office was conducted. LPA observed the following: the office is located in a secured suite inside a large building that is professionally maintained. There is an attendant in the lobby to assist and direct visitors. The office has multiple private rooms to meet with clients. Staff members have desks, cubicles, and the necessary equipment to perform their duties. There are bathrooms for staff and client use as well as a kitchen area. Hazardous items are secured and locked away. There are file cabinets in place to secure staff and client files. Fire extinguishers and a centralized fire sprinkler system are in place. The building has a dedicated security team that patrols the exterior and interior of the building. LPAs observed the facility to be in good repair, well-equipped, and ready for operation. A Component III meeting was also held and best practices and common regulations were discussed with the applicant. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the agency.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On September 07, 2023 at approximately 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a post-licensing inspection at the facility. The THPP is located in the CityServe non-profit building. LPA met Yoana Andrade, Case Manager. The program uses host families, long-term hotel units, and apartment units to place Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) participants. A tour of the office was conducted. LPA observed the following: the office is located in a secured suite inside a large building that is professionally maintained. There is an attendant in the lobby to assist and direct visitors. The office has multiple private rooms to meet with clients. Staff members have desks, cubicles, and the necessary equipment to perform their duties. There are bathrooms for staff and client use as well as a kitchen area. Hazardous items are secured and locked away. There are file cabinets in place to secure staff and client files. Fire extinguishers and a centralized fire sprinkler system are in place. The building has a dedicated security team that patrols the exterior and interior of the building. Currently, clients are situated in an extended stay hotel that is approximately 8 minutes away from the office. Construction of apartments that are right next to the office is currently underway and clients will move to these apartments in the near future. A walk-through of a client unit was toured and no immediate concerns were observed. There is an on-site office that Case Managers utilize at the hotel. A review of client and staff records were conducted. The facility utilizes a digital filing system and all required documents for clients and staff were present. No deficiencies were cited during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On May 1, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted a case management inspection at the Transitional Housing Program (THP) Office and met Office Manager, Veronica Lopez. The purpose of the inspection was to amend the LIC 809 with deficiency citation issued to the facility on 02/28/24. On 01/24/24, a Special Incident Report (SIR) was received by the Department. The SIR indicated that on 12/30/23, participant reference #1 (P1) see Confidential Names List (LIC 811) was arguing with his girlfriend at the apartment complex and the police was called. This resulted with participant being arrested but then let go. The participant was not charged. P1's authorized representative was notified. P1 was placed in a 30-behavior contract and his girlfriend was not allowed in the apartment. LPA reviewed the client file. LPA gathered the information from the case manager (CM) that she found out about the incident from the property manager, which was not indicated on the incident report. P1 denied the incident. CM visits the apartment weekly however, P1 canceled the meeting after the incident happened. There was no update regarding the incident as P1 was not charged. Based on the information gathered, CM found out about the incident on 01/19/24 and sent the report to the Department on 01/24/24. No other information provided to LPA. After the Department received more information from licensee and upon further review, it was found that the facility notified the Department via email on 01/19/24 regarding the incident. Therefore, the citation is rescinded. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the amended LIC 809 and LIC 9102TA were provided to the facility representative. No deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection.
