A letter to that effect will be submitted to the Department by Plan of Correction (POC) date (03/04/24).

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: On 5/2/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the representative above. LPA spoke to Kylie Martinez, Social Worker Supervisor (SWS) over the phone regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on March 29, 2024. The SIR stated that Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) #1 (C1) (see confidential names form LIC 811) was raped by her boyfriend in her apartment. Census: Children 37. Based on an interview conducted with the SWS and record review (SIR), the NMD had placed a restraining order against her boyfriend, but the status of the restraining order is still pending. The Agency staff had offered the NMD medical care and support services such as domestic violence programs in which she refuse to attend. The NMD is still residing in her apartment unit and has been informed to contact her social worker, any other staff or law enforcement in case she feels unsafe. The agency is in constant contact with the NMD to ensure she feels safe. At this current moment, the boyfriend remains in jail. SWS will provide LPA with copies of the contact notes, NSP and any additional documents to support this case management via email. No further follow-up required. A technical advisory was issued for reporting requirements A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative above.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
On July 29, 2024, at 1:15 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Gilbert Gutierrez and Brent Lockhart conducted a case management inspection to the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) Office and met Office Manager, Veronica Lopez. The purpose of the inspection was to provide the amended LIC 809 with deficiency and civil penalty assessment issued to licensee on 05/16/24 due to staff (S4) see LIC 811 (Confidential Names List) has no clearance transfer and not associated to the THPP. On May 28, 2024, the Department received the appeal letter from licensee and upon management review determined that staff S4 was associated to licensee’s Foster Family Agency (FFA) on 11/07/23 and then to the THPP on 05/17/24, after the inspection. Based on the information, the deficiency citation and civil penalty assessment was dismissed. In lieu of the deficiency, an advisory note is hereby issued to licensee. The amended report will read as follows: PHYSICAL PLANT The facility license is posted in a prominent location. All participant records are maintained in a secure area or locked file cabinets in the administrative office. The administrative office has telephone service on the premises. OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS The facility maintains a register of participants available upon request. The facility is currently operating within licensing regulations. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS The facility has an emergency and disaster plan for the THPP NMD participants. The emergency plan shall include emergency information, instructions, and telephone numbers, including a 24-hour emergency number for the licensee and the participant’s responsible party.

STAFF RECORDS There is a total of nine (9) staff; three (3) of which are full time case managers and one (1) social worker supervisor. Staff records are available upon request. The agency complies with client to social worker ratio. The Program Director of placement program meets the education and experience requirements, completed the required training, file contains the Statement acknowledging requirement to report child abuse, fingerprint, and child abuse index check clearances and current with CPR and first aid. CLIENT RECORDS The facility currently has thirty-six (36) transitional housing placement participants ages 18-21 years old. The facility ensured the participants record are maintained locked on site in the THPP office. At the time of the inspection, participant 3's NSP was not signed by her and by her authorized representative. LPAs reviewed five (5) personnel records, five (5) participant’s record (refer to Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 05/16/24) and interviewed two (2) staff. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the amended LIC 809, LIC 809C and LIC 9102TV were provided to the facility representative. A deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative:
Confidential interviews were completed on 06/19/24, 08/28/24, 09/16/24. LPA Martinez attempted to interview FY1 on 07/26/24, 08/26/24, and 09/04/24. Despite these multiple attempts, no statements were successfully gathered from FY1. 1. Failure to Provide Reasonable Accommodations and Adequate Support Confidential interviews revealed that FY1 was assisted in starting the application process for housing. FY1 application was initially denied due to concerns about FY1 communication style and behavior. The decision was later reconsidered, leading to an offer of housing. Interviews also disclosed evidence from FY1 indicating FY1 decision not to move forward with the placement. FY1 was not an official client but was being considered for placement LPA Martinez attempted to interview FY1 on 07/26/24, 08/26/24, and 09/04/24. Despite these multiple attempts, no statements were successfully gathered from FY1. 2.Discrimination and Retaliation Against the Client Confidential interviews revealed no direct evidence of discrimination or retaliation. FY1 was not an official client but was being considered for placement. FY1 application was initially denied due to concerns about communication style and behavior.The decision was later reconsidered by the THPP leading to an offer of housing. Interviews also disclosed evidence from FY1 indicating decision not to move forward with the placement. LPA Martinez attempted to interview FY1 on 07/26/24, 08/26/24, and 09/04/24. Despite these multiple attempts, no statements were successfully gathered from FY1.

Based on the confidential interviews and records reviewed, the complaint against the THPP is unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated determination means the allegation lacks a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided a signed LIC 9099 to the STRTP representative.
investigation_findings: 13On 09/20/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP).LPA Martinez met with the facility representative named above. The purpose of the inspection is to deliver the finding for the above allegations. On 06/18/24, the Community Care Licensing Division of the California Department of Social Services received a complaint from the Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegation(s): 1.Failure to Provide Reasonable Accommodations and Adequate Support 2.Discrimination and Retaliation Against the Client LPA Martinez investigated the above allegation. The investigation included a review of records and confidential interviews, but it was not limited to these.

facility_name: ENVIRONMENTAL ALTERNATIVES DBA: EA FAMILY SERVICES
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robyn Word made an announced pre-licensing inspection on 1/10/21 at 1:30 PM and met with Lee Peters, Office Manager. LPA toured the office space that will be jointly used for Foster Family Agencies and Transitional Housing Placement Programs. LPA observed the main office to have a reception area and a file area where all of the files are locked and inaccessible to individuals without keys. LPA observed that there is an adequate amount of privacy for interviews and office meeting space as well as storage. There is an office space for Social Workers. LPA observed eight smoke detectors in the office space. The facility has provided a program statement that has been approved. The agency is ready to be licensed for the Transitional Housing Program at this time. The Transitional Housing Program will serve nonminor dependents this is the population to be served with this license at this time. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to the Office Manager.

On 1/23/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Uchenna Ajaero, made an unannounced Annual Required Inspection visit to the agency. However, FAS did not provide the option for the Annual Required button in the 'Type of Visit' Window. Therefore, the Case management - Annual Continuation button was utilized for this Annual Required Inspection. LPM, Jodean Hall was notified. LPA met Dale Giddings, Social Worker Supervisor, (SWS) and Naomi Hatch, Agency Social Worker (ASW) and informed them of the purpose of the visit. LPA Ajaero inspected and reviewed Postings of facility license, Personal Rights Poster, Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures appeared to be in good repair, no leaks and delivering hot water. LPA observed there to be soap and paper towels available in the bathrooms. The Office was clean and organized. The LPA reviewed records for the THP program. The agency uses a computer database for record keeping. The Agency HR Supervisor, Sara Bodenham issued a log in ID and password for LPA to access files. THPP records show that staff members meet education and experience requirements, as listed in the LIC 859. Currently there are two THPP clients admitted. Agency Social Worker (ASW) Naomi Hatch stated that due to the fact that these youths are between the ages of 18 through 25 years, they retain the right to what documents they provide the Agency. Tthey have 2 other clients whose admission is still pending. Clients are provided accommodation at apartments. The agency is contacted by either the youth, probation officers and or County Case Workers. The apartments are in Redding, California. LPA is not inspecting them at this time. No citation was issued at this time. Exit interview was conducted. LPA provided a copy of this report to Dale Giddings, Social Worker Supervisor

LPA observed minor repairs needed inside client’s apartment, which could be addressed by the management company and were not a health or safety issue for the client. The heater was not functioning for several weeks, but the ASW and management company addressed it. The client was given a portable heater until the heater was repaired. The ASW was responsive to the calls from the client and assisted by contacting the apartment management company on several occasions for the client. The agency addressed the client’s minor pest control problem by ensuring there were two separate visits to the unit by a pest control company. In addition, the ASW dropped off several cans of bugs spray to the client. The client never contacted the property management company regarding the minor repairs needed. Work orders placed were done so by the ASW and were regarding the heater and pests. It is unclear if client was aware they were responsible for contacting the property management company for maintenance. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. No citation were given. A copy of this report was electronically sent at the time of the visit. An exit interview was conducted.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/13/2023 at 1:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced and met with Reese Howell Offcie manger for the purpose of delivering the complaint findings into the allegations listed above. LPA delivered findings in person to 1138 Shasta St, Redding, CA 96001. On 4/18/2023 LPA McKinley conducted an unannounced complaint investigation and interviewed Naomi Hatch, Agency Social Worker. LPA discussed the allegations and requested the following documents: Needs and Services, Case Notes, accounting records, copies of Transitional Housing Placement agreement and placement agency agreements for five clients. LPA inspected the client’s apartment on 4/18/2023. During the investigation, LPA interviewed the reporting party, one client, two facility staff, two county social workers, and three property management staff. LPA conducted a records review. continued on 9099- C page

narrative:
On 9/05/2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Lacy Weinberg Office Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Bi-Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Bi-Annual inspection for the facility was on 1/23/2023. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has five offices for social workers and three confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files were stored in locking file cabinets. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has 0 minor clients and 6 Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs 1 Social Worker/ Case Manager, and 1 of Supervisors/Program Manager. LPA reviewed 1 Social Worker personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Social Worker personnel. LPA interviewed 1 social worker personnel. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed 3 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate

supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C report was provided to Lacy Weinberg Office Manager. An exit interview was conducted.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by the Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto on 08/31/20 at 9:30 AM via Facetime due to Covid19 pandemic. LPA met with THPP/THP +FC Case Manager Social Worker, Brittney Ibarra and discussed the incident. LPA discussed a 24-hour incident report submitted to Community Care Licensing on August 28, 2020 concerning an incident that transpired at the THPP+FC client’s apartment. CCL was notified that client 1 (Refer to confidential names, LIC 811) called the Emergency Medical Technician and when they arrived at her apartment, she assaulted them. Client 1 got in her vehicle and accelerated through the parking lot hitting a male pedestrian, 61 years old. Client 1 drove toward a male victim a 37-year-old Stockton Fire Fighter. The Fire Fighter had to jump out of the way to keep from getting hit. Client 1 was located by Stockton Police Department and was arrested for Assault & Battery and Hit and Run. Client is out on bail. Case Manager will follow up with LPA regarding this incident. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with case manager. A copy of this report was emailed to case manager for signature.

met_with: Anna Garrison, Program, THPP Program Director
narrative:
Due to COVID19 restrictions, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted an unannounced tele-visit case management inspection to the facility on 12/03/20 at 2:00 PM. LPA made contact with THPP Program Director, Anna Garrison regarding an incident. Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an incident report dated 11/18/20. The incident pertained to C1 participating in a THPP/THP+FC program. C1 received a 30 day notice from the property manager due to damage to her apartment. While C1 was on the phone with her Case Manager (CM), C1 went to the Property manager's office to discuss the 30 day notice that she received. During the conversation CM heard scuffle and raised voices. C1 and property manager were arguing back and forth. The police was called and a report was made. CM stated she heard Sgt and Officer state that they could see the property manager pushing and kicking C1 in the office video, however, the property manager felt threatened as C1 was being aggressive and threatening to property manager. The Officers stated that property manager could use force necessary to remove C1 from her office. C1 was upset that the police did not do anything about the situation. C1 argued and cussed at both the Officer and Sgt. C1 made threatening remarks about "beating the shit" out of property manager. C1 went to look for property manager and found her in her car. CM could hear C1 on the phone telling the property manager to get out of her car. C1 informed CM that she had popped the property manager's tires with a knife.

C1 informed Case Manager that she wanted to fight the property manager. Program Director and Case Manager have attempted to work with C1 regarding incidents that have been harmful to herself and others and have put safety plans in place. However, EA-THPP will be discharging client from their THPP + FC program on December 17, 2020, which lines up with the 30 day notice from the property management. County Social Worker has been informed regarding the incidents and the discharge. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the THPP Program Director.

met_with: Deally Curran, Agency Social Worker Supervisor
narrative: Due to COVID-19 restrictions pandemic, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a case management unannounced tele-visit on 03/17/21 at 3:00 PM. LPA spoke with Agency Social Worker Supervisor, (ASWS) Deally Curran regarding the death of C1 placed in the THPP program. ASWS stated the C1 was found deceased by client’s adult foster brother in the home in the morning. The Sheriff and Ambulance were called out to the home. From the information received by LPA, at this time there is no evidence that the cause of death was a result of any action or inaction by the client. ASWS stated the Stanislaus County Social Worker Supervisor jointly arrived at the home when the Sheriff and the Ambulance arrived. The Sheriff stated, it will take about four to six weeks to find a cause of death. ASWS will follow up with LPA regarding the cause of death. At the time of this report, the cause of death had not yet been determined. No deficiencies were cited on today's tele-visit. An exit interview was conducted. This document was emailed to Agency Social Worker Supervisor for signature.

LPA informed Ms. Curran the allegation that the licensee failed to make payments on the nonminor dependent's apartment in a timely manner is substantiated since S1 admitted to the leasing agency and documented in C1's file that the late fees were Environmental Alternative's responsibility and not C1's. As a result of the information obtained and documentation reviewed, the complaint allegation is SUBSTANTIATED meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility was cited for violation of Title 22 Division Six Section 86022(a)(4)(I) Plan of Operation. The plan of operation states that the monies received by the participants pay the expenses of rent, utilities, telephone, transportation, food...It further states that the participant's continued eligibility hinges on "paying bills on time". In addition, the plan of operation states that THP+FC/THPP staff...shall assist in payment of bills, conferring with the payee when necessary to insure payment has been made. There is no evidence that this was done as the leasing agency indicated that the utilities were either not paid or were paid late. Investigation showed that the agency was responsible for not paying C1's rent in a timely manner as the rent payment was late on at least two occasions, thus causing C1 to not be eligible for the month-to-month option upon the expiration of C1's lease. Subsequently, eviction proceedings for C1 were started as there is no documentation that the agency had other housing for C1 and C1 was unable to vacate in the allotted time. Exit interview conducted and documents provided to the facility for signature and return.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection to the facility on 5/20/21 at 10:00 AM and met with Deally Curran, Social Worker Supervisor to discuss the findings of the complaint. LPA informed Ms. Curran that the complaint investigation included initial tele inspection to the facility 1/15/21, interviews with C1 (see LIC811 dated 5/20/21), C1's lawyer, reporting party, and review of documentation provided by the facility as well as documents provided by C1's lawyer. Investigation shows that C1 solely signed a lease agreement on 2/14/2014. At the end of C1's lease in 2015, C1 was trying to get her apartment complex to move to a month to month rental agreement and when C1 went to the leasing office to discuss the details, C1 was told that "due to rent being paid late twice" and "late fees on utilities", they would not be renewing C1's lease nor would they move to a month-to-month agreement. The case notes written by S1, C1's case worker at that time, indicate that on 1/22/2015, S1 did go to the leasing office to discuss that the "late fee(s) on rent should not fall on [C1]'s record but on EA's behalf" but the leasing office would still not go month-to-month with C1. The leasing agency informed C1 to vacate the premises by 2/14/2015. There is no documentation that the agency had other housing for C1 and C1 was unable to vacate in the allotted time. This resulted in eviction proceedings to begin for C1 although C1 did vacate the premises prior to formal execution of the action.

deficiencies.description: Plan of Operation - Procedures for payment or monitoring of utilities, telephone, and rent...review of the plan of operation for this facility states "[EA] shall assist in payment of bills, conferring with the payee when necessary to insure payment has been made". This was not done as evidenced by S1 noted in C1's file that the agency was responsible for not paying C1's rent in a timely manner as the rent payment was late on at least two occasions. In addition, utilities were either not paid or were paid late resulting in leasing agency refusing to go month to month with C1. This caused the leasing agency to begin eviction procedings against C1 at the end of her lease as C1 could not secure housing elsewhere in the allotted time and the agency had no alternative housing for C1 which poses an potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility shall update their plan of operation to include changes that have been made in regulation since initial licensure in 2013. In addition, facility shall update plan of operation specific to monitoring of payments necessary for independent living for participants, signing of leases, timely payments by participants and provider, and any other changes necessary to bring the plan of operation and program statement up to date due to changes in legislation and operation within the agency.

Facility shall submit the updated plan of operation to Licensing by 6/18/21.

met_with: Kyle Denton, Office Manager and Sydney Johnson, Office Manager
narrative:
On May 10, 2023 at 11:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of completing an unannounced required Annual Inspection. LPA Verna met with Kyle Denton, Office Manager and Sydney Johnson, Office Manager. Environmental Alternatives is a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) that supports Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) in creating and achieving independent living goals, and fostering independence. LPA Verna completed an inspection of the physical plant, the office and THPP office. LPA observed the facility sketch, disaster plan and facility license was posted in a prominent place in the office. The office had three levels. All three levels contained staff offices. The main level had visitation room, kitchen, bathroom and client file storage. The upper level had a bathroom. The lower level had a recreation area, bathroom, and storage closets/rooms. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and in working condition. The water temperature was tested and measured at 108.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in May 2023. Files and cleaners were not left accessible to clients or others. The agency was observed to be clean, safe, and in good repair with the exception of one observation. LPA Verna observed the client restroom's on (the main floor) bathroom stall door did not close fully or lock and was not in good repair. continued on 809-c

LPA completed the staff file review and reviewed a total of five staff files. The staff files contained the required documentation, with the exception of: While the agency does have written job descriptions and duties, they are not stored in the personnel records of five out of five employees (electronic). It was observed that LIC 501 Personnel Records forms did not include all employee information such as date of hire and drivers license number, but the agency has documents on file including copies of drivers license's. LPA Verna reviewed of a total of five client files. From files and documents reviewed on today's date, it was observed that the client files contained the required documents with the exception of: Health and medical records were missing in five out of five client files, however three out of five client files documented the client declined to share health and medical information with the THPP. Also, there were five out of five client records which did not contain the LIC 602 or a medical assessment (health screening and TB test/results). Additionally, there was no record on file that the client refused to obtain a health screening and TB test/results. The facility stated that the clients have the right to refuse to share medical information, and they file documents the clients agree to share. Additionally, client files reviewed did contain completed Transitional Independent Living Plans (TILP), when provided by the placing county. LPA Verna conducted 3 staff interviews. The annual inspection was completed on today's date. The facility is being issued five Technical Advisories. Additionally, the facility is being issued one citation regarding deficiencies to Building and Grounds, CCR Title 22 Regulation section 80087(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. See LIC 809-D for citation and POC information. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and was provided to Kyle Denton, Office Manager and Sydney Johnson, Office Manager.

On May 19, 2022, at 3:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell, conducted an unannounced Case Management deficiencies inspection at Family Care Network located at the above address. Dana Nichols (Resource Family Services Manager), granted access into the facility. The purpose of the visit was to inquire about and deliver a deficiency citation regarding an incident that occurred on 4/29/22. The incident entails a resident residing in the Poinsettia THPP apartment testing positive for TB and reporting results to staff on 4/29/22, but staff did not report incident to the Department until 5/12/2022. Upon receipt of the SIR, LPA O'Connell called the licensee and spoke with Dana Nichols who admitted to submitting the report late. LPA discussed with the RF Services Manager the reason for the citation, to which RF Services Manager agreed. During the visit, LPA O'Connell requested the LIC500 and client roster for the THPP program. RF Services Manager communicated that one of the residents in the Poinsettia THPP apartment is not on the client roster, and is part of the Fostering Youth to Independence (FYI) program which is a county contracted program. Both LPA O'Connell and the RF Services Manager discussed the parameters of the program and RF Services Manager agreed to submit a copy of the program contract with the county to CCLD. There is a deficiency cited per Title 22 Regulations on this date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility with the Manager. Cont on LIC809D.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/30/2021 at 1245pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Tana Kinder met with THPP Program Director to deliver complaint investigation findings. Prior to the meeting, LPA Kinder reviewed the agency’s file at the licensing office, including the complaint history, criminal background check, incident reports and facility personnel report summary. LPA Kinder conducted a video inspection of the facility inside and out, using the video platform, Microsoft Teams and no citations were issued. LPA conducted 6 confidential interviews between 6/2/2021-7/2/2021. LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents: facility sketch, 4 client's documentation; including placement agreement, 1 client's Admission and Discharge Agreement, Client Placement History for 2021, program statement, and Staff Roster with phone numbers and 1 staff member's disciplinary file for past 2 years. The allegation is: Staff inappropriately touching youth in care. A client has stated that they were inappropriately touched by a staff member. The staff member denies this occurred. Additional staff that were aware of the allegation stated the date of the alleged incident changed and the initial date was the alleged staff’s day off. Additionally, staff of the opposite sex are not allowed to be at the client’s apartment without staff of the same sex present.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a tele-visit follow-up complaint inspection with First Place of Youth and spoke with Lauren Graveman Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations, LPA Rollins conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, social workers and conducted client file review. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interaction between participants in care. Confidential interviews reveal conflicting stories about participants was engaging in prostitution while at the apartment. Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove that there was a lack of supervision resulting in inappropriate interaction between particpants in care and particpants was engaging in prostitution while at the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there is lack of supervision in inappropriate interaction between particpants in care and particpants was engaging in prostitution while in the apartment, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with Adminstrator and report was e-mail to Administrator for signature

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced required Annual inspection to First Place For Youth Administrative office. LPA met with Lauren Grayman Administrator. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 01:45 PM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Administrator of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Administrator about the residential units. Administrator stated that all residential units have all working toilets, sinks and tubs. Administrator stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Administrator notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the apartment units. At 02:15 PM, LPA reviewed 9 participants files with Administrator. LPA observed all 9 Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. At 2:50 PM LPA observed 7 staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current.

During inspection, LPA receive a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. LPA also spoke with Administrator about updating the Program Administrator documents. A review of Licensing Information System on September 28, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

Based on interviews and documentation there was not enough evidence to prove that facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for participant, participant was threatened by another participant, staff did not accord participant privacy, facility staff spoke inappropriately to participant and facility staff did not ensure that a non minor parent provided proper care for participant child. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility staff failed to provide a safe environment for participant, participant was threatened by another participant, staff did not accord participant privacy, facility staff spoke inappropriately to participant and facility staff did not ensure that a non minor parent provided proper care for participant child, therefore the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted with Administrator and report was left at the facility.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced required Annual inspection to First Place For Youth Administrative office. LPA Valenzuela and met with Lauren Grayman Administrator. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 10:00 AM LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza arrived to facility and the administrator was not present. At 10:48 AM Lauren Grayman, Administrator arrived to the facility. At 11:00 AM, LPA did a walk-through inspection with Administrator of the office. Facility has access to password protected electronic files, which staff members have access to them. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. The agency has their license posted in their office. LPA spoke with Administrator about the residential units. Administrator stated that all residential units have all working toilets, sinks and tubs. At 11:40 AM ,LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza reviewed 10 participants files (P1- P10) (Please refer to LIC 811 for confidential names, dated 05/24/22) with Administrator. During participant file reviews LPA and LPM was not able to locate medical assessment for all 10 participants. The Administrator stated that the facility staff request copies from the participants. However the participant do not always release that information. During inspection, the Administrator showed LPA and LPM their intake and staff case notes which showed that this was being completed, however the medical assessments were not performed by a licensed physician. In addition the facility did not have the clients ambulatory status on file.

At 12:40 PM LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza reviewed 10 staff files which were complete. However LPA and LPM discovered that several staff members were not fingerprint cleared. It was later learned that they provided staff files that did not work for the above licensed facility. The facility keeps staff files for the whole region, and not just of the licensed facility, which made it difficult for LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza to conduct an adequate staff file review. LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza advised facility going forward to provide staff files for the above licensed facility only. LPA Valenzuela and LPM Mendoza reviewed an additional 5 staff files, which all staff were fingerprint cleared and all staff files were complete. Please note HR employee was out today, 05/24/22. LPA was unable to obtain an updated LIC 500. LPA requested the facility to submit a copy to LPM Mendoza via mail no later than Friday 5/27/22. The facility is currently in the process of changing administrators and will submit all required correct documents to CCL once they confirm who they will designate. LPA was not able to interview staff due to the time consumption of the Staff and Participant file reviews. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 86069(a) and 86069(b)(4): Participant Medical Assessments. In addition, Two Technical Violations were issued. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was emailed to the Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint inspection with First Place for Youth and spoke with Lauren Grayman- Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, incident reports and records were reviewed, and confidential interviews were conducted. Based on interviews and record review, LPA spoke to Administrator regarding apartment and let LPA know that the apartment was put on a treatment plan when roaches were first reported but client moved out. First Place For Youth gave up the lease due to client no longer being at the unit. The agency has investigated the complaint alleging apartment has roaches and mold. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. No citations were given due to the apartment being put on a pest control treatment plan when first notified about the incident. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

13On 10-5-22 12:21PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted a follow up complaint investigation at First Place For Youth and met with Chloe Whittlesey, Program Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings of the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff and clients. During confidential interviews with LPA Karkazis, it was disclosed that there was an infestation of mice in one of the apartments. It was also disclosed that the facility immediately began addressing the problem by bringing in glue traps and hiring an exterminator. A verbal and written timeline of the service was provided to LPA Karkazis, to fix the mice infestation, and relocation of clients until the rodents were gone. It was also disclosed to LPA Karkazis that a few months ago it took First Place For Youth three weeks to address a bug infestation in their apartment. Photos of rat droppings were also obtained. Based on confidential interviews, photos, and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met to determine that staff were not assisting to keep residents free of rodents. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. First Place For Youth has taken immediate steps to irradicate rodents and shall not be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Chloe Whittlesey, Program Manager.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/08/2022 at 12:20PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela conducted a visit to the above agency to deliver the findings on the listed allegation. LPA met with Dereassa Chambers, Program Manager. During the course the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews. According to confidential interviews, and record review, LPA Valenzuela concluded, the allegations that facility staff are not providing assistance to Non-Minor Dependent, had inconsistent support.Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated, and no Title 22 deficiencies were observed. narrative:
**Due to technical laptop issues, this form is superseded by the latter LIC809 form also dated 12/1/2022.** At 11:50AM on December 1, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Schlembach and Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced visit of the above listed agency. The LPAs met with Program Administrator Lauren Grayman and DeReassa Chambers (County Program Manager - Santa Clara County) who assisted with the visit. LPA Schlembach explained that the purpose of the visit was to conduct a case management regarding deficiencies observed by LPA Schlembach during the course of a complaint investigation dated 06/27/2022. Based on confidential interviews, reviewing staff, client, and agency files, LPA Schlembach confirmed the following: 1. The agency did not report incidents to the Department, as required. This is a violation THPP ILS, Section 86261(a)(4), which states, “The licensee or THPP staff shall report to the licensing agency and the person or agency responsible for placing a nonminor dependent, such as a social worker or probation officer, when any of the following events occur… Any unusual incident that involves a nonminor dependent and threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of the nonminor dependent or anyone in the THPP.” 2. The agency did operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation. This is a violation of THPP ILS Section 80022(k), which states, “The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation. *Continued on LIC809-C*

**Due to technical laptop issues, this form is superseded by the latter LIC809 form also dated 12/1/2022.** Specifically from FPFY's Plan of Operation: · Complaints of noise, cleanliness or other site specific concerns will result in a warning letter. · Violations of the visitor policy will result in increased visits from program staff. Repeat violations will result in a final warning and either relocation or exit from the program. · Duplicating apartment keys for non-participants or any behavior that threatens the safety of the youth or others will result in the youth being relocated as soon as possible and the convening of a team decision meeting with the youth, MFP staff, and county workers to determine youth’s continued eligibility for the program. · FPFY staff provide round-the-clock support to participants. MFP maintains round-the-clock on-call support for program participants at all times. On-call staff respond by telephone and in-person if needed to address complaints and emergencies. On-call staff are supported by a program supervisor, administrator or agency executive at all times. · A Safety Plan is used when a client has expressed that his/her safety is threatened by an EXTERNAL source. · All social work staff receive annual in-service training equivalent to at least 20 hours. First Place for Youth provides 24 hours of initial orientation training to each staff person including Child Abuse Reporting, Rights of Participants, Characteristics of Transition Age Foster Youth, Strengths based and Trauma Informed Assessment and Intervention, Motivational Interviewing, Assessment, Crisis Response and De-escalation; Skill Building; and Documentation. First Place for Youth provides a minimum of twenty hours of in-service training per FTE annually. An exit interview was conducted with Lauren Grayman, and a signed copies of the following forms was emailed to Lauren Grayman and Rachel Carlos: LIC809 - Facility Evaluation Report, LIC809-C - Facility Evaluation Report Continued, and LIC809-D - Facility Evaluation Report Deficiencies.

investigation_findings: 13At 11:45AM on December 1, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Schlembach and Shikya Belfield conducted an unnanounced complaint inspection at the above-listed agency. The LPAs met with Administrator Lauren Grayman and DeReassa Chambers (County Program Manager - Santa Clara County) who assisted with the visit. Program Director Rachel Carlos made herself available via telephone for the duration of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, staff and client file reviews, and review of other agency documentation it was confirmed that the agency did not ensure that all participants had safe, healthy, and comfortable homes to live in. An exit interview was conducted with Lauren Grayman, and a copy of this report, along the associated deficiency page and appeal rights was emailed to Lauren Grayman and Rachel Carlos.

deficiencies.description: Section 86272(a)(1): Personal Rights – The licensee shall ensure that each nonminor dependent is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and the following personal rights: A nonminor dependent shall be free from corporal or unusual punishment; infliction of pain; humiliation; intimidation; ridicule; coercion; threat; physical, sexual, mental, or other abuse; or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, medication, or aids to physical functioning. (Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9, subsection (a) provides in part: It is the policy of the state that all children in foster care shall have the following rights: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where he or she is treated with respect.) This requirement was not met as evidenced by, Based on confidential interviews, it was confirmed that First Place for Youth (FPFY) did not ensure that nonminor dependents live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee agrees to hold a program-staff training on personal rights by December 31, 2022. The curriculum materials, the length of the training, and a list of the names of the participants will be emailed to LPA Schlembach, following the training.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced required Annual inspection to First Place for Youth. LPA met with Jameson Wolf, County Program Manager. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The facility is licensed for 250 participants. Present were three staff members and no clients At 1:30PM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Jameson Wolf . The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all client files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in the Human Resources Office. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Jameson Wolf about the residential units. Jameson Wolf stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Jameson Wolf stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Jameson Wolf notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 1:57PM, LPA reviewed five client files and five staff files with Jameson Wolf. LPA observed five client files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA observed five staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was given to Jameson Wolf, County Program Manager

met_with: Rachael Carlos, Regional Director of Programs
investigation_findings: 13On 10-4-23 10:29AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at First Place for Youth and met with Rachael Carlos, Regional Director of Programs, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. Regarding the allegation that THP is not meeting participant’s needs: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, and conducted document research. During confidential interviews, inconsistent information was provided. Some interviewees stated that the facility was not doing anything to meet the client’s needs while other interviewees were providing alternatives to meet the participant’s needs. LPA conducted document research and found that all participants were safe and not in danger, and alternative living arrangements provided. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the THP is not meeting participant’s needs. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Rachael Carlos, Regional Director of Programs.

An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with De Reassa Chambers, Clinical Program Manager.

narrative: On 12-18-24 10:26AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at First Place for Youth (FPFY) and met with De'Reassa Chambers, Clinical Program Manager who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Case Management Inspection. During the complaint investigation dated 9-13-24 #14-CR20240913110932, LPA conducted confidential interviews and document research which revealed in the FPFY program statement that if a client is in possession of weapons (legal, illegal, or simulated) to any FPFY activity, will be exited from the program. Upon discovery of the client’s weapons, FPFY issued a housing violation. The client maintained placement and was not exited from the program. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Article 03, 86022(e) Plan of Operation Type B. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to De'Reassa Chambers, Clinical Program Manager.

investigation_findings: 13On 12-18-24 10:26AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at First Place for Youth (FPFY) and met with De'Reassa Chambers, Clinical Program Manager, who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that staff allowed minor to have possession of weapons. LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews, reviewed documentation, and it was confirmed that a client in care had weapons. LPA obtained a photo of the weapons in possession of the minor. Confidential interviews disclosed that the client was instructed to remove the weapons and first to keep them in their vehicle. They then later were asked to be stored away from the premises. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the above allegation staff allowed minor to have possession of weapons is SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is being cited for Title 22 Interim Licensing Standards AB 12 Nonminor Dependents, THPP Article 06. 86272(a) PERSONAL RIGHTS. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was given to De'Reassa Chambers, Clinical Program Manager.

deficiencies.description:
86272(a) The licensee shall ensure that each nonminor dependent is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and the following personal rights: To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home…

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records review (C1) had possessions of weapons while in care. This poses an immediate, healthy, safety, and personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility must update their program statement with clear procedures of weapons discovery and consequences.  The program statement and weapons intake forms must contain the same plan.  Updates shall be sent to George.Karkazis@dss.ca.gov by 1-31-24, and revised if necessary.

At this time the investigation is not complete, further interviews and document research are required. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Nicole Harrington, Regional Director of Programs.

met_with: Nicole Harrington, Regional Director of Programs
narrative: On August 7, 2025 a Case Management visit was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Omar Sawyer and LPA Monica Pavia. The purpose of this inspection is to complete and close an inspection from March 3, 2025. The purpose of that inspection was to obtain additional information regarding an incident of a client who was the victim of a homicide, which occurred 03/02/25. LPA Sawyer and LPA Pavia met with Nicole Harrington, Regional Director of Programs. The investigation was conducted fully by the licensing agency's Investigations Branch (IB). On July 30, 2021 at 11:20am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emelyn Sanchez P. made an unannounced visit to the First Place for Youth THPP+FC, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection Visit. LPA, Sanchez P met with Facility Administrator, Jamie Kugelberg who granted access and provided a tour of the Administrative Office which is located at the above said address on the 6th floor of an executive suite that is shared amongst other companies. The facility is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care (THP+FC) to 250 Non-Minor Dependents only. The office is set up as follows: This is a 13 room office with a lobby area, one small conference room, one large conference room, lunch/break room and printing area. The lobby area has two desks along the wall with three operating computers and chairs. There is also one round table with a sofa and two sofa chairs and small table. The receptionist desks are located to the left when entering the office space. The small conference/classroom area has a table with more then 10 chairs for seating. The large conference room has a large table with 9 chairs and a desk/cabinet with an operating computer to the left when entering the room. The lunch/break room area has a small table with three chairs, microwave, and refrigerator/freeze for staff to use. Clients are not allowed inside the break room without a staff member. In the assigned office space for the Regional Director are the staff files locked in a small cabinet. All client files are kept locked in cabinets in the office room assigned to the Youth Advocates. This office is used by clients, office personnel, and social workers. The facility was inspected and the following was observed: The licensee operates within capacity limitations. A review of all staff clearances conducted on 7/30/2021 indicate that all individuals who require background checks have received criminal record clearances and child abuse index clearances or exemptions. All posting requirements were met. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C.

LPA will return to the facility at later date to complete the Annual Inspection (i.e Staff/Client Records review and conduct Staff/Client interviews) No deficiencies observed at the time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On June 9, 2022 at 9:31am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to First Place for Youth THPP+FC, for the purpose of conducting a two (2) year Required Inspection. LPA Edison met with Lamont Walker, Regional Director of Programs who granted access and provided a tour of the Administrative Office which is located at the above said address on the 6th floor of an executive suite that is shared with other companies. The facility is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care (THP+FC) to two-hundred and fifty (250) Non-Minor Dependents only. The census on the date of this visit is one hundred thirty-three (133). The office is set up as follows: This is a thirteen (13) room office with a lobby area, one small conference room, one (1) large conference room, lunch/break room and printing area. The lobby area has two (2) desks along the wall with three (3) operable computers. There is also one (1) round table with a sofa, two (2) chairs, a and small table. The receptionist desks are located to the left when entering the office space. The small conference/classroom area has a table with ten (10) or more chairs for seating. The large conference room has a large table with nine (9) chairs and a desk/cabinet with an operable computer to the left upon entrance to the room. The lunch/break room area has a small table with three (3) chairs, microwave, and refrigerator/freezer for staff use. Clients are not permitted inside of the break room unless accompanied by a staff member. Staff files are kept locked in a small cabinet in the office occupied by the Regional Director of Programs. Client files are kept locked in cabinets in the office occupied by the Youth Advocates. The Youth Advocate office is also used by clients, office personnel, and social workers. Continued on LIC 809-C

During this visit, LPA reviewed three (3) staff records and conducted two (2) staff interviews. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Casualty Plan was available for review. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Direct care staff have valid CPR and First Aid training. All posting requirements were met. During this visit, LPA reviewed three (3) client records. Client records contained copies of Needs and Service Plans and Medical Authorizations signed by each child and their authorized representative. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Off Site Living Units Inspected: 1. 2010 El Segundo Blvd. #4, Compton, CA 90222 2. 14637 Denker Ave. #B , Gardena, CA 90247 The facility was inspected, and the following was observed: The licensee operates within capacity limitations. There were no firearms or other weapons observed inside of the living units. No bodies of water on living unit premises. Overall, the offsite living units are safe, sanitary, and in good repair for the safety and wellbeing of clients, employees, and visitors. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested audible and are in operable condition in the living units. There is a fully charged regulation fire extinguisher in the units. Hot water was tested and is in a safe temperature range. Based on the observations made during today’s inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Regional Director of Programs.

On August 18, 2022 at 1:16pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to First Place for Youth for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident #823167, Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) Death. LPA met with Lamont Walker, Regional Director of Programs and discussed the incident. A Special Incident Report was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on August 12, 2022 for the incident which occurred on August 5, 2022, when Non-Minor Dependent #1 (NMD1) (see Confidential Names List, LIC 811 dated 8/18/2022) was involved in a fatal automobile accident in the state of Idaho. During this visit, confidential interviews were conducted with Staff #1. Additional staff interviews will be conducted on a later date. Staff interview conducted on this day revealed that NMD1 had driven alone to the state of Idaho where NMD1 was involved in a fatal automobile accident. Staff interviews also revealed that upon being notified of the death of NMD1, the facility staff immediately notified Community Care Licensing (CCL) of the death of NMD1. Additionally, LPA Edison learned that NMD1's placement with First Place for Youth was closed effective August 5, 2022 per the date of NMD's death . Based on the information gathered at this time, the facility took proper action regarding the incident in question and no violation will be cited on this day regarding this case management incident. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Regional Director of Programs.

On February 14, 2023 at 8:40am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to First Place for Youth THP+FC for the purpose of conducting a Case Management for Special Incident Report #841202. investigation_findings: 13On March 2, 2023 at 2:09pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to First Place for Youth and spoke with Lamont Walker, Regional Director of Programs. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, a total of one (1) witness, three (3) Non-Minor Dependents, and three (3) staff were interviewed. Confidential interviews and inconsistent statements made by staff, witnesses, and Non-Minor Dependent #1 (NMD1) did not substantiate the allegation, Youth is not given privacy. Statements made by S1 and NMD1 did not confirm that NMD1 was not dressed when S1 entered NMD1’s bedroom. Confidential interviews revealed upon inspection of NMD1’s unit, multiple alcohol bottles were observed by S1 and the smell of marijuana in the unit. Additional confidential staff interviews also revealed NMD1 violated the program agreement on illegal activities/drug use/ alcohol use. Documentary evidence revealed S1 training on conducting unscheduled visits to participant units and notice of NMD1’s notice of lease violation.

On August 15, 2024, (LPA), Licensing Program Analyst Kim Dear made a unannounced visit to the First Place For Youth organization to conduct a Annual Inspection. LPA was met by Brandy Sperry, the Office Administrator whom granted access into the facility, Ms. Sperry then contacted LaMont Walker,LPA began the inspection of the physical plant areas of the facility. The facility provides care and supervision for non- minor dependants. The facilities current census, consists of (143), one- hundred and forty- three clients, non- ambulatory only. The facility location is on the (6th.),sixth floor, suite 200. This location has (15) office rooms and a mid- sized conference room. The office spaces has a desk set up with chairs aligning the office walls. The individual office set- ups displayed a computer and desk personalized with artifacts of its occupants. The conference room housed an abundance of seating chairs neatly stack top one another and a cherry- wood finished table with seating chairs for (12), twelve individuals sat in the center of the room. All required certifications, fire clearance, License of Operational type documents were displayed in frames about the hall way wall. Fifteen staff files and (5) client files were reviewed (15). Two staff were present for interviews, however no clients were available for interviewing at the time of this inspection. Mr. Walker provided the current LIC500 and client rosters via email. Both documents containing almost identical information as to the LIS printout. During this inspection, the LPA found the facility to be clean, sanitary, organized and free from hazard(s). No deficiencies could be visually found nor identified after completion of the CARES Tool, therefore no citations will be issued at this time. The exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this inspection report will be emailed to the Regional Director, LaMont Walker.

On July 31, 2025 at 9:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) J. Armstrong arrived at First Place for Youth THPP+FC for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required visit inspection of the Transitional Housing Placement Administrative office. LPA’s met with Lamont Walker the Administrator, who granted access and gave a tour of the entire Administrative Office. The facility is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care (THP+FC) to two-hundred and fifty (250) Non-Minor Dependents only. The census on the date of this visit is 150. This Administrative Office is situated in a business district building located on the 6th floor. The office includes the following areas:This is a thirteen (13) room office with a lobby area, one (1) small conference room, one (1) large conference room, lunch/break room and printing area and 2 private rooms used for one on one meeting with clients. The lobby area has two (2) desks along the wall with three 3 chairs. There is also one (1) round table with 2 sofa, two (2) chairs, and 2 small tables. The reception desks are located to the left when entering the office space. The small conference which used to be used as a classroom area has a table with ten (10) or more chairs for seating. The large conference room has a large table with nine (9) chairs and a desk/cabinet with an operable computer to the left upon entrance to the room. There were other office rooms utilized by the CEO, Administrator, Program Manager, Education and Employment specialist, and development director.(Continued on LIC809C )

The lunch/break room area has a small table with chairs, microwave,refrigerator/freezer for staff use, and a Fire Extinguisher. Staff files are kept locked in a small cabinet in the office occupied by the Regional Director of Programs. Client files are kept locked in cabinets in the office occupied by the Youth Advocates. During this visit, LPA reviewed four (4) staff records and conducted two (1) staff interviews. The Emergency Mass Disaster Casualty Plan was available for review. All staff have valid CPR, First Aid training, DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. All posting requirements were met. LPA also reviewed six (6) client records. Client records contained copies of Needs and Service Plans and Medical Authorizations signed by each child and their authorized representative, Signed Admission Agreement, and Signed Personal Rights Form. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. LPA informed the Administrator , one of the facility’s remote THPP site would be inspected on this day, for compliance with Title 22 Regulations. The Administrator provided the following addresses: 1185 N. Virgil Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90029 Administrator, agreed to meet LPA at the site to grant access to the units for inspection. LPA inspected all one unit and found each unit to be clean and in good repair. No deficiencies were observed or cited. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

met_with: Regional Director of Programs - LaMont Walker
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection August 28, 2025, at 10:28 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 10 out of 145 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 19 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 143 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 28, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth placed in care of the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Regional Director Of Programs LaMont Walker.

The staff interviewed and staff notes indicate they were aware of the concerns brought up by the adult client and tried to work through the issues with the adult client by following the steps outlined in the program statement indicating the adult client should try to address concerns directly with their adult roommate and if that does not resolve the issue, the agency can get involved by talking with the other adult client or facilitating a meeting between the adult roommates. Staff have stated they were not aware of some reported incidents until months after they occurred or after the adult client was moved into another apartment. It does appear that some incidents did rise to the level of a safety concern that were addressed, but it is not clear that it was addressed in a timely manner. This was also the case related to meeting the client’s needs. The question is whether or not they were met in a reasonable amount of time. LPA was able to interview the adult client’s roommate but the adult client in the complaint did not return multiple requests to discuss complaint allegations. The adult roommate provided conflicting information from what was stated in the complaint. Based on 4 confidential interviews, one witness’ not participating in an interview, staff notes, information provided in incident reports related to the complaint allegations, inconsistencies in statements and documentation as well as the lack of corroboration, the allegations are determined to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal process was provided to the program manager.

narrative: On May 1, 2023, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection. LPA Stiger met with Susan Kemp, Independent Living Specialized Program (ILSP) Supervisor and toured the facility, inside. The facility is licensed to serve minor youth ages 16 to 17 for THP and Non-Minor Dependent ages 17 to 21 years for THP+FC program. LPA Stiger observed at the time of the visit, the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. The Administrator office was inspected and the following was observed: two (2) desks, two (2) bathrooms, two (2) licenses and Youth Bill of Rights posted. One (1) electrical room. There are three (3) offices used for Housing and Educational programs. The Independent Living Program (ILP) is attached to the Administrative office and four (4) offices and equipped with the following: and one (1) staff lounge, three (3) offices including participant store. One (1) kitchen area with appliances and one (1) cabinet area stored with masks, sanitizer and cleaning products. LPA Stiger reviewed five (5) staff files and five (5) participant's files during today's inspection LPA Stiger observed a copy of Personal right's and a copy of the License posted in the common area of the Administrative Office. met_with: Education and Employment Manager, Raymond Gardner & Independent Living Specialized Program (ILSP), Susan Kimball
narrative:
On May 14, 2024 at approximately 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Farhaan Sarangi arrived unannounced at First Place For Youth THPP/THP+FC for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Random Inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Housing Specialist, Janica Quiones and was granted access into the facility. Education and Employment Manager, Raymond Gardner arrived 30 minutes later. Independent Living Specialized Program (ILSP), Susan Kimball arrived two and half hours later. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility were fingerprint cleared through DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index. LPA toured the facility and observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary with all exits free from obstruction. The Administrator office was inspected and the following was observed: two (2) desks, licenses and Youth Bill of Rights posted. 2 of 2 bathrooms water temperature measured at 118 degrees and is within regulation. One (1) electrical room was observed. There are three (3) offices used for Housing and Educational programs. The Independent Living Program (ILP) is attached to the Administrative office and four (4) offices and equipped with the following: One (1) staff lounge, three (3) offices including participant store which does not charge youth for snacks. One (1) kitchen area with appliances and one (1) cabinet area stored with masks, sanitizer and cleaning products. First aid kit was inspected and found to be appropriate during the inspection. Office supplies were observed on the left side of the staff lounge. Facility does not serve meals to clients in care. LPA also observed working smoke detectors and carbon monoxide sound directly to the Local Fire Jurisdiction. 3 of 3 Fire Extinguishers were observed to be last charged on February 2024. During this Annual/Random inspection, LPA toured a client apartment and found the living environment to be clean and comfortable with all exits free from obstruction. During the inspection, LPA reviewed five (5) participant's files. (Report continued on LIC 809C)

During a record review, LPA observed no Medical Assessments conducted on participants (See LIC 9102-Technical Violation). LPA educated Education and Employment Manager, Raymond Gardner regarding the importance of obtaining Medical Assessments for clients in care. LPA observed a copy of Personal right's and a copy of the License posted in the common area of the Administrative Office. Facility is in the process of updating the Emergency Disaster Plan (See LIC 9102-Technical Advisory). LPA requested the following documents to be sent: LIC 500- Personnel Report LIC 308- Designation of Responsibility LIC 309- Administrative Organization LIC 400- Affidavit regarding Client Cash Resources (if any) Most updated Emergency Disaster Plan (if any) Most up-to-date Liability insurance Control of Property Register of Participants Annual Continuation will be conducted at a later date and time. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Education and Employment Manager, Raymond Gardner and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 10, 2024 at approximately 11:05 am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Zaria Turner arrived at the above Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPAs were greeted by Susan Kimball, County Program Manager who granted LPAs access. LPAs conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiency. The water temperature in the participant bathroom was recorded at 143 degrees F with no hot water warning sign. (See LIC 9102 TV) LPAs requested a sign to be displayed in the bathroom warning participants of the hot water temperature and proof of hot water sign being posted. This case management will remain open, until proof of signage is provided to LPA Shulz to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to County Program Manager, Susan Kimball.

On September 20, 2024 at approximately 9:55 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarina Buchannan arrived at the above Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA was greeted by Tempest Smith, Education Advocate Lead who granted LPA access. On September 10, 2024, LPAs Tatyana Shulz and Zaria Turner conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPAs observed the following deficiency. The water temperature in the participant bathroom was recorded at 143 degrees Fahrenheit with no hot water warning sign posted. On September 17, 2024, LPA Shulz received a picture from the facility showing that a sign warning participants of the hot water temperature is now displayed next to the sink in the bathroom. On September 20, 2024 LPA Buchannan observed the water temperature to be 148.5 degrees Fahrenheit but that the facility has added a sign near the sink warning of the high temperature. (See LIC 9102 TV) This case management that was initially open on September 10, 2024 is now closed. The facility is in full compliance. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Tempest Smith.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the above allegations cannot be substantiated due to conflicting statements. 3 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that there was ample storage space for the client and that they saw no evidence of a lack of storage for the participant. 2 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that they attempted to conduct roommate meetings to address interpersonal conflicts, such as inadequate storage, but both roommates declined to participate in the meetings to rectify the issue. Lastly, 4 out of 5 confidential interviews stated that the participant would threaten and use physical violence towards staff members who were trying to help the participant with storage conflicts and abuse allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.
