13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward spoke with the facility manager and the person who was allegedly appointed as administrator after Mr. Ferguson was ordered off the premises by DCFS. The facility manager, Ms. Green, stated that she was nevever given any documentation theat the appointed administrator met the necessary qualifications to act in that position. When LPA spoke with the appointed administrator, Ms. Ka'i Parker, she stated that she did not meet the qualifications and that she did not consider herself to be the administrator. Based on the aforementioned interviews, the allegation that the acting administrator does not meet Title 22 qualifications is resolved as substantiated. A finding that the complaint is substantiated means that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met.

deficiencies.description:
Administrator Qualifications
All THPP + FC licensees shall have an administrator that meet Title 22 requirements. Based on employee interviews, the facility failed to meet this requirement.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit documentation that a qualified administrator has been appointed by the POC due date. The licensee must submit administrator qualifications and a board resolution signifying the appointment

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA spoke to the facility manager at the time, the former director, and the former president of the borad of directors. Mr, Ferguson, the former director stated that after DCFS ordered him off of the premises, he turned his keys over to Tim Moore who was the president of the board of directors. Per Mr. Moore, he received the keys from Mr. Ferguson within 24 hours of DCFS's decision Mr. Ferguson denied that he provided his keys to anyone so that they could bring him client or employee records or financial instruments. Per interviews with facility manager and board president, it was determined that stated that Cyril Wright had access to the building in his capacity as landlord. However it remains unclear whether he had keys to access any sensitive information.Based on the foregoing interviews, the allegations that the former director provided unauthroized access to client records, employee records or organizational finances are resolved as unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: On December 31, 2024 at 9:30 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brent Lockhart and Karen McGee conducted a pre-licensing visit to Florence Crittenton THPP office. LPAs met with Vice President Cesar Salgado. The THPP is relocating from 2939 Pacific Commerce Drive, Rancho Dominguez, CA 90221 to 12440 Firestone Blvd. Suite 215, Norwalk, CA 90650. The THPP program will be sharing the same suite as the other Florence Crittenton welfare programs in a commercial building. The THPP currently utilizes apartments to place participants. Currently, the THPP has twelve placements, no host family and single housing units. A tour of the office was made with VP Salgado. LPAs observed the following: The THPP has a break room for staff, (2) conference rooms, (5) drop down offices, Clinical Director and Supervisor offices, storage room, and bullpen area for staff that provided desk, chairs and telephones which were available for use. LPAs observed the room where participant records will be stored. The room will be locked at all times, and the files will be stored in locked file cabinets. In addition, THPP files will be kept separate from other program files. There are restrooms located outside the suite in the main hallway of the commercial building. Prior to the pre-licensing inspection, LPA Lockhart reviewed all required documents for licensure. The office is equipped with three fire extinguishers. VP Salgado oversees Facility Administrator Elizabeth Arrelano and (5) Case Managers. A copy of the report was provided to the facility. (An amended copy of this document was provided on January 3, 2025.)

met_with: Audrey Fisher-Price Vice President of Community Based Programs
narrative: On March 28, 2025, at 10:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Brent Lockhart and John Bonilla conducted an announced inspection at Florence Crittenton of Orange County, a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP), for the purpose of discussing the facility’s Plan of Operation/Program Statement (PoO/PS). LPAs met with Audrey Fisher-Price, Vice President of Community Based Programs. During this inspection, LPAs went over the Department’s current program tool with facility representative and suggested some revisions to their existing PoO/PS to bring the documents current. LPA Lockhart asks that the THPP resubmit their revision to him by April 11, 2025. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. A signed copy of this report was provided to THPP representative. On June 11, 2025, at 9:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Gilbert Gutierrez conducted an un-announced post-licensing inspection to Florence Crittenton of Orange County Transitional Housing Program (THP) and met Program Manager, Andrea Davis who gave a tour of the facility. Program Manager provided the following documents: ACCREDITATION Board Minutes Meeting LIC 610C (Emergency Disaster Plan) LIC 500 (Personnel Report) Client Roster Physical Plant At the time of the inspection, the following was observed. posted license, accreditation, grievance box, a lobby/reception area, break room, conference rooms, drop down rooms, Program Manager and Supervisor offices, storage room, and file room. The first aid kit was complete. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the break room and filing room were working. There was fire extinguishers located in the reception area and hallways of the THPP office. The restrooms were located outside the suite in the main hallway of the commercial building.

Client Records The records were maintained in the file room where the participants' records are stored locked in metal filing cabinets. LPA reviewed 2 participant records. The records consisted of but not limited to the following: Certificate of Compliance, THP-NMD Application, Pre-placement Appraisal,Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP)/Needs and Services Plan (NSP), Transitional Housing Program Agreement, Acknowledgement of Receipt of Grievance and Personal and Bi-Monthly Maintenance and Site Inspection Form. Staff Records Staff records are available upon request. LPA reviewed 2 personnel records (refer to LIC 811 Confidential Names Form) dated 06/11/25 and interviewed 1 staff. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 811s and LIC 9102TV were provided to the Program Manager.

On July 23, 2025, at 2:00 p.m., Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jean Herring and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart held a virtual meeting via MS Teams with Audrey Fisher-Price, Vice President of Community-Based Programs. The following points were discussed: Administrator Change Notification During a post-licensing inspection on June 11, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst Gilbert Gutierrez discovered that the administrator listed in the system has not been serving in that role since January 2025. On June 13, 2025, LPA Brent Lockhart received an email notifying that Andrea Davis would serve as the THPP administrator. During today’s meeting, Ms. Fisher-Price provided a board resolution authorizing Ms. Davis and three other staff members to accept licensing reports and make administrative decisions. However, the resolution did not designate Ms. Davis as the THPP Administrator nor specify the effective date of her appointment. LPM Herring emphasized the requirement to notify Community Care Licensing (CCL) of any Administrator change within ten (10) days. Ms. Fisher-Price agreed to submit a Board resolution designating Andrea Davis as the administrator including the effective date of her appointment. A technical advisory note was issued (refer to Document LIC9102TV) for the delayed submission. Per Ms. Fisher-Price, designated Administrator Andrea Davis wasn't able to attend the teams meeting. Program Statement Revisions LPM Herring inquired about the timeline for the updated program statement. LPM emphasized the importance of submitting the Program Statement revisions to ensure compliance with the latest ILS standards.

Ms. Fisher-Price requested a few weeks and committed to submitting the revisions no later than August 15, 2025. A signed copy of this report was provided to the licensee.

On May 4, 2022 at 12:20PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yuvi Diaz conducted an announced required- 2 year inspection. LPA Diaz met with Jason Sitar, Program Manager who assisted with this inspection. LPA Diaz observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Facility office consisted of kitchen space, open area for activities, conference table, four offices with working spaces for social workers and other staff, and two bathrooms.LPA Diaz observed the Foster Youth Personal Rights, covid posters, facility license, floor plan, and the emergency/disaster plan. LPA Diaz observed the files are stored in locked file cabinets in a locked designated room. LPA Diaz reviewed four staff files: one Administrator file, one Program Manager file, and two social worker files. They all contained the following documents: CPR and First Aid training. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse check clearances. A review of Licensing Information System on May 3, 2022 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. There where no deficiencies noted at today's inspection. but a technical advisory note was provided due to no job descriptions in the staff files. Program Manager had no knowledge of this requirement, but has reached out to Human Resource to have copies of the job descriptions and will be filed in the staff files. LPA Diaz completed three domains from the care tools: Physical Plant, Operations, and Disaster Preparedness. LPA Diaz will complete the care tools at a different time. Exit interview was conducted with Jason Sitar, Program Manager. A copy of this report will be e-mailed to jsitar@lssnorcal.org

On December 7, 2023, at 12:02PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purposes of verifying Administrative documents. LPA Stiger met with the Deputy Director who assisted with this visit. During this visit, it was determined additional verification is needed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided. This case management investigation needs further investigation.

Based on evidence obtained and confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process the allegations above cannot be substantiated due to the inability to obtain a statement from the participant in question. LPA attempted to contact the participant multiple times in order to gather information on the above allegations but was unable to reach the participant via phone number and email listed on the report. 1 out of 3 confidential interviews stated that participant was not unlawfully evicted. The agency was able to place the participant in their rapid rehousing program. Allowing the participant to keep their place of residence after completing the program. 2 out of 3 confidential interviews stated that participant did receive the funds owed to them before leaving the program. LPA obtained documentation of the participant receiving all funds owed to them on May 2, 2024. Lastly, 1 out of 3 confidential interviews stated the participant was given a grievance form but LPA was unable to confirm or deny these claims after attempting to make contact on 4 separate occasions with the participant. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Exit interview conducted, copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the licensee.

narrative:
On May 21, 2025 at approximately 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Zaria Turner, made an unannounced visit with the purpose of conducting an annual inspection to the above Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA Turner met with Facility Administrator, Jason Sitar, and a walk through of the interior and exterior was completed. LPA conducted a walk though of the interior and exterior of the facility. The facility was clean, safe and kept free of obstruction. LPA observed the posting of License, Personal Rights, and Emergency Disaster Plan. The facility consists of four office rooms, a workshop room, a kitchen, a nook, a file room, laundry room, and two bathrooms. Office room #1 is equipped with three desks, three office chairs, one monitor, a printer, and and two supply closets. Office room #2 is equipped with one desk, one office chair, two monitors, a file cabinet, a chair, a side table, a love seat, and a supply closet. Office room #3 is equipped with a desk, an office chair, two monitors, three chairs, and a supply closet. Office room #4 is equipped with two desks, an office chair, two monitors, two chairs, and a supply closet. The workshop room is equipped with two tables, eight chairs, two desks, two monitors, and two office chairs, a TV and dresser stand, a file dresser, and two love seats. The nook is equipped with five chairs, a desk, and bookshelf. There is a laundry room with a washer and dryer and cabinets above where disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept and locked away. Continue summary of inspection on 809-C

First Aid Kit fully stocked. Hot Water between 105–120 degrees F. Fire Extinguishers are up to date and in working order. The toilets and bathroom fixtures are in good repair. Soap and paper towels are available. The facility is free of vermin. Administrative office is within two hours of participants living areas. The yard contains a large grassy area and a basketball hoop. There is no pool on the premises. The following domains were also reviewed during today's inspection, Physical Plant, Operation, Emergency Disaster Preparedness, and Staff and Client Records. A total of four staff files and four client files were reviewed. LPA conducted two staff interviews. A review of the Licensing Information System indicates the facility is up to date on their facility annual fees. Several deficiencies were assessed during today's inspection. (See LIC 809-Ds) An exit interview was conducted with Jason Sitar, Facility Administrator, and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were provided during today's inspection.

narrative:
On May 24, 2022 at 9:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above location for the purpose of conducting a Required 2 year inspection. LPA met with Linda Smith, Chief Financial Officer, who granted access and toured the entire physical plant. The census today is zero. This organization does not currently have a contract with any entity to accept clients and is not operating. NOTE: There are 3 adults here at the office space. CFO Linda Smith stated that they are here at the office under a Community based Day Program Due to Covid restrictions. LPA will follow up with LPM regarding this program operating out of the office. The physical plant of the administrative office is as follows: The front exterior of the facility is a gated grassy area that leads to the front door. The gate is not locked. There is a walk way that leads to the rear exterior of the facility. The interior of the building consists of an office with an entry/lobby and two separate rooms. Entry/Lobby: To the left of the doorway, there is a desk with a computer workstation. There is a table with four chairs on the right side of the lobby. Office: The office area contains desks and computers for staff. Client and staff files will be contained in locked file cabinets in the rear of the room. There is a separate office/therapy room that is available should clients need privacy for counseling or meetings. The bathroom has a toilet and a sink. Cont 809-C

Foundation For Special People THP+FC will utilize the single site housing model and even though the location has not been identified, the following services will be applicable, 1. Participants will have their own bedroom, 2. No more than two participants will share a bathroom, 3. No more than two participants will share a refrigerator, 4. There will be an on-site supervisor available 24/7 to support, assist and oversee any needs of the participants, 5. There will be an assigned Social Worker to assist and meet with participants a minimum of one time per week (face-to-face) and 6. Supervision, if needed, with the distribution of any prescription medication. To date, the following administrative staff have been identified: Joyce Kitchen (Johnson) (Executive Director/Administrator), Linda Smith (Chief Financial Officer). Deanne Jackson (Property Manager). All other positions are TBD. On 7/21/2017 the facility was given a Deficiency Plan of Correction to adjust the program statement to reflect the additional business being conducted from this office space. There is now an auto mechanic business being ran out of the garage area in the back of the office. During this visit, the following deficiencies were observed/cited (SEE LIC809-D). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

LPA observed the apartment at a comfortable temperature. At 3:00 PM, LPA reviewed 5 participants files with Administrator. All participants files are complete and documentation is up to date. At 3:45 PM LPA reviewed 5 staff files with Administrator. All Staff files were complete, documentation was up to date and all staff had there annual training hours.

During the inspection LPA requested an updated LIC 500 to maintain the facility file current. All personnel required to have fingerprint clearances were verified using Licensing Information System facility personnel report dated 9/21/21. No deficiencies were cited during today's visit. Exit interview conducted and a report was left at the Administrative Office.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted a complaint inspection with Fred Finch and met with Mar Smith Senior Director. LPA spoke with Kellie Knox Administrator over the phone and Administrator approved SD to sign for Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation. During the course of investigating this allegation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, social workers, conducted a client file review and reviewed documentation. Confidential interviews and documentation reveal that facility staff did not report incident in a timely manner. Based on confidential interviews and documentation there was enough evidence to prove that facility staff did not report incident in a timely manner, as required. Based on the information obtained; there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that facility staff did not report incident in a timely manner by reporting requirements. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the Adminstrator for signature.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements: (1) a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation, the licensee did not ensure that facility staff reported an incident  in a timely manner, which poses a potential health,safety or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Licensee has agreed to conduct training on reporting requirements for incident reports to authorized representative & department. Licensee will submit training and sign in sheet by poc due date

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced required Annual Inspection at Fred Finch Rising Oaks. LPA met with Carolina Sousa, Housing Program Manager. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. Present were two staff and no clients. At 10:32AM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Carolina Sousa, Housing Program Manager. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in the locked human resources building. All files are electronically stored. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Carolina Sousa about the residential units. Carolina Sousa stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Carolina Sousa stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Carolina Sousa notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 11:41AM, LPA reviewed five participants files and five staff files with Lauren Tanzer, Clinical Director. LPA observed five Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA observed five staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. Per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Regarding the allegation that staff threatened participant: During the course of the investigation, LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews, document research and video surveillance review. During confidential interviews, all parties interviewed stated that the client was in a bad mood, and there was a misunderstanding, between client and staff. No threats were made by staff to the participant. LPA reviewed video surveillance, which has no audio. The conversation between staff and participant was peaceful, without aggressive behavior. LPA conducted document research in an incident report dated 3-10-23 and shift notes. The incident report stated that it was one person’s word against another. Shift notes reveals that staff de-escalated the situation. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff threatened participant. Therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED

13On 11-8-23 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced inspection at Fred Finch Rising Oaks and met with Carolina Sousa, Housing Program Manager who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that staff do not prevent residents from harassing other residents and staff do not enforce visitor policies. LPA Karkazis conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, representatives, and conducted document research, in which inconsistent information was provided. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the allegation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Carolina Sousa, Housing Program Manager.

The investigation #CD1425-02023 was assigned to Community Care Licensing Investigations Branch (IB), Investigator Austin Blatnick. LPA Karkazis and Investigator Blatnick conducted confidential interviews and document research, in which inconsistent information was provided. narrative: On August 11, 2025, at 11:35 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cole Oliver conducted an unannounced case management visit to the facility. The purpose of the visit was to address concerns regarding unreceived incident reports (IRs). LPA Oliver met with Clinical Manager, Lauren Tanzer and Housing Program Manager, Carolina Soza. During the visit, LPA Oliver requested that all incident reports from January 1, 2025, through August 11, 2025, be emailed directly to LPA Oliver before 08/29/25. Beginning August 12, 2025, all incident reports are to be submitted to both Community Care Licensing (CCL) and LPA Oliver. In addition LPA Oliver went over IR reporting procedures. Clinical Manager Lauren Tanzer will send a test email to confirm successful communication. No violations were cited during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Clinical Manager Lauren Tanzer, whose signature confirms receipt. A copy will be emailed to Lauren Tanzer.

Reporting Requirements, Emailing Incident Reports to the CCLD Inbox Fresno. Administrator & Social worker- Qualifications and Duties, Personnel Requirements, Personnel Requirements, Criminal Record Clearance. Admission Agreements, Participants Medical Assessment, Register of Clients, Personal Rights.Telephones, Transportation, Health Related Services, Food Services, Responsibility for Care & Supervision, Activities, Building and Grounds. Inspection Authority of Licensing Agency, Department Approval for Remote Site Model, Waivers and Exceptions. Complains and the LPA, Deficiency Types, Extension Request, Types of Civil Penalties, Providers Information Notices (PINs), Complaint and Regulatory Enforcement CARE Tools, Officer of the Day, TSP Services. On May 5, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Vanessa Galvan and Olivia Medrano traveled to Golden Rose-Fowler, Fowler, CA, and met with Licensee Diana Luevanos. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a post-licensing inspection. LPA Galvan conducted a physical plant inspection and included the following observation and checks: client and staff files are kept in locked filing cabinets. The agency has adequate confidential meeting space, space for Social Worker and Case Manager to complete job duties. The facility has a current copy of the license, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights, LIC 610C, posted in a common area. The agency has a client register roster LIC 9120, with all required information. The agency’s office is located within two hours of travel time of the THPP participants living units. The agency employs (1) Administrator/Social Worker Supervisor/Program Director, (1) Case Manager, and (1) Transporter. LPAs reviewed two staff files. A review of the staff files on this date indicates that two facility staff has received child abuse index and fingerprint clearances. One staff did not have a clearance with child abuse index and fingerprint clearance. Staff files meet did not regulatory standards. The agency currently has (2) THPP NMD participants. LPA Galvan reviewed (2) THPP NMD Participant files on this date. Client files did not meet regulatory standards. LPA discussed the client's medical assessments, client’s Needs and Services Plans initial completed in 30 days and modification every six month, clients allowance/rent/emancipation savings and documentation, reminder of no comingling of funds. All staff need to have a fingerprint clearance prior to working for the program, requirement for staff files, availability of the Administrator, Staff training and documentation, documentation of fire drills, updating the LIC 610C to reflect second evacuation location. The facility is being cited for (4) Type A, (8) Type B, (2) Technical Violations, (1) Civil penalty. (See Attached LIC 9099D) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided discussed and provided to Diana Luevanos at the conclusion of the inspection.

No staff or client files were inspected. No staff or client interviews were conducted. The administrative office is located at 1672 Casarin Avenue, Unit #2., Simi Valley, CA 93065. The office is located on the back house unit and is set up as follows: The main office is for the administrator/supervising social worker and is currently used for storage. The main office has locked file cabinet to store staff and client files. There is a kitchen and restroom available. There is a detached garage that can be used as a conference room. The unit has sitting area with desk, couch, and table. All posting requirements were met. refrigerator, and kitchen appliances are in working condition. Smoke alarm was tested to be in working condition. There are (2) fire extinguishers. Thermostat was set to 70 degrees. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

On February 6, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk, scheduled and met with the facility licensee, administrator, and management team for an Informal Office meeting, held at the Woodland Hills Regional Office. The purpose of the meeting was to gain clarification about the current state of operation. Community Care Licensing Division staff in attendance: Bernice Karnsrithong, Children’s Residential Regional Manager (RM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Kevin Sauk, Licensing Children’s Residential Program Manager (LPM), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Nancy O’Connell, Children’s Residential Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Guiding Our Youth staff in attendance: Andrew Lang- Licensee. Paulette Poutre, staff. Melissa Kagen,staff. Maral Saltanian, staff. Madison Hall, staff. Kathleen Burrell, staff. Tessa Koziol, staff Introductions were conducted and LPM Sauk provided a copy of the meeting agenda to all in attendance. The following topics were addressed: Staff Roles, Staff Schedule, Inspection Authority, Care and Supervision, Emergency Intervention Plan, and Staff training. LPM Sauk provided general information about the applicable regulations related to aforementioned topics, and obtained clarification on facility policies and procedures. Facility staff provided responses to all topics addressed and were in agreement to provide information requested by the Department, update the facility program statement as needed and adhere to regulatory requirements. CCLD informed staff that reports would be generated and sent for review and signature

On the above date, LPA David Hiett met with the following representatives from applicant: Scott Singer, Chief Residential Program Officer Trisha Goodwin, Director of Transitional Housing and Alumni Relations Peter Tripp, THP FC (NMD) Specialist Coordinator Current status of county review/approval. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the current status of the application to become a THP NMD. Topics discussed were: Incorrect application organization Incomplete required forms Required contents of Program Statement / Plan of Operation Overview of expectations for providing detail descriptions of program operations Status of pending county review to and if further revisions will be requested by county.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Isabel Diego made an announced prelicensing inspection, on above date. LPA and LPM met with applicant, we and Administrator Scott Singer, director of transitional programs and vocational programs Trish Goodwin, and transitional housing programs facility coordinator Peter Tripp toured the office building. The applicant is applying for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) license with a capacity of 36 to serve minors and NMDs. LPA will update the system to reflect the new capacity from 24 to 36. Files will be kept locked in a filing cabinet in an office, on site.The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings with participants, if needed. LPA and LPM observed the office to be quiet, clean, and in good and safe condition. The office has storage space, meeting spaces, and a confidential meeting space. The office will be open Monday to Friday, 8AM to 5PM, and the program has a 24hr on-call worker. Participant records will be stored in a locked cabinet in the main back room of the office, The THPP has a Community Engagement Center/training center at this location for participants to utilize. All staff at the participant living unit will be fingerprint cleared prior to accepting any admissions. During inspection, LPA and LPM toured the office along with the three remote sites the facility will be using for participants that are in clean, and in good and safe condition. The facility will be housing two populations, minors and non minor dependents, at different locations and will not be commingling. At this time the department is requesting that the facility gets fingerprint clearance and during inspection the facility provided a clean copy of the program statement and electronic copy by March 30, 2023. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Scott Singer. Provisional licensure anticipated for 03/23/23.

At 11:45PM on 09/21/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karmen Balhotra made an unannounced Post-Licensing inspection to the facility listed above. LPA met with Scott Singer, Administrator and Trisha Goodwin, Director of Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) who helped facilitate the inspection. The facility is LPA entered the facility through the Admissions building and was directed to offices further down the campus to conduct the inspection. LPA toured the office, which has multiple offices and conference rooms where confidential space can be provided if needed by clients. LPA reviewed client and personnel files and all individuals were cleared via a Guardian roster search dated 09/21/2023. All files were locked in a filing cabinet in a secure location. All proper documentation is posted and the facility holds an accreditation through the Joint Commission and is valid until July 22, 2025. LPA walked to the THPP locations with THPP Director which is on the 70 plus acre campus of the facility. LPA toured two house which house minors and non-minor dependents separately. The facility houses two populations, minors and non-minor dependents. Each population is placed different locations within the facility campus. There are currently five minors and one non-minor dependent in placement. The THPP locations provide clients with their own room, bathroom, and personal storage. A communal kitchen is available to clients in placement and there is adequate amount of food available. The THPP location that has minors in placement have staff available 24 hours who also have a live-in staff room. In addition, there is on-call staff available when needed. LPA observed the toured locations to be free of any safety hazards. At this time, LPA will recommend for the facility to move forward from the Provisional License to a complete License. The department will mail copies of the license to the facility once approved by the department. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Director of THPP.

met_with: Director of Residence Jeremiah Presinal; Director of Transitional Programs Trisha Goodwin
narrative: At 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to the facility for a required 2-year inspection. LPA met with Director of Residence Jeremiah Presinal and Director of Transitional Programs Trisha Goodwin LPA reviewed 5 client files and 5 staff files. All files were observed to be complete and contain all required documentation. LPA toured the facility sites, met with and observed staff and clients, and conducted two confidential interviews. Based on LPA's observations and interviews, the facility sites are maintained in safe condition, clients' needs are being met, the environment provides multiple options for recreation, and the staff provide a supportive environment for the clients. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Director of Residence, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On December 17, 2020, at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ann Valenzuela and Adrian Mendez conducted a virtual inspection of the facility due to COVID-19 restrictions. LPAs met with Executive Director, Carrisa Hart, Clinical Director Joe Duquesnel, and Controller Kenny Geh for a pre-license of a Transitional Housing Program (THP). Kenny gave a virtual tour of the THP office and apartment. The office resides at 308 N. Lemon Street, Fullerton, CA 92832, located behind the Monkey Business Cafe. The office consists of a waiting area that connects to the staff kitchen which houses a large table and chairs for a conference area. The office building has one restroom, and three offices. One office is the Controller's office which houses the residents files in a locked filling cabinet. There is another office for the case managers, and an office for the Operational Manager, where the personnel files are also kept in a locked cabinet. All three offices have locking doors. LPAs observed computers and phones in the offices. When exiting the backdoor of the office there is a parking lot with ample parking and seven garages, between the office building and the THP apartments. The apartments are two stories with units A and D downstairs, and units B and C upstairs. All units are identical in floor plan. LPAs toured unit B which consist of a living room, two bedrooms, bathroom, kitchen and a laundry area. The unit had new hardwood floors throughout the living room and bedrooms. The laundry area had a washer and dryer. The unit has ample storage space throughout the apartment. The windows had blinds for privacy. The upstairs apartments have two entrance and exits; one in the from of the complex and the other in the back by the parking. The downstairs apartments have small backyards, which are intended to be converted into a garden an accessible for all residents. The units will be furnished at the time of occupancy, for the resident to choose furnishings. The facility meets the Regulatory requirements and is ready for licensure at the conclusion of the visit. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to the Applicant for signature and returned to LPA to maintain in CCL facility file.

On November 18, 2021 at 1:58 PM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Anastasia Flores and Leslie Covarrubias arrived and was greeted by Hart Community Homes, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) Controller, Kenny Geh for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Required/ Annual Licensing Inspection for the agency's (THPP) At 2:21 PM, LPA’s toured the facility with Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. Facility utilizes apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has 4 Apartments designated for THPP/ NMD. The LPA’s toured apartment #B, the apartment was observed to be fully furnished to provide the basic necessities for the residents. There are six Non minor dependents (NMD) youth who are currently in placement with the agency. The client files are located in locked file cabinets in the center of the main office. The agency employ's the following assigned staff under the THPP program :Program Director, Joe Duquesnel, Case Manager Supervisor/Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez, one case manager, Marlyn Posadas. Staff and client records need to be reviewed at a later date. Facility was unable to provide an LIC500 for the LPA’s at the time of the inspection. The facility is being cited for Title 22, Division 6, chapter 7, section 86071(a)(2)(A) Participant of clients, based on record review, the licensee did not have the client’s files in a confidentially secure area. Upon inspection the client files were kept in an unlocked cabinet in the center of the administration office, section; 86030.5(e) Identification of Transitional Housing Placement Program Participant Living Units, based on interview with Celia Vasquez and Kenny Geh and record review, the licensee did not know if the agency kept a copy of the certificate of compliance, section; 86030.5(c)(1) Identification of Transitional Housing Placement Program Participant Living Units, based on observation and interview, the licensee was unsure of what the certificate of compliance is or if the agency had one for each client's residence, (continued on next page)

section; 86071(a)(1)(B) Register of participants, based on observation and record review, six of six clients, the licensee did not have the physician information listed on the client roster and Health and safety Code (HSC) 1565(c) Other provisions, based on interview, the licensee does not conduct a drill every quarter which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. In addition, the facility is being cited for 86161 (i) (1)Reporting Requirements, based on interview with program administrator, the licensee is not reporting the law enforcement contact information to the department as specified in the ILS guidelines. Carissa Hart verbally approved Celia Vasquez to sign for the report as a LIC308 was not readily available for LPA’s upon inspection. A copy of this report, 809D’s, and appeal rights were provided to Celia Vasquez.

On September 11, 2023, at 12:30 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Celia Vasquez, STRTP Administrator, of Hart Community Homes. The purpose of the case management inspection is to follow up on information received by Community Care Licensing. It was reported on 08/15/2023 that the Administrator no longer worked at the facility, and CCL had not received notification of change of the Administrator. LPA spoke with Celia Vasquez, who confirmed that their Administrator resigned on 07/14/2023. LPA requested the facility to submit its plan for the Administrator Change within 10 days. LPA reviewed the Administrator’s employee file. Based on interviews and records reviewed, the facility is cited for one deficiency (refer to LIC 809D) from Title 22, Chapter 7, Subchapter 1, 86161(j) Reporting Requirements. An exit interview and appeal rights were discussed with Celia Vasquez. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the Facility Administrator. A signed copy of the report will be placed in the facility file.

deficiencies.description:
86161 Reporting Requirements
(j)	The licensee shall notify the licensing agency, within ten business days of a change of administrator.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review the Licensee did not notify Community Care Licensing regarding the absence of a current certified administrator, which poses an immediate health and safety risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Celia, they are the now the designated THPP Administrator and Celia will send the updated LIC 500 and board letter by 5:00 pm on 09/11/2023.

narrative:
On December 01, 2023, at 09:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst’s (LPA’s) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado conducted an unannounced random annual licensing inspection at Hart Community Homes, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA’s met with Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. The facility utilizes apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has four apartments designated for THPP/ NMD’s use. There are seven non-minor dependents (NMD) youth who are currently in placement with the agency. The agency employs the following assigned staff under the THPP program: Program Director, Program Administrator, none case manager. The LPA’s toured apartment #B, the apartment was observed to be fully furnished to provide the basic necessities for the participants. The office resides at 208 N. Lemon Street, Fullerton, CA 92832, located behind the Monkey Business Cafe. The office consists of a waiting area that connects to the staff kitchen which houses a large table and chairs for a conference area. The office building has one restroom, and three offices. One office is the Controller's office which houses the participant files in a locked filling cabinet. There is another office for the case managers, and an office for the Operational Manager, where the personnel files are also kept in a locked cabinet. All three offices have locking doors. LPAs observed computers and phones in the offices. LPA’s reviewed a drill log of the emergency disaster and casualty plan. During the inspection, LPA’s reviewed seven participant files. Four out of seven (P1, P2, P3, P4) participant files reviewed did not have a medical assessment completed. LPA’s also reviewed two staff files, Staff #1 (S1) did not have a criminal record clearance. Continued on next page

Based on interviews and records review, the facility is cited for deficiency from Title 22, Chapter 7, Subchapter 1, sections, 86019(e) Criminal Record Clearance and 86069(a) Participant Medical Assessment. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 809D’s, and appeal rights were provided to Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. Civil Penalties were assessed.

narrative:
On December 5, 2024, at 1:20 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an unannounced random annual licensing inspection at Hart Community Homes, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA met with Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. The facility is licensed to provide ten placements for Transitional Housing Placement Program Non-Minor Dependent (THPP-NMD) from ages 18 (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently nine participants in the THPP-NMD program. The facility utilizes a scattered site apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has four apartments designated for THPP/ NMD’s use as a single site and one apartment located in Laguna Hills. The agency employs the following assigned staff under the THPP program: Program Director/ Program Administrator and Case Manager. The administrative office resides at 208 N. Lemon Street, Fullerton, CA 92832, located behind the Monkey Business Cafe. The office consists of a waiting area that connects to the staff kitchen which houses a large table and chairs for a conference area. The office building has one restroom, and three offices. The client files are locked in a locked file cabinet in the reception area. There is another office for the Case Managers, and an office for the Human Resources Director, where the personnel files are also kept in a locked cabinet. All three offices have locking doors. LPA observed computers and phones in the offices. The Program Director was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 25 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Program Director is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department to include all Law Enforcement contacts. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

LPA reviewed two staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA also reviewed five THPP-NMD Participant files. Based on record review, LPA observed two out of five client files (C3, C4) were missing a written medical assessment and one out of five client files (C5) was missing the Needs and Services Plan. Therefore, the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations Section Division Six 86069(a) Participant Medical Assessment and Interim Licensing Standards AB 12 Nonminor Dependents THPP Regulation 86268.3(a) Needs and Services Plan. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Celia Vasquez. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report was emailed to Celia Vasquez.

On August 7, 2025, at 11:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced annual licensing inspection at Hart Community Homes, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA met with Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. The facility is licensed to provide ten placements for Transitional Housing Placement Program Non-Minor Dependent (THPP-NMD) from ages 18 through 21. There are currently nine participants in the THPP-NMD program. LPA observed all licensing fees to be current. The facility utilizes a scattered site apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has four apartments designated for THPP/NMD. The agency employs the following assigned staff under the THPP program: Program Director/ Program Administrator and Case Manager. The administrative office is located at 208 N. Lemon Street, Fullerton, CA 92832. The office consists of a waiting area that connects to the staff kitchen which houses a large table and chairs for a conference area.The office building has one restroom, and three offices. The client files are locked in a locked file cabinet in the reception area. There is another office for the Case Managers, and an office for the Human Resources Director, where the personnel files are also kept in a locked cabinet. All three offices have locking doors. *****CONTINUED ON PAGE 2****

****CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1**** LPA observed computers and phones in the offices. LPA observed Community Care Licensing required documents posted in a prominent area on the wall, which include License (LIC 200), Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610C), See Something Say Something (PUB 45), Personal Rights, and Grievance Policy. The Program Director was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 25 ratio, which should never be exceeded. The Program Director is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department to include all Law Enforcement contacts. LPA reviewed two staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA also reviewed five THPP-NMD Participant files. LPA reviewed five client files (C1-C5), to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. Client files had signed personal rights forms, signed admission agreements, education records, physical examinations, and Needs and Services plans. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies were observed during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted, this report was discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to the Program Administrator, Celia Vasquez. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file. Due to technical issues the Administrator was emailed today's inspection report.

On 04/25/2022 at 12:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted a visit to the main office of the above facility. On 04/23/2022, LPA was informed that an 18 year old client of the facility had died of an overdose on 04/22/2022. LPA met with April Pao, Program Manager. The facility had not yet completed a Needs and Services plan for this client. LPA collected copies of the Transitional Independent Living Plan, the client's progress notes, and the information for the other clients. LPA also discussed with April Pao, Program Manager, what steps the facility is taking to help staff and youth process the incident. Program Manager discussed the plan following the incident. The facility is providing and will continue to provide grief counseling to clients and staff. Facility has also provided extra support to clients by having dinners and allowing discussion. There is a session scheduled with a trauma therapist for the staff, and more resources being provided to the clients. Facility has begun informing all clients' teams and reaching out directly to the clients themselves to check in. The facility is also working with the client's mother to receive their belongings. LPA conducted an exit interview with April Pao, Program Manager at 2:25PM. Facility will provide updates on the counseling sessions and when the family collects the client's belongings.

On 04/22/2022 at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual visit. LPA Selena Hood and LPA Lisette Valenzuela met with April Pao, Program Manager, at the main office. LPA Hood and LPA Valenzuela reviewed three client files, ten staff files, and interviewed one staff member. LPAs also conducted a physical plant inspection. No Type A or Type B deficiencies were cited. LPAs cited three Technical Violations for: Interim Licensing Standard Version 86268.3(a), ILS 86268.3(d), and ILS 86068.3(b) (see LIC9102s). LPAs conducted an exit interview with April Pao, Program Manager, at 2:40PM. LPAs discussed and delivered appeal rights.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Sethany Yem and Dung Mac conducted a case management inspection on 6/05/2024 at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. Three out of 7 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youths were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 6/05/2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the Board Meeting Minutes related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Emergency Prevention Plan and Needs and Services Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Libby Matulich, Program Manager.

facility_name: HEART MATTERS TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAM, THE
narrative:
On 4/30/21, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Carrie Mathews who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an announced pre-licensing inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator at 11:05am. Presently, the THPP NMD has requested a capacity of 50 NMD’s who will be placed in remote site apartments and host families. Licensee was advised the apartments must be located within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in San Bernardino County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area equipped with two desks, another office space equipped with five work stations, a kitchen area, bathroom, and locked storage room. In addition there is a large storage area located off the kitchen. The office space will be utilized by the out stationed staff and by the THPP NMD's. The kitchen area was equipped with a refrigerator, variety of snacks and a microwave. The area was equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. Throughout the office there are motivational signs, along with an educational and employment resource area. According to Administrator all participant files will be stored in locked storage room. LPA observed two locked storage cabinets within the storage room which will hold the THPP NMD files and the staff files. Per licensee only the Administrator and CEO will be provided to the keys to the storage room. Currently the THPP is only staffed with the Administrator, all additional positions will be hired after obtaining the CCL license. During this inspection Component III for THPP NMD was conducted by LPA Zirbes. During this component, LPA discussed Post Licensing Visits that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations; NMD regulations, personal fingerprint requirements, associations, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA informed the Administrator, about the reporting requirements specifically, AB388 and LIC 624 LE. Furthermore, Provider Information Notices (PIN), Resource Guides and the process for designating a new facility Administrator was reviewed.

Licensee was advised that this pre-licensing report and application will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are licensed as a THPP NMD. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Carrie Mathews and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility. The signed report will be in the facility file.

facility_name: HEART MATTERS TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAM, THE
narrative:
On May 11, 2022 at 1:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Sarah Smith met with Program Administrator, Jami Sheridan to conduct an unannounced post-licensing inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Program Administrator at 5:30 p.m. Presently, the THPP NMD has a capacity of 50 NMD’s who are placed in remote site apartments and host families. The current census is five. All remote sites are within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in San Bernardino County. Currently, the office is in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area equipped with two desks, and three additional office spaces, a kitchen area, bathroom, and locked storage room. In addition there is a computer lab located off the kitchen. The office space is utilized by the Program Administrator, the Evolution Coach/Social Worker, and by the THPP NMD's. The kitchen area was equipped with a refrigerator, variety of snacks and a microwave. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. Throughout the office there are motivational signs, along with an educational and employment resource area. All participant and staff files were stored in locked storage room. LPA observed two locked storage cabinets within the storage room which hold the THPP NMD files. The staff files are maintained off site. Only the Administrator has the keys to the storage room. Currently the THPP is staffed with the Program Administrator, and two social workers. Based on LPA file review and observations, the facility will be cited for Title 22 Regulations: Personnel Records 86066(a)(11), 86066(a)(12), and Interim Licensing Standards: Participant Medical Assessment 86069(a), Non-minor Dependents' Record 86270(a)(2)(E), and Needs and Services Plan 86268.3(c)(1). -----continued on next page-----

An exit interview was conducted with Program Administrator, Jami Sheridan and a copy of this report and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

facility_name: HEART MATTERS TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAM, THE
narrative: Documents received by LPA Almaraz reiterated that clients were not allowed to have animals at the facility. Confidential witness stated that C1 had brought an unauthorized animal into the facility and C1 had trouble with keeping C1’s residence clean. Other confidential witnesses stated that at a prior placement C1 was allowed to have an emotional support animal. It was added that facility staff made it seem like C1 would be allowed to have a companion animal for therapeutic needs at this facility. In regard to the allegation that facility staff do not accord dignity to C1, confidential witnesses stated that facility staff always responded in a timely manner and at no time did facility staff avoid any of C1’s questions. Other confidential witness stated that C1’s questions regarding approval of an emotional support animal were ignored by several facility staff. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that facility staff did not meet client #1’s (C1) needs by not allowing C1 to have a companion animal for therapeutic needs and that facility staff was avoiding C1’s questions regarding a companion animal may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was explained and provided to Carrie Mathews.
investigation_findings: 13On August 3, 2022 at 12:47 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Michael Almaraz arrived at the facility and met with Executive Director, Carrie Mathews, to issue the finding for the above stated allegations. The complaint investigation was jointly conducted by LPA A. Flores and LPA M. Almaraz. On December 15, 2021, at 9:44 AM LPA Flores arrived at the facility to initiate the investigation. During the inspection, LPA Flores reviewed staff and client records. Additionally, LPA Almaraz conducted interviews with one of one client listed on the confidential names list (LIC 811), two staff, and County Social Worker (CSW). On December 9, 2021, the Department received a complaint alleging that facility is not meeting a non-minor dependent's therapeutic needs and facility staff do not accord dignity to foster non-minor dependent. It was specifically alleged that facility staff did not meet client #1’s (C1) needs by not allowing C1 to have a companion animal for therapeutic needs and facility staff was avoiding C1’s questions regarding a companion animal. During the investigation, confidential witnesses stated that clients were not allowed to have animals in the program, and it was disclosed to C1 prior to placement. (continued on next page...)

facility_name: HEART MATTERS TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAM, THE
narrative:
On April 19, 2023 at 10:47 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced visit to The Heart Matters, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met and toured the facility with Program Administrator, Kyndle Crigler. Presently, the THPP has a capacity of 50 participants who are placed in remote site apartments in Moreno Valley and Colton. All remote sites are within two hours of the administrative office. The current census is 18 participants in the program. The THPP Administrative office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area equipped with two desks, a kitchen area, a bathroom, a locked storage room, additional office spaces, and a computer lab that is available for participants to use. The office space is utilized by the Program Administrator, the Evolution Coach (Social Worker), and by the THPP’s participants. The kitchen area is equipped with a refrigerator, a microwave, and a variety of snacks. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. Throughout the office there are motivational signs as well as an educational and employment resource area for participants to utilize. Facility showed LPA a copy of the emergency binder kept at remote site apartments, a drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. All participant records are kept under lock in a storage room. LPA observed two locked storage cabinets within the storage room which hold the participant files. The Program Administrator has the keys to the locked storage room. Currently, the THPP is staffed with one Executive Director, one Program Administrator, and one Evolution Coach (Social Worker). All staff files are located off site in a different office suite that is located within the same retail business establishment. LPA observed staff files were stored under lock and were available for LPA to review. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. *Next page LIC 809-C*

LPA reviewed three staff files, five participant files, and completed two staff interviews. All three staff files reviewed met the minimum qualifications as required by the Department and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. All five participant files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. Based on observation and record review, the facility is in compliance and no deficiencies were noted at this time. Exit interview conducted with Program Administrator, Kyndle Crigler, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

facility_name: HEART MATTERS TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAM, THE
narrative:
On May 6, 2024 at 10:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced visit at The Heart Matters, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMDs). The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA met and did a walk-through of the facility with, Administrator, Jennifer Reyes. The THPP has a capacity for up to 50 participants who are placed in remote site apartments in Moreno Valley and Colton. All remote sites are within two hours of the administrative office. Currently, the census for the THPP is 25 Participants. The THPP Administrative office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area equipped with two desks, a kitchen area, a bathroom, a locked storage room, additional office spaces, and a computer lab that is available for participants to use. The office space is utilized by office staff and THPP participants. The kitchen area is equipped with a refrigerator, a microwave, and a variety of snacks. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, supplies, and has an area to conduct private interviews. Throughout the office there are motivational signs as well as educational and employment resources for participants to utilize. LPA reviewed copies of pertinent records such as certificates of compliance, the emergency binders kept at remote site apartments, and drill logs for emergency disasters. Participant records are kept in a locked cabinet inside a locked storage room which can be accessed with a key. All staff files are located off site in a different office suite that is located within the same retail business establishment. Staff files are stored under lock and were available for LPA to review. Currently, the THPP is staffed with one Executive Director, one Program Administrator, one Program Manager, two Evolution Coaches (Social Workers), and one Program Assistant. *Continued on next page LIC 809-C*

Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should not be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. While at the facility, LPA reviewed five personnel records, five participant records, and conducted two staff interviews. Five out of five staff files reviewed had a completed health screening/tuberculosis (TB) test and have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances on file. Five out of five personnel records reviewed had completed a minimum of one hour training in child abuse identification and met the minimum qualifications as required by the Department. Five out of five participant files reviewed had required documents including admission agreement, personal rights, medical/education history, immunization records, an initial/current Needs and Services Plan (NSP), and a completed Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP). Four out of five participant records reviewed did not have a written medical assessment prior to or within 30 calendar days of their acceptance into the program. Four out of five participant records reviewed did not have results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis on file. Based on observation and record review, the facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR) sections: 86069(a) and 86069(b)(1) which poses a potential health and safety risk to clients in care. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of this report along with LIC 809-C and LIC 809-D were given to Administrator, Jennifer Reyes.

Present at the meeting from Heritage THPP was Sandi Heyer, Executive Director. During the meeting the following items were discussed: 1. All requested revisions in the application documents (LIC401 and LIC610C) have been submitted by applicant and has been reviewed by LPA Silva. 2. Applicant requested change in capacity from 24 to 48. A new LIC200 and the difference in licensing fee due to capacity change will be submitted to the Regional Office on 06/11/24. 3. LPA Silva requested revisions to the Program Statement/Plan of Operation (POO/PS) due to capacity change : Page 2 of POO/PS (capacity states 24), LIC500 and Table of Organization 4. LPA Silva requested to include Telecommunications Device Notification LIC9158 in the intake process of the POO/PS. 5. On June 14, 2024 at 9:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an announced pre-licensing inspection and Component III meeting. LPA met with Executive Director Sandi Heyer and Administrator Maria Serratos. The THPP-NMD program will provide services to non-minor dependents, ages 18 to 21, in remote sites within two (2) hours of driving distance from the agency’s administrative office. A tour of the office was conducted. The office building is located in a commercial area with adequate parking spaces available. There are multiple office spaces, a conference room, a storage room, kitchen and restrooms. All office spaces/rooms are well equipped with desks, chairs, computers, file cabinets and shelves. The offices provide privacy for confidential interviews. Telephone service is available in the THPP office. There are locked file cabinets in place to secure staff and client files. Fire extinguishers, carbon monoxide and fire alarms are in place. The facility has a current Emergency and Disaster Plan available in the office. LPA observed the facility to be in good repair, well equipped and ready for operation. A Component III meeting was also conducted to familiarize the applicant with THPP Rules and Regulations as well as best practices. The purpose of the Component III is also to prepare the applicant on how to maintain and operate their facility and provide information to avoid potential problem areas. A copy of the THPP Component III handout was provided to Ms.Heyer and Ms. Serratos. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was provided to the Executive Director.

On May 28, 2025 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Post Licensing inspection. LPA met with Executive Director, Sandi Heyer. The THPP-NMD program provides services to non-minor dependents, ages 18 to 21, in remote sites within two (2) hours of driving distance from the agency’s administrative office. PHYSICAL PLANT The facility license is posted in a prominent location. All participant records are maintained in a secure area or locked file cabinets in the administrative office. The administrative office has telephone service on the premises. The office provides privacy for confidential interviews. OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS The facility maintains a register of participants available upon request. The facility is currently operating within licensing regulations. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS The facility has an emergency and disaster plan for the THPP NMD participants. The emergency plan includes emergency information, instructions, and telephone numbers, including a 24-hour emergency number for the licensee and the participant’s responsible party.

STAFF RECORDS LPA reviewed four (4) staff records (refer to Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 05/28/25). Staff records are available upon request. The agency is in compliance with the social worker ratio. Program Administrator meets the education and experience requirements, completed the required training, file contains the Statement acknowledging requirement to report child abuse, fingerprint, and child abuse index check clearances and current with CPR and first aid. CLIENT RECORDS The facility currently has twelve (12) transitional housing placement participants ages 18-21 years old. LPA reviewed five (5) THPP participant's records. The facility ensured that the Transitional Independent Living Plan/Needs and Services Plan is signed by the NMD, the THPP Administrator or SW personnel and the agency responsible for placement. The facility ensured the participants record are maintained locked on site in the THPP office. LPA interviewed one (1) staff. During today's visit, no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the Executive Director.

On 07/15/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith conducted the Component II - Face to Face office interview at the El Segundo Regional Office with Casey Meinster, Administrator. The THPP application and program statement was reviewed and discussed with staff. The following documents are needed and Casey stated that she will submit to licensing by Monday, July 21, 2025: 1. Update LIC 500-Personnel Report - Job descriptions should match job title on personnel report. Refer to THPP regulations. Provide the correct job descriptions for Administrator, Supervising Social Worker, Social worker personnel, etc. 2. Update and submit organization chart. 3. New application, LIC 200, submitted with name of program Hillsides THPP NMD (Submitted in office) 4. Update LIC 610C-Emergency Disaster Plan- due to being incomplete (Updated and received in office). Continued on LIC809C

5. LIC 999-Facility Sketch: should be of administration office with correct address. 6. Submit correct form- LIC 508D: Out -of-State Disclosure & Criminal Record Statement. 7. LIC 9165- Resubmit new forms. Forms received are outdated and must apply to the THPP application. 8. LIC 309-Administrative Organization needs to be completed (see section 10. Officers) 9. Create a certificate of compliance to certify that living units meet regulation requirements. 10. Applicant and administrator must be associated to the facility. 11. LPA informed Administrator to apply for a rate with Foster Care Rates. Administrator told LPA and LPM that she needed to wait until Provisional License was received. 12. Fire clearance is pending to accept non-ambulatory clients. During the review of the plan of operation, there were several compliance concerns that must be corrected. For example, there were statements that referred to “youth” instead of “Non-Minor Dependents” and incorrect section codes referenced. Clarification is needed of job titles. Submit revisions to Plan of Operation/Program Statement. Include details regarding smoking prohibition (Refer to section XVII-Unauthorized Purchases). Component III is scheduled for Wednesday, July 16, 2025, via Microsoft Teams at 10:30am. Pre-licensing visit is scheduled for Thursday, July 17, 2025 at 9:30am. On 07/16/25, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Andrea Aceves and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at Hillsides THPP. LPA and LPM met with Director, Andrew Hernandez. At the time of the visit, there are no clients in placement. The facility is seeking a license to provide care for capacity of twenty (20) which ten (10) are ambulatory and ten (10) are non-ambulatory, Non-Minor Dependents, ages 18-21 and are using a remote site model. Facility Overview: The THPP-NMD administration office is located in a commercial building within suite 140 and also utilized as a resource center. The entrance to the suite can be accessed during office hours. The lobby of the suite has resource information brochures available for visitors as well as the Emergency Disaster Plan was posted and visible. The suite office is a large area with a reception area. The suite has a workstation area with multiple computers available for clients. There are five (5) small offices in which one (1) will be designated for confidential interviews for clients and CCL staff. In addition, a locked storage cabinet will be placed in the meeting space to store any confidential files. The suite has a large conference table with multiple chairs for clients. There is a TV area with a PlayStation, chairs for clients and a bookshelf with books and board games. A music room is available for clients. A kitchen area that includes a stove, microwave and refrigerator is available for clients. A shower room and laundry room are also accessible for clients. Cameras are also placed throughout the suite’s common areas. See LIC809C

The licensee will store client and staff files electronically and must be readily available to CCL staff upon request. All staff must be associated to THPP-NMD prior to working in the facility. Licensee submitted a revised Plan of Operation, and the LPA will review it. LPA received the following documents from Andrew: · Revised THPP LIC500-Personnel Report · Revised LIC508D-Criminal Record Statements · Updated LIC309-Administrative Organization · Updated Organizational Chart · Update THPP-NMD Administrative Office Facility Sketch · Revised Plan of Operation · Updated Expectations · Revised Job Descriptions * Group Home application to reduce capacity and check Fire Clearance for non-ambulatory NMD remains pending. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Director, Andrew Hernandez.

At 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the facility above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Case Management - Non-Compliance Inspection. List of all units overseen by the facility, including address and vacancy status 2. Staff training sign-in sheets for the last 6 months 3. Updated LIC500 - Staff Roster 4. Stipend distribution log/Licensing safeguard form/stipend deduction log for 4 random residents from September 2020. 5. September 2020 utility bills for 4 random residents. 6.
