During the investigation, LPA Raissi and Tran conducted various interviews and email interactions with client and two staff members. Please refer to the confidential names list LIC811 dated November 4, 2020. LPA Raissi and Tran interviewed (C1) on September 30, 2020 and October 1, 2020. Then LPA Raissi interviewed two staff members (S1 and S2) on October 7th-15th of 2020 via Zoom. LPA Raissi obtained a copy of the C1 Lease agreement, C1’s needs and service plan, and the Shared Living Agreement (SLA) which details agency, Holly Place’s no pet policy. Regarding the allegation, client denied service animal, LPA Raissi had a telephone interview with S2 on October 15, 2020. S2 told C1 on September 29, 2020 that there should be a meeting with management and C1 to address the matter of having an Emotional Support Animal (ESA). S2 was told by (THPP) agency that animals were not allowed by the landlord. S2 notified management and a meeting was scheduled to review. Based on interview with S1 on October 8, 2020 and S2 on October 15, 2020, clients can have an ESA. Agency is looking to implement into their policy for future clients. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore, LPA Raissi have found this complaint was unsubstantiated as C1 was approved to have an ESA. No citation was given. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Ron Dhillon. LPAs Raissi and Tran requested that a copy of the findings be signed and sent back to LPA Tran (AmyLe.Tran@dss.ca.gov).
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) AmyLe Tran and Sam Raissi conducted an announced virtual visit to the above listed facility to inform Executive Director, Ron Dhillon (S1) and Program Coordinator, Mandave Sandhu via tele-visit, of the findings for the above listed complaint allegation. narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) AmyLe Tran conducted a case management tele-inspection to the TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PLACEMENT PROGRAM (THPP) agency, Holly Place on March 26, 2021, at 3:30 PM via tele-visit (due to COVID 19). LPA met with Administrator, Pamela Mack (PMack) via Microsoft Teams. The purpose of the case management was regarding incident reports mailed to Community Care Licensing (CCL) and received on March 18, 2021. Administrator informed LPA about fax/scanner was not working properly on 03/03/2021. Refer to (811 Confidential Names list, March 26, 2021). LPA requested the following documents: No guest/visitor policy due to covid-19, and contacts for clients involved in the listed incidents below. Incident date: 10/16/2020 On 10/15/2020, C2’s baby’s father was arrested by the police on site. C2 was punched and chased around the unit by her baby’s father. The ambulance was at the scene as C2 broke her finger. C2 was chased by her baby’s father with a knife. C2’s baby was also at the scene and safe. CM was called by C1 and arrived immediately. Incident date: 11/27/2020 On 11/27/2020, C3 stated C4 had accused her for going into her room and had verbal altercations. C3 had called the police. C3 reported there were gun shots in the unit during the incident. CM was informed and had a discussion with both C3 and C4. (Continue on LIC 809

Incident date: 02/02/2021 On 02/02/2021, C5 and C6 had verbal altercations and were ready to into a physical fight. Case Manager (CM) was also present to help de-escalate the situation. C6 started making phone calls telling someone to bring a gun because he was going to shoot C5. C5 called the police right away. CM took C5 to a local hotel for his safety. C5 was moved to a new unit and C6 was terminated from Holly Place. Incident date: 03/09/2021 On 03/09/2021, C8 had contacted the police due to safety concerns. C7 and C8 had a verbal altercation. C8 had saw a gun and called the police due to safety concerns. C7 was terminated from Holly Place program. Incident date: 03/20/2021 On 03/20/2021, C9 reported to Case Manager (CM) that she was in a physical altercation with roommate, C10. C10 accusing C9 had stolen the packages delivered for C10. C10’s boyfriend was also present and kicked open C9’s bedroom door. C9 and C10 began to fight. C10 threatened to stab C9 with a knife. C10 and her boyfriend left the unit. On 03/21/2021, C10 returned to the unit with boyfriend and mother. C10 packed her items and left. The agency has acted by providing support, increased supervision and monitor, added CFT meetings, offered counseling and moving clients to another unit site for added safety reasons. There appears to be no negligence on behalf of the staff and agency. Once assigned case manager was called for the incident, they acted immediately to provide proper support for clients. If further information develops regards to these matters, PMack agrees to update LPA Tran with any ongoing developments. No citation was given for this visit. A copy of this report was emailed to PMack for review and signature acknowledges receipt. (End)

On 04/29/2021 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) AmyLe Tran met with the facility above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Case Management - Non-Compliance Inspection. Due to COVID-19 precautions, this virtual inspection is being conducted in place of an in-person inspection of the program office. LPA met with Holly's Place Administrator, Pamela 'PMack' Mack, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 55 NMDs. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 04/28/2021) LPA Tran conducted interview with S1. LPA Tran started this inspection by requesting the following documents, to be submitted through email no later than end of business hours on Monday, 05/03/2021: 1. List of all units overseen by the facility, including address and vacancy status 2. Staff training sign-in sheets for the last 6 months 3. Updated LIC500 - Staff Roster 4. Stipend distribution log/Licensing safeguard form/stipend deduction log for 4 random residents from January 2021 to present. 5. February 2021 utility bills for 3 random residents. 6. January 2021 maintenance/repairs log 7. 3 random TILPs Upon review of Auditor's report, it was learned that the licensee did not have adequate records available to determine if clients were receiving their stipend checks on time or at all, or if clients being appropriately charged for maintenance and repairs, and not refunding the client's emancipation upon discharge.

Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80064(a)(4) Administrator - Qualifications and Duties. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Pamela Mack, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. (End)

On 01/05/2021, the San Jose Children’s Residential Program Regional Office receive a complaint for the facility, Holly Place with allegation: “Facility is in disrepair”. This complaint was assigned to LPA, Madeleine Fremont on 01/05/2021, then reassigned to LPA, AmyLe Tran on 04/21/2021. During the investigation, LPA Tran conducted various interviews and email interactions with client and 3 staff members with Holly Place. LPA interviewed and interacted with client P1 on (04/22/2021), S1 on (03/16/2021), S2 on (03/16/2021), S3 on (05/12/2021), and S4 on (03/26/2021). LPA Tran reached out to SW1 multiple times on (05/04/2021, 05/19/2021, and 05/21/2021) with no response. LPA Tran obtained a copy and reviewed the following documents: Maintenance requests from P1, TILP Needs and Services for P1, PG&E for November and December of 2020, promise to pay invoice/debt agreement, Updated LIC-500, Incident reports involving P1, list of P1 stipend deductions and records dated 05/21/2020 – 12/29/2029, and Holly Place’s Shared Living Agreement. Based on interviews, documents received, and incident reports, the agency has been responsive with client’s maintenance requests. LPA Tran interviewed P1 on 04/22/2021. P1 stated “I don’t want to proceed with the complaint anymore. Holly Place has provided me space heaters to help my place keep warm.” LPA Tran informed P1 that the investigation still needs to be conducted to ensure the agency is within compliance. Then on 05/12/2021, LPA interviewed S3. S3 had the property owners involved to ensure the heater was working properly. Property owners had the Warranty company and HVAC companies arrived on multiple occasions to ensure unit heater is working properly. The repair technicians stated heater has an automatic shut off for safety reasons. Both heater in unit is working properly. Tenant would put heater on full blast causing the auto shut off. Technicians verified the heater was working but not warm enough for tenant’s medical condition. Property owners immediately brought space heaters for tenants as a solution. (Continue on LIC 9099-C)

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore, the complaint allegations: “Facility is in disrepair” is unsubstantiated. No citation was given. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Ron Dhillon. LPA Tran requested that a copy of the findings be signed and sent back to LPA Tran (AmyLe.Tran@dss.ca.gov). (End)

narrative:
On 03/10/2021, the San Jose Children’s Residential Program Regional Office receive a complaint for the facility, Holly Place with two allegations: “Facility is in disrepair” and “Facility staff are withholding non-minor dependent's money.” This complaint was assigned to LPA Tran on 03/10/2021. During the investigation, LPA Tran conducted various interviews and email interactions with client and 4 staff members. LPA interviewed and interacted with S1 and S2 on (03/16/2021), then S3 on (03/16/2021, 03/24/2021, 03/17/2021, and 04/19/2021), and S4 on (03/26/2021 and 04/12/2021). LPA Tran also interviewed C1’s Social Worker, SW on (04/12/2021). Lastly, LPA Tran interviewed C1 on (03/15/202, 04/12/2021, and 04/19/2021). LPA Tran obtained a copy of the following documents: Maintenance requests from C1, Receipts for Pest Control Service for apartment unit, Electronic Stipend Ledger, List of participants located at the Spring Dr. Hayward apartment, Transitional Independent Living Plan and Agreement for C1, Appraisal Needs and Services Plan for C1, Promise to pay invoice/debt agreement, and Holly Place’s Shared Living Agreement. Based on interviews, documents received, and incident reports, the agency has been responsive with client’s maintenance requests. LPA Tran interviewed S3 and S4 on 04/12/2021, S4 conducts weekly meeting with C1. C1 did not mention about the leak issue of refrigerator. On 04/06/2021 C1 denied maintenance services and repair diagnosis. The lack of cooperation from C1 prolongs the maintenance issue available for clients. The agency posted notices to enter the apartment 24-48 hours before entering unit to make repairs and replacement refrigerator delivery. On 03/17/2021 LPA Tran reviewed documents: Electronic Stipend Ledger, Transitional Independent Living Plan and Agreement for C1, Appraisal Needs and Services Plan for C1, Promise to pay invoice/debt agreement, and Holly Place’s Shared Living Agreement. C1 signed agreement dated on 12/16/2020, agreeing to have $100 from Stipend funds to be added to savings account. C1 receives $400 every over week for the infant fund and receives $150 every week as stipend. C1 signed agreement on withholding $100 into savings account. The saving balance amount will be provided to C1 when she leaves the program and agency. (Continue on LIC 9099-C)

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore, the complaint allegations: “Facility is in disrepair” and “Facility staff are withholding non-minor dependent's money” is unsubstantiated. No citation was given. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Ron Dhillon. narrative: At 11:53AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the facility above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management Inspection. This inspection is in regards to an LIC624A - Death Report involving C1 which was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 08/17/2021. LPA met with Holly Place Administrative Assistant Jean Grant, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also present during this inspection was Interim Program Administrator Dawn Moultrie, Executive Director Ron Dhillon, Program Coordinator Mandave Sandhu, and Case Manager Annie Patton, the assigned case manager for C1. Currently in care are 50 ambulatory non-minor dependent (NMD) clients. (Please reference LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 08/18/2021) During this inspection, LPA requested the following documentation: 1. Participant file for C1 - received 2. Incident reports involving C1 going back two months from this date (08/18/2021) - no serious incidents 3. LIC500 Staff Roster/Schedule - received 4. Case Manager case notes for C1 for July-August 2021 - received During this inspection, LPA conducted a confidential interview with S2. Based on review of facility records and personnel interview, it has been determined that the facility did not report the death of a nonminor dependent to the Licensing Agency within the 24 hour timeline specified in Interim Licensing Standards Section 86161. A deficiency is being cited per Interim Licensing Standards AB12 Nonminor Dependents, THPP, Article 6, Section 86161(b)(1)(c) - Reporting Requirements. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. At this time, one deficiency is being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Interim Program Administrator Dawn Moultrie, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Program Coordinator Mandave Sandhu regarding a complaint investigation at the Transitional Housing Placement Program. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA Bertoli interviewed participants, staff, and welfare worker, and reviewed documentation. The participant who was the alleged victim (see LIC 811 dated 3/29/22) had indicated that they would provide names, pictures, and text messages to corroborate the occurrence of the incidents, but none was provided despite multiple requests. This evidence was also requested by the Welfare Worker, and nothing was produced. None of the other persons interviewed had knowledge or evidence of the alleged incidents. A fight did occur at the participant's unit between C1 and C2, but there was no other indication of the related allegations occurring, aside from the statements of C2. LPA Bertoli was unable to determine if Case Managers allowed bullying of participants, or didn't meet participants' needs, or if the complex was unsafe, or if they failed to treat participants with respect. (cont. on LIC 9099-C)

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia made an unannounced case management inspection to review an incident that occurred on Tuesday, 6/28/22. LPA reviewed client records and discussed incident with Administrator, Holly Tracy. This case management inspection is now closed.

The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. narrative: On 5/15/23 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding incident reports not being submitted and maintenance concerns. No incident reports submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) since November 2022. During a review of case notes for a complaint, there were incidents where it needed to be reported to licensing. Some include property destruction and participants feeling unsafe. On 3/7/23, it was reported that there was a positive case of COVID. There was no incident report sent to CCL. LPA Ng discussed reporting requirements and advised staff that any escalated behavior, property destruction or injury is considered an incident and should be documented properly and sent to the department within seven days. In addition, certain unusual incidents, such as epidemic outbreaks are to be reported by telephone within 24 hours. All law enforcement contacts should also be reported to CCL. The facility failed to make the telephone report to CCL. LPA Ng also discussed maintenance concerns. On 4/18/23, LPA Ng did a walk through of a participant unit and found that the thermostat was broken and there was a bubble on the floor with mold inside it. LPA also reviewed maintenance records and corresponding emails found that the maintenance request for the thermostat and mold were on March 27th, 2023. It was not fixed as of 4/18/23. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80061(b)(1) Reporting Requirements and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Please refer to attached LIC 809-D. At this time, 2 deficiencies were given. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Mandave Sandhu, Interim Administrator.

deficiencies.description:
80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds: (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, there are maintenance requests that were made months ago that are still not fixed. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will ensure all maintenance requests are completed and fixed in a timely manner.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements: (b)Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, there has been no incident reports reported to CCL in 2023. Facility also failed to report epidemic outbreak by telephone within 24 hours.  This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will send in incident reports to  SBIRCR@dss.ca.gov and notify LPA Ng within 24 hours. Administrator will hold a meeting regarding reporting requirements. Meeting topics and staff signatures will be sent to LPA Ng by due date.

narrative: On 9/25/23 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management regarding an incident that happened on 9/8/23. This involved three youth (C1,C2,C3) being detained by Police and one of the youth having an unloaded shotgun during a police search. Hercules PD notified Program Manager Arnold Stance and an incident report was sent to CCL. LPA Ng asked for an update on the incident. Administrator stated that two of the youth were detained but released the same day and the youth who had the shotgun in their possession was released the following day. Administrator provided LPA with a detention certificate dated 9/13/23. Administrator stated that they were waiting for the police report but never received it. LPA Ng reminded Administrator that every time they receive an update on an incident like this, a follow up incident needs to be sent in. LPA gave the example of the detention certificate as an update. One technical violation was given, an exit interview was given, and a copy of this report was given to Administrator Mandave Sandhu.

On 03/26/2024 at 10:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted a Case Management and met with Administrator, Mandave Sandhu. LPA Rodriguez disclosed the purpose of the visit and was granted entry into the facility by the Administrator. LPA Rodriguez was advised that there was a strong smell of marijuana in one of the apartment complexes. THPP placements are not allowed to smoke inside of the apartment, it is in the regulations. LPA Rodriguez asked Administrator Mandave a few questions (See LIC 812). Administrator Mandave stated and showed a physical copy of their Shared Living Agreement under Health and Safety Items that, “All cannabis must be stored in a lockbox. It’s important for you to know that smoking marijuana is not permitted in any of the units.” Administrator Mandave stated that they want to take it out, due to the law stating that you must be twenty-one (21) or older to lawfully possess, use, transport, or sell marijuana. Administrator Mandave has been aware of the situation, and they want to change the Shared Living Agreement to not permitting any use or storage of marijuana inside the apartment units. Administrator Mandave has agreed to email LPA Rodriguez the revised version of the Shared Living Agreement. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was printed and given to Administrator Mandave Sandhu, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/6/2024 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an announced inspection to the above facility. The purpose of this inspection is to inform the facility representative that a complaint is being investigated regarding the above allegations. LPA Belfield met with Licensee Arnold Stance who assisted with this inspection. Based on confidential interviews conducted and supportive documentation to include but not limit, copies of leases and termination notices, the program was late and failed to maintain rental payments for at least two of the properties used to house THPP participants. As a result, at least two participants had to be relocated to new living units. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the clients in care. Therefore, these allegations are

narrative: On March 26, 2025 at approximately 2:30 pm Regional Manager (RM) Helga Wong and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) conducted an Informal Meeting with Licensee Arnold Stance. Present during the meeting was Licensee of Holly Place Arnold Stance, RM Helga Wong, LPM Carolyn Flynn, and Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shikya Belfield, Hanako Primer, Simran Nayyar, Omar Sawyer. The purpose of this meeting was to address recent concerns brought to the attention of the department. These concerns include but are not limited to program finances, health and safety participants, administrative organization, and plans concerning living units of current participants. During the meeting, LPM Carolyn Flynn requested LIC500, Mapping roster of current participants, documented plan regarding the relocation of the (5) participants that will be relocating, and updated staff records to be sent to LPA Shikya Belfield via email by March 28, 2025. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed Arnold Stance, Licensee. A signed copy of the report is requested to be sent back to LPA Shikya Belfield. *Type of Visit should have been Office.*

The purpose of the this meeting is to get clarity requested by Holly Place representatives, on the placement of the Non Minor dependents in their program. On June 17, 2021 at 1:15pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an announced visit to Human Edvancement Transitional Housing Placement Program for the purpose of conducting an annual/required. LPA met with Chanel Coopwood, THPP Director and Administrator who granted access to the office together toured the administrative office. The office space at the above address is a private suite with two desks and computers. One of the desks is intended for Social Work Supervisor who may oversee the case plans for placement. LPA Hernandez also observed two file cabinets and a printer in the office along with shelf space. File cabinets that will be utilized to store the participants and their client records. Per applicant, the staff records will remain on site and will utilize the available cabinet space at the administrative office. LPA Hernandez toured the Office Space and observed two conference rooms available for use and conducting private and confidential meetings with clients and social workers at the office. Administrator stated that she is planning to move to another a bigger office. There are no participants at the time of the inspection. Administrator stated that she submitted the paperwork to the county on June 8, 2021. A review of facility's personnel summary indicates that all staff who required to have a criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response. There are no deficiencies noted or cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, chapters 1 & 5. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the administrator due to technical difficulties with the printer.

On July 11, 2023, at 12:20 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA),Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to Human Edvancement Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for the purpose of conducting the second attempt, at an annual inspection. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 07/11/2023.This facility has a provisional Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) license to provide care and supervision for twelve (12) non-minor children ages 18-22 years old, Ambulatory only. LPA Wilson met with the Program Administrator (PA) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility files was conducted. LPA Wilson inspected the following: Operations, Program Statement, Client Records, Staff Files Disaster Preparedness. LPA Wilson interviewed (PA) using the inspection tool. Staff Files inspected (PA, S2, S3) Client Files (C1, C2, C3) who are the only residents at this time. (2) Type B Violations have been determined at this time. Type B: Regulatory Reference 86161(b): TV Regional Office has not received Incident Reports. PA provided LPA Wilson with copies of (2) incident reports dated 11/14/2023 and 04/01/2023. Type B: Regulatory Reference 86065(e) Staff have not had adequate training to meet the requirement. A Technical Advisory has been determined at this time. Regulatory Reference 87009(a): TA: License posted in the staff office, which remains locked. A copy of the report and the appeal rights were left at the facility.

narrative: On July 21, 2023 at 3:00 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk, held a TEAMS meeting with Licensee, Human Edvancement for the purpose of conducting technical support, review recent deficiencies, and to answer questions concerning regulations requirements. LPA Wilson virtually met with the Representative Facility Administrator (FA). LPA Wilson reviewed/discussed the children/staff's forms that are required, and to be maintained at the Facility so they are available for inspections. LPA Wilson went over the Child's Records documents, placement appraisal information LIC603, Appraisal/Needs and Service Plan LIC625, Identification and Emergency Information LIC601, Consent For Emergency Medical Treatment Children’s Residential Facilities LIC627B, Unusual Incident Report LIC624. LPA Wilson also reviewed/discussed the Personnel records, Health Screening Report, Facility Personnel LIC503, Personnel Record LIC501, Criminal Record Statement LIC508, Employee Rights LIC 9052, Personnel Report LIC500, Appeal Procedures For Applicants/Licensee LIC9058. LPA WIlson emailed the licensee copies of LIC624-LE, THPP Orientation Packet, a list of important CCL links and provided the relevant regulatory reference as questions arose.

On 2/6/24 at 11:12 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to Human Edvancement Transitional Housing Placement Program for the purpose of conducting a Required 2-year inspection visit. LPA and LPM met with Chanel Coopwood, THPP Director and Administrator and toured the administrative office. Applicant is utilizing an office space at the above address as the administrative office. The office space is a private suite with two desks and computers. LPA also observe one file cabinet and a printer in the office along with shelf space. The file cabinet is utilized to store the participants and staff records. LPA and LPM toured the Office Space and observed two conference rooms available are for use and conducting private and confidential meetings with clients social workers and CCL staff at the office. LPA requested and received a copy of the staff and client roster. Acopy of this report was given to the Licensee. Exit Interview Completed. No deficiencies cited.

On 2/6/25 at 11:12 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to Human Edvancement Transitional Housing Placement Program for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Licensee Initiated visit. Licensee is requesting a capacity increase from 12-24. LPA and LPM met with Chanel Coopwood, THPP Director and Administrator. LPA and LPM advised Licensee to submit a letter of recommendation with the updated capacity to Licensing after obtaining it from LA County. LPA advised Licensee to submit a list of certified and decertified units any times there is changes in the placement of the youth. LPA will conduct a final review of the application for a capacity increase and follow up with Licensee. Exit Interview Complete.

On April 9, 2025, at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis met with The Hyacinth Network Applicants Ashbinah Coney and Ahmaad Coney to complete Component II of the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) application process, the face-to-face interview. The Applicant attended Component I, the THPP orientation, on November 26, 2024. The purpose of the meeting was to review the THPP application process with the applicant, review incomplete licensing (LIC) application forms, and resolve any questions or concerns to ensure that the applicant understands the process and can provide the services outlined in the Program Statement (PS) and Plan of Operation (POO) submitted. LPA verified that the Applicant had applicable clearances and was associated with the THPP. During the meeting, LPA reviewed the LIC application forms, and the Section A documents review that was sent to the Applicant on March 26, 2025. During the meeting, LPA received updated LIC forms that were incomplete or missing. LPA informed the Applicant that the PS and POO would require revisions, and they have been provided to the Applicant. LPA will be completing the revisions and send those revisions to Applicant. The LPA discussed the Program Statement reviews, Transportations, Medical Services and Optional Services for the non-minor dependents in the program. (Continued on LIC 809C...)

The LPA also discussed LIC forms, 401 and 401a regarding questions for financial information. LPA will follow up with clarification on what information is needed on the LIC 401 and LIC 401a forms and will provide the clarification to the Applicant’s at a later date. LPA also discussed section B11 Control of Property and explained to the applicants that Community Care Licensing needs a copy of the rental/ lease agreement from the apartment complex they will utilize for the non-minor dependents to reside. The following documents were requested from the Applicant due by April 25, 2025: Documents Requested Rental/ Lease Agreement A copy of this report was printed and provided to the Applicant Ashbinah Coney. The original copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On July 9, 2025, at 09:50am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Robinson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection located at 11801 Pierce St. STE 200, Riverside, Ca 92505. The Licensee above submitted a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) application. LPA met with Ashbinah Coney, Administrator. Upon entrance into the facility, there are multiple businesses with private suites. The facility is located on the second floor with a locked door for privacy. There is one office that is equipped with two computer desks and two sofa chairs. The building holds a conference room located on the second floor and is available for use when requested for additional meeting space. The office holds a working telephone, computer and printer and scanner available for office needs. The facility will be holding client files that will be locked in the office. There is a staff break room equipped with refrigerator and microwave downstairs in the building. The restrooms are located inside the building upstairs and downstairs. A copy of this report was given to the Applicant.

facility_name: INNER CIRCLE: FIND YOUR WAY HOME
narrative: On 9/14/2020 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman conducted a Tele-Inspection with Michelle Tapp, Executive Director (ED) via FaceTime for the purpose of identifying an additional living unit. the facility has one client in care at another location. LPA inspected the apartment and observed the facility has a living unit that will accommodate two clients. The living unit contains household essentials including cooking utensils, furniture, dishes, pots and pans, a fire extinguisher, and two medication lockboxes. The living unit has a washer and dryer in the unit and the facility has provided laundry supplies. LPA observed the Certification of Compliance for the living unit, facility sketch and disaster plan are posted. The living unit is stocked with at least a seven day supply of non-perishable foods and the refrigerator is stocked with at least a two days supply of perishable foods. ED will post COVID-19 posters and flyers in the apartment. The living unit contains hand sanitizer and masks for the clients. The living unit is supplied with hygiene supplies for theh clients as well as cleaning supplies, The living room has one couch, a coffee table, an end table, a TV stand and a TV. The living unit is a two bedroom, one bathroom unit that has two full size beds with a mattress pad, sheets and pillows on the beds and there are extra sheets available for each bed. The bedroom contains a dresser and the closet contains hangers and storage bins for the client. The bedroom with the sink has a refrigerator in it for client use. The dining room has a table with four chairs. The kitchen has a microwave, toaster, and a cell phone available for the clients. The facility submitted the Certification of Compliance for this living unit, facility sketch, and disaster plan via email to LPA on 9/11/20. Effective 9/14/2020 LPA Stidman has determined the facility meets the requirement for the addition of Transitional Housing Placement living units per Health and Safety Code Section 1501(b)(5).

facility_name: INNER CIRCLE: FIND YOUR WAY HOME
narrative: On May 24, 2022, at 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yuvi Diaz and Yelena Palmer, Policy Analyst (PA) conducted an announced required- 2 year inspection. LPA Diaz met with Michelle Tapp, Executive Director who assisted with this inspection. LPA Diaz observed at the time of this inspection, the facility to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Facility office consisted of kitchenette space, five offices, and bathrooms. LPA Diaz observed the Foster Youth Personal Rights, covid posters, facility license, floor plan, and the emergency/disaster plan. LPA Diaz observed the files are stored in locked file cabinets in a locked designated room. LPA Diaz reviewed three staff files: one Administrator file, Executive Director file, and one Case worker file. They all contained the following documents: CPR./First Aid training, training's, job description, medical forms, and criminal record check. They also have DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse check clearances. A review of Licensing Information System on May 9, 2022, indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. There were no deficiencies noted at today's inspection. LPA Diaz completed all domains from the care tools: Physical Plant, Operations, and Disaster Preparedness, Staff Records, and Client Records Exit interview was conducted with Michelle Tapp, Executive Director. A copy of this report will be e-mailed to mtapp@innercirlcefindyourwayhome.org

facility_name: INNER CIRCLE: FIND YOUR WAY HOME
narrative: On 8/14/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor attempted an annual inspection at the above facility. When LPA arrived, a Social Worker informed LPA that the facility is no longer in operation. The Social Worker will have the Administrator call LPA. This report is created to document the attempted visit.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced pre-licensing inspection on 12/20/21 at 12:00 PM and met with Charlotte Paulsen, Executive Director and Seandy Gonzalez, Director of Journey of Hope (JOH) Programs. LPA toured two offices that are jointly used for Foster Family Agencies and Transitional Housing Placement Programs. There are two separate buildings that are used for offices for interviewing, social workers and interviewing. LPA observed the main office to have a reception area and a file area where all of the files are locked and inaccessible to individuals without keys. LPA observed that there is an adequate amount of privacy for interviews and office meeting space as well as storage. The facility has provided a program statement that is still under some revisions and the agency has agreed to complete all of the revisions within 60 days of licensure. The agency is ready to be licensed for the Transitional Housing Program at this time. The Transitional Housing Program will serve minors and nonminor dependents and have letters of support for the Unaccompanied Undocumented Minors and the Unaccompanied Refugee Minor Programs and this is the population to be served with this license at this time. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Paulsen.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced post-licensing visit 5/6/22 at 8:45 AM and met with Candace Milton, Supervising Social Worker who assisted with the inspection. LPA was informed that there are currently no participants in the transitional housing program and that they are actively recruiting for participants in the transitional housing. The program currently has social worker staff and social worker supervising but that they are not currently supervising participants at this time. LPA observed that there are office areas for private interviews, a waiting area for participants, and foster family business. LPA observed that the office is clean and accessible to the public and open and operating as required. LPA observed that the filing system is set up for THP files for minors and non minor dependents when participants are accepted. LPA observed that the fire extinguisher was last inspected on 2/7/22. LPA observed that the phone number listed on the facility profile needs to be updated as it is based on the application and has not been updated to reflect this location as of yet. LPA did not conduct staff interviews at this time since the program is not currently operating. LPA did not observe any violations at this time and no citations were issued at the conclusion of the visit. Exit interview conducted and document was provided to Ms. Milton and Charlotte Paulsen.

On 1/18/2023 at 10:05 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced Annual Inspection visit to the Institute for Children's Aid and met with Candace Milton, Assistant Director who assisted with the inspection. LPA Ajaero was informed that there are currently no participants in the transitional housing program. The program currently has social worker staff and social worker supervisors but they are not currently supervising participants at this time because they have none yet. LPA Ajaero conducted a tour of the facility. There are two buildings located within this premises. One building is used for the administrative offices and the second building is the Education center. At the Administrative building, LPA Ajaero observed that there is a large office space on the first floor, and three offices upstairs, with two restrooms. LPA observed that the office is clean and accessible to the public and it is open and operating as required. The filing system in the administrative building is set up for THP files for minors and non-minor dependents when participants are accepted. The Education center has three large rooms on the ground floor for private interviews, a waiting area for participants, and foster family visits, a full bath and a half bath. One of the offices contain backpacks and personal school items for the youths. LPA observed at the Administrative building that the fire extinguisher was last inspected on 4/22/22. LPA conducted four staff interviews. LPA did not observe any violations at this time and no citations were issued during this visit. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to Ms. Candace Milton.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the agency and met with Child & Family Specialist Administrator Jean Addison-Appiah who assisted with the inspection. LPA and CFSA conducted a walk through of the buildings. LPA observed: this agency is in a two-story home structure. There is a lobby area with a front desk, one conference room, three bathrooms, seven offices, one storage area, one kitchen area, and a computer wire room. The agency has a second building on the property for meeting with clients, and where the case managers operate. It is also a two story home structure, with a lobby area/front desk, three conference rooms, two bathrooms, three offices, a file room, one kitchen area, and one storage room. The buildings were clean and in good repair. The temperature was appropriate for comfort. Files are maintained in a secure location. Telephone service is available for clients to use. The license is posted as required. There were no deficiencies observed. LPA observed the agency's Plan of Operation. LPA reviewed the Emergency Disaster Plan and found that sections from Health and Safety Code 1565(a) are missing. LPA issued an advisory note for the agency to review this HSC section and update their emergency disaster plan to include all information required. LPA reviewed the Board Meeting minutes and the Board is meeting as required. The agency has no clients in placement. No citations issued on this date. An exit interview was conducted with Assistant Director Candace Pena and a copy of this report was provided to her.

On November 27 at approximately 8:50 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi arrived at International Christian Adoptions (ICA) Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Director Mallary Manimtim for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPA conducted a tour of the facility for a pre-license of a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for minors and non-minor dependents. The facility's headquarters/office is located in an industrial office park and the THPP facility is location in a home approximately 20 minutes away from the office. The ICA office includes available spaces for private interviews, family visits and social worker/staff desk areas. Client and personnel files are kept in locked file cabinets and are available for review by Licensing staff at any visit. The THPP home itself is located in a residential neighborhood and is a two story home with five bedrooms and furnished through out with all the necessary amenties including wi-fi internet access. The facility is staffed 24 hours a day / 7 days a week by ICA THPP staff. During the visit to the facility, LPA conducted a physical plan tour and completed Component II and Component III of the pre-licensing process. LPA also discussed a future Post-Licensing Visit and discussed solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations, personal fingerprint requirements, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA communicated the Department's and LPA's responsibility: Special Incident reporting requirements for LIC624, CC:internal procedures - AB388 reporting form LIC 624E. The facility will be notified once they are fully licensed as a THP/NMD facility. The license will expire one year from the effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 7 clients with the inclusion of 3 children of clients, for a total maximum of 10 persons housed in the THPP. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients, refugee clients, minor clients and non-minor dependent clients. The possibility of the facility requesting a capacity increase in the future, was also discussed.

After a final review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with a Technical Advisory was provided to Director Mallary Manimtim.

On March 19, 2025 at 9:50 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joon Choi arrived at International Christian Adoptions (ICA) Transitional Housing Program's (THPP) administrative office, and met with Director Mallary Manimtim (DIR) and Program Director Seandy Gonzalez (PD). The purpose of this visit was to conduct a post-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for children ages 16-17, non-minor dependents (NMDs), and pregant/parenting youth. A tour of the administrative office was conducted. Currently the THPP has three minor clients and three NMD clients placed in the one remote site home (among the clients, three toddler children are present, and one client is pregnant). The THPP office is located in an industrial office park and the THPP facility is location in a home approximately 20 minutes away from the office. The ICA office includes available spaces for private interviews, family visits and social worker/staff desk areas. Client and personnel files are kept in locked file cabinets and are available for review by Licensing staff at any visit. The THPP home itself is located in a residential neighborhood and is a two story home with five bedrooms and furnished through out with all the necessary amenties including wi-fi internet access. The facility is staffed 24 hours a day / 7 days a week by ICA THPP staff. THPP license was posted in the entry area. LPA reviewed LIC 500 personal report. THPP currently employs a Program Director (who is on call after hours), a Director, an Administrator, two social workers, a house manager, case aids, and six direct care staff (who cover all shifts, weekends, holidays, within the 24 hour day). With the assistance of DIR and PD, LPA reviewed five client files and five staff files. This THPP had physical hard copy files on hand. LPA also interviewed two staff (PD and DIR). Based on the post licensing inspection on this date, the THPP is in compliance.

An exit interview was conducted with Director Mallary Manimtim and a copy of this report and a Technical Assistance (TA) was provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Carolyn Flynn and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong met with Pamela Brown, Administrator (Adm) to conduct Component II of the orientation process at the San Jose Regional Office at 11:00 AM. The following items were discussed: Adm schedule Intake procedures Needs and Services/Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) Participant’s Personal Rights Visitation/Overnight Restricted Health Condition Organization – Board Members Finances School/Work for participants relationships Additional information discussed will be added to the Program Statement and re-submitted to LPA Flynn. Component III – Pre-Licensing Visit will be scheduled by LPA Madi Fremont once LPA Flynn receives and approves the above listed items. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed with Pamela Brown, Administrator, whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carolyn Flynn made an announced visit to the above listed facility to conduct a pre-licensing inspection at 10:30 AM on 09/03/2021. LPA was met by Licensee Pamela Brown who escorted LPA on a tour of the facility. LPA discussed that certificates for each apartment are required before clients can be admitted and need to be kept in the files. LPA reviewed the process that complaints will be conducted and verified that a Plan of Operations is secured on site. LPA also observed the conference area and private office with locked files. Licensee informed LPA that the telephone number has changed to 510-200-7642. LPA confirmed that rest of the office information and all is correct. LPA confirmed that Licensee does not have any further questions but did offer that she can contact LPA if questions do arise. LPA Flynn explained the timeline for getting the license. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed with Pamela Brown, Licensee, whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents

On 11/23/22 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Journey2Success' Administrative office. LPA met with Pamela Brown, Administrator. At 10:45 AM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Administrator of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Administrator about the residential unit. Administrator stated that the residential units have all working toilets, sinks and tubs. Administrator notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials. At 11:30 AM, LPA reviewed 7 participants files with Administrator. LPA observed all 7 participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA Ng discussed the facility capacity and limitations. The facility has a current capacity of 6. Facility was cited 86010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. (Please refer to 809D) At 12:15 PM LPA observed 2 staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. LPA Ng interviewed 1 staff. During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC 500 Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on November 23, 2022 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title 22 Regulations, 1 deficiency were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.
Visit was attempted on 12/12/23 at 1:00 PM. LPA will return at a later date to conduct annual. See LIC 812 pertaining to attempted visit.
On 01/02/24 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez conducted an attempted unannounced visit to the above facility. See LIC 812 pertaining to attempted visit.

On 12/29/23 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to complete the required annual inspection. LPA Rodriguez and LPM Wong met with Administrator Pamela Brown, at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA Rodriguez conducted the physical plant inspection, reviewed plan of operations plan and reviewed the disaster preparedness plan. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in locked cabinets. LPA Rodriguez reviewed six client files. LPA Rodriguez discussed the following with the Administrator: client files, disaster preparedness plan, and plan of operations plan. No staff was present to conduct interviews. At this time, the inspection is not complete. LPA Rodriguez will be back at a later day to complete the required annual inspection. LPA Rodriguez conducted an exit interview, and a copy of this document was printed and given to Administrator Pamela Brown.

On July 30, 2021 at 09:43 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Anastasia Flores and Valerie Wilson was greeted and granted access to facility by Program Administrator, Sarah Dehay. At 9:45 AM LPA’s toured the facility with Ms. Dehay. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing inspection of the facility Kamalii’l Foster Family Agency THPPP for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The office resides on business facility premises with a locked door. The office consists of four chairs and one front desk with a computer and telephone that will be utilized by staff. In the staff office there is a table, chairs and office desk with computer, telephone and a locked filing cabinet for staff files. In the second office there is a shelf utilized for THP + files, LPA informed Ms Dehay the office will need to obtain a locked filing cabinet for the NMD files. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The following were discussed: · Eric Mortensen is not yet associated to the facility license #337900041 · The facility will create a separate entrance for the THPP for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) Program and provide LPA Flores with a photograph via email when the changes have occurred. LPA informed Ms. Dehay that due to confidentiality the Foster Family Agency cannot have the same entrance as the THPP-NMD program. · The facility will have signs created and placed on the doors for the public view. · The facility will be sure to have an updated LIC500 sent to LPA Flores prior to being licensed. · The facility will be sure to have any and all employees fingerprinted and have background clearance completed prior to be hired. · Facility will send Education transcripts for Administrator and job application to agency. · Facility will have a doorbell installed for the other entrance and proof of installation will be sent via photo. (continued on next page)

· Component III for Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) was discussed by LPA Flores. · During this component LPA discussed Post Licensing Visits that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations; personal fingerprint requirements, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA communicated about LPA’s responsibility; Special Incident reporting requirements, for LIC624, CC: internal procedures, AB388 reporting form LE624E. LPA and applicant discussed where to locate a copy of the special incident report and provided applicant the email address and directions on reporting incidents to Community Care Licensing Riverside Office. LPA advised that this pre-licensing report and application will be reviewed by the Department. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a THPP/NMD facility. License will expire one year from effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 25 clients. It was discussed the possibility of expansion for the facility license in the future as stated in the program statement. An exit interview and a copy of this report was conducted and handed to facility representative.

On August 31, 2022 at 9:20 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Toni Castillo met with Administrator Sarah DeHav who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an unannounced post-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator. Currently the THPP has nine NMD placement's and five remote site apartments. The remote apartments are all within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area, a meeting/conference rooms, one case manager offices, administrative offices, locked storage area, two interview rooms, two bathrooms, and a kitchen area. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. THPP license was posted in the entry area. LPA reviewed LIC 500 personal report. THPP currently employs CEO/Program Director, Administrator (who is on call after hours) and a Case Manager. LPA reviewed five NMD files. This THPP utilizes a secured electronic computer program to maintain client and staff files which was available for LPA to review. LPA also reviewed all staff files which was a total of three. Based on the post licensing inspection on this date, the THPP is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Sarah DeHav and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On June 7, 2023 at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado, arrived at Kamali'i Foster Family Agency (FFA) and Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for the purpose of conducting an unannounced required two year inspection for the THPP for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD's). LPA's were granted access to the facility; Met and toured the facility with Sarah DeHay, Administrator. Currently the THPP has 17 participants and 11 remote site apartments. The remote apartments are all within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area, a meeting/conference room, one case manager offices, administrative offices, locked storage area, two interview rooms, two bathrooms, and a kitchen area. The office is equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. THPP license was posted in the entry area. LPA's reviewed LIC 500 personal report. THPP currently employs CEO/Program Director, Administrator (who is on call after hours) and two Case Managers. Facility provided a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. Staff was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Staff is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department and to include all Law Enforcement contacts. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Deaton emailed this report on 11/8/2021 to Krista Foster Homes (THPP). This report was not sent timely. The apartment has ample parking space for the residents. The bedrooms are all furnished with two twin size beds, dressers, closets and clean linens. On October 7, 2022, at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection with Administrator, Elizabeth Urenda, and was given a tour of the Remote Site Model home located in Costa Mesa. This is a single site facility that is moving over from the Laguna Niguel single site facility. The home is a single story with three bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility is licensed to have a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The residence has a desk, a large living room, and a recreation room that leads outside to the backyard. The yard also has additional chairs for sitting. The kitchen is equipped with working appliances and stocked with eating utensils, cups, glasses, plates, bowls and dishes and pans for food preparation. The kitchen has a table to eat at. The facility files (clients files and staff files) are going to be held at the corporate office in Irvine. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The garage will hold a washer and dryer for the clients, the washer and dryer has been ordered, and is waiting to be delivered. The facility has ample storage space in the garage. The garage will be emptied prior to accepting clients. The windows had blinds for privacy. The fireplace has been capped and is non-operable, which does not require a barrier at this time. There is a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and the garage. Bedroom 1 has one twin size bed, one dresser, and one closet. The bedroom does not have a mattress as a client in another location will be moving to the facility and will be bringing their mattress with them. At this time, there is only one bed in bedroom one with the capacity to add in another bed to allow two clients to reside in the bedroom. Bedroom 2 has two twin sized beds, two dressers, and a closet. Bedroom 3 has two twin size beds, two dressers, and a closet. All bedroom windows had blinds for privacy. No more than two clients will share any of the bedrooms. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

Prior to clients moving, the facility will obtain a working telephone line and send the invoice of service to LPA Linley. The facility will send photos of the washer, dryer, TV in living room, and pictures of the debris removed from the garage and backyard. Prior to clients moving in, the facility will send an updated LIC 610 form and any other forms with the updated single site address. The facility will post a copy of the license, personal rights, and the contact information for Community Care Licensing in the facility. The facility meets the Regulatory requirements and is ready for licensure at the conclusion of the visit. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator and a copy will be placed in the facility file.

facility_name: LGBT SANCTUARY PALM SPRINGS, INC., THE
narrative:
Based on confidential interviews and record review, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove the facility failed to follow the plan of operation. The Facility is cited under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, regulation 80022 (k) Plan of operation. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

The Department received a second allegation on July 6, 2020. The allegation alleged that around January 8, 2020, resident 6 (R6) was experiencing a severe mental health crisis. Per the allegation, the facility failed to react in a timely manner to R6’s mental health crisis. Confidential witnesses reported the facility staff offer services when a resident is experiences a mental health crisis. S1, S2, and S3 reported mental health services were offered to R6 however R6 continued to deny the need for services. CSW confirmed the facility offered mental health services to R6 however, R6 refused the offered services. Per LPA’s file review, R6 was encouraged to seek professional help and seek treatment from a psychiatrist or crisis center. Furthermore, the facility reached out to R6’s support system. Based on confidential interviews and record reviews the allegations that resident (R1) was inappropriately touched by another resident (R2) and facility staff did not seek medical attention for the resident (R6) in a timely manner may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Administrator Tammy Nelson. A copy of the signed report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On December 22, 2020 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Administrator Tammy Nelson via FaceTime to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. Due to COVID 19 a tele inspection was conducted. During the investigation, LPA interviewed five of six residents, four County Social Workers (CSW), one Probation Officer and three facility staff members (S1, S2, S3). LPA made three attempts to discuss the allegation with the sixth resident. Furthermore, LPA completed a review of the facility records. In addition, a facility tele-inspection was completed by LPA Zirbes on July 16, 2020 at 12:00pm. On July 6, 2020, the Department received an allegation that the residents were being left alone from the hours of 12am - 8am every Saturday night starting on May 9, 2020. All confidential interviews confirmed the residents were being left alone at the facility. LPA’s interviews with the staff members also confirmed the residents were being left alone at the facility. LPA reviewed the Department approved plan of operation. Per the plan of operation “House parents or resident managers will also be present during all non business hours including weekends or holidays”. Report continued on page two

deficiencies.description: 80022 (k) Plan of operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. The requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility failed operate in accordance with the Plan of operation when the residents were left unattended at the facility.  This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per Program Director, after the incident occurred and the staff left unexpectedly, Sanctuary Palm Springs submitted an update Plan of Operation which was approved by CCL on 8/26/2020. Sanctuary Palm Springs will follow and operate in accordance to current Plan of Operation.

investigation_findings: 13On June 29, 2022 at 10:15 Am., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Kuliema Calloway and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk arrived at the facility to deliver the findings of the complaint investigations conducted by LPA Enrique Hernandez. LPA and LPM met with Angelique Rangel, Adminstrator and discussed the investigative findings. During the investigation process, confidential interviews revealed that no one has seen any clients being sexually inapproapriate with one another. Although one statement stated otherwise, after the confidential interview the allegation was denied. The social worker has no concern with the facility and was never informed by any of the participants about the allegation. Continued on LIC 9099 C

13On 12/14/22, at 1:10pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA spoke with the office assistant and together, discussed the investigative findings. On 8/2/22, the Department received a complaint reporting allegations related to neglect and lack of supervision of transitional aged youth residing in Transitional Housing Placement Program. During the course of investigation, record reviews and interviews were conducted in order to determine findings of allegations. Regarding the provision of supervision of residents in care, record reviews conducted reflect that the licensee maintained the required staffing coverage during the assigned hours within the program. Further review reflects that emergency procedures are established within the program and made available to residents. Upon interview of staff and residents, it was confirmed that case management services are provided on a weekly basis, thereby providing residents with access to support and the opportunity to report concerns and obtain support from staff. Lastly, needs and services plans were reviewed and demonstrate the incorporation of mental health service goals for each resident. Due to the age of residents, all mental health services remain voluntary. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed with the staff and due to technical difficulties, a copy of the report was emailed to the facility administrator.

deficiencies.description: Criminal record clearance-(d) 	All individuals subject to criminal record review shall be fingerprinted and sign a Criminal Record Statement (LIC 508 [Rev. 1/03]) under penalty of perjury. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: P1 has not abided by the orders stipulated within the exclusion order, which took effect on 5/9/22, and has continued to: maintain presence within the facility, access client records and retain executive decision-making duties, which poses a potential risk to the health, safety and personal rights of residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility administrator and office administrator will ensure that only authorized individuals are allowed into the facility or have access to clients and/or client records. The facility administrator  will ensure that ALL staff listed on the LIC500 are trained on reporting uncleared staff to Community Care Licensing Division in the form of a complaint. The Facility Administrator will provide a copy of the training material script that is given to staff, along with signatures from all staff, confirming that the training was completed. The facility administrator and Office administrator will ensure that P1 is not allowed back in the the facility or have access to client records until a criminal record clearance is obtained. Proof of training will be provided to LPA O'Connell via email at nancy.oconnell@dss.ca.gov by 3/26/23.

narrative:
On 08/30/2023 at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell and LPA Jhane Haynes made an unannounced visit inspection to Living Arrows THPP Administrative Office located at 1560 E Main Street, #116, Ventura, CA 93001 for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA met with Marylou Andrade, facility administrator and Judith Rodriguez Case Manager, who granted access to the Administrative Office and together toured the office. The office building and is set up as follows: The administrative office Suite #116 accommodates only THPP staff and consists of entrance with a code to get into the office. LPA observed a station with a sign in sheet and temperature check. The office is a two-room office with a bathroom in good working order at the time of the inspection. The building is equipped with a large conference room that can be used for meetings or training. The second room is an attached conference room available with two desks computers. Staff and client records are maintained in the Administrative Office inside locked cabinets and through electronic record. All posting requirements were met. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP + FC) and Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) to 74 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one Continued on LIC809C.

(21). There are currently nine (9) participants in placement in the Ventura County. During the time of inspection, LPA O’Connell and Haynes conducted an inspection of the physical plant, emergency preparedness, and operations procedures. As part of the annual inspection, LPA O’Connell and LPA Haynes traveled to THPP remote site #1 in order to conduct a site inspection. LPA O’Connell and LPA Haynes inspected the property and observed functional carbon monoxide detectors, required posted documents, locked files, and emergency procedure binder. The kitchen was inspected and the refrigerator maintained required amount of food for clients. The backyard was clean, and orderly and free of obstructions or safety hazards. The interior portion of the facility was clean, and orderly. Due to time constraints, LPA O’Connell will return to complete the annual review. There were no deficiencies observed or cited during today's inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the administrator of the facility.

On 9-12-23, at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk met with the management team for 4kids2kids- Safe House (STRTP) and their related facility, Living Arrows-Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). The purpose of this meeting was for Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) to address operational issues for both facilities as well as matters related to qualifications of current/former staff. individuals in attendance: Marylou Escoto- Facility Administrator (FA), for 4kids2kids-Safe House (STRTP) and Living Arrows (THPP) Yazmine Sepulveda- Facility Manager (FM), for 4kids2kids-Safe House (STRTP) Christina Mengrahani- Head of Services (HOS), for 4kids2kids- Safe House (STRTP) Alaina Upthegrove- Bookeeper for Living Arrows (THPP) and (pending approval by CCLD) assigned "designee" for THPP Topics of discussion: a. Access to facility records - applicable regulation was reviewed and discussed due to recent inspections involving a delay/inability in accessing facility records by CCLD staff . LPM Sauk discussed the related requirement (Section 80044 Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency:) to allow CCLD staff to have access to all facility records, including medication logs during unannounced inspections. b. Fingerprint clearance of staff prior to working at facility- LPM Sauk informed FA of the requirement to ensure that staff are reflected as fingerprint cleared in Guardian, prior to working at the facility. LPM Sauk inquired about who has the authority to to grant new staff permission to work on the facility premises after verifying clearance. FA communicated that she is responsible for verifying all new staff are fingerprint cleared prior to anyone working within the facilities. LPM Sauk noted that FA is reflected as a "corporate board member" in Guardian and this inaccuracy would need to be corrected- FA agreed to update Guardian record. Continued on LIC809C

LPM Sauk addressed the inaccuracies in staff still showing as associated to the facilities in Guardian, but are being reported as "former" employees. LPM Sauk instructed FA that staff who are no longer employed by the organization, will need to be dis-associated from the Guardian rosters. c. Maintenance of required documentation- LPM Sauk addressed the substantial delays in providing the LIC500 to Licensing staff during inspection and informed the FA that the LIC500 (Personnel Report) shall be provided to CCL upon request. LPM further communicated that If the facilities choose not to use an LIC500 form, they may use a form of their own, which shall include all of the same information on the LIC500 at a minimum. Further, the LIC500 provided to CCL should be current and have the date of the LPA’s visit. LPM Sauk referenced the related regulatory requirements: Section 80066(e),Section 80066 (c), Section 80066 (f). d. Communication issues between the facilities and CCLD- due to ongoing communication issues in contacting the FA as well as and barriers in obtaining information for both facilities, LPM Sauk inquired about the point of contact for both facilities. FA confirms that she is the administrator for both the STRTP and THPP, but is supported by the FM (assigned to the STRTP) along with a newly assigned designee (assigned to support the THPP). FA explained that both the bookkeeper and FM can be contacted in the event of FA's absence. LPM Sauk gathered details about the newly assigned designee's/bookkeeper’s role in the facility, her qualifications, and scope of duties. A review of the bookkeeper’s qualifications will be conducted prior to granting approval as the new designee for the facility. LPA O'Connell communicated the need to engage in transparent communication and requested that all communication between the organization and CCLD include the FA. LPA O'Connell communicated instance where incidents have occurred and the FA communicated that she did not have awareness or was informed of the situation. FA agreed to communicate request to entire staff/board member group. e. Required staff and their qualifications- LPM Sauk inquired about who the identified Social Work Supervisors and Social Worker personnel are for the THPP. FA identifies that there is one Supervising Social Worker who reviews documentation. LPM Sauk requested additional information on the Social Work Supervisor to ensure qualifications. FA agreed. LPM Sauk referenced the following related regulatory requirement: Sections 86065.4 (Social Work Supervisor/Social Worker Ratio), 86065.2 (Social Worker Supervisor), 86065.3 (Social Work Personnel). Continued on LIC809C

f. Physical Plant of THPP facility- LPM Sauk informed FA that in 2022, the administrative assistant for the THPP reported that the second back-room office at the Living Arrows office would no longer be used as part of the facility, but CCLD recently found out that the office is still available for use. LPM Sauk inquired about the use of the space, as well as the function. FA reports that she did not have awareness of any plans to relinquish use of the space and the second adjoining office at the THPP remains part of the facility property. FA reports that the space is used to conduct meetings amongst staff and meet with clients as needed. g. Recent Deficiencies- due to the recent inspections of the STRTP facility, concerns regarding food storage and the physical plant cleanliness were addressed. LPM Sauk communicated awareness that the facility utilizes food pantry donations to supplement grocery store purchases for clients and communicated that food must be inspected regularly to ensure it is safe for consumption and not expired. LPM Sauk also communicated the need to maintain the facilities in a cleanly condition at all times, per regulatory requirements. FA acknowledged and agreed to address issue immediately. LPM Sauk concluded the meeting and communicated that a copy of this report would be provided to the FA for review and signature.

Based on the documentary evidence, interviews, and statements obtained during the investigation process, LPA was unable to determine if the above said allegations occurred therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the facility bookkeeper.

LPA met with Bookkeeper (BK) Alaina Upthegrove in leui of FA's absence and together discussed the investigative findings. During the investigation LPA Phillips interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information regarding the allegations. Staff denied the allegations listed above and reported no client information was being shared with former staff. Confidential interviews revealed residents have not been charged fees after relocating. Interviews conducted and documentary evidence, stipend log, email correspondence, and program policy regarding clients moving out the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. (Continued to LIC9099-C)
